The Breed is all bite.

A superior suburban chick flick.
A rose-tinted homage. But affecting too.

It seems like only yesterday the three wizardy sprigs were battling giant spiders and cracking conspiracies in the girls' toilets. That knowing comedy keeps this episode sharp.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

So bleak and depressing you will never look at a gemstone again without idly wondering how many lives it might have cost.

O'Toole is a lecherous marvel, and worth every ounce of his Oscar nomination for Best Actor.
Toby Jones defies the odds with an extraordinary impersonation of the author in Douglas McGrath's Infamous.

Few pictures can match the glamorous pull of Dreamgirls. Bill Condon's first big musical since Chicago is a glossy, gleaming Cadillac of a film with a vintage rhythm and blues engine tuned to perfection. The cast is dressed to kill.

Richard Eyre directs the film like a chamber play. He leans on Philip Glass's ever-present and insistent music like a crutch. But his natural gift for framing scenes is terrifically assured. A potent and evil pleasure.

The moral is hardly original. The scale certainly is. Only a director of Eastwood's standing could possibly terrify enough producers into financing this decidedly foreign, but impressively chunky, white elephant.
Damon's shirts are always crisp, but he has the charisma of a perfectly groomed corpse.
A choice cast fails to turn this woeful slapstick into the scathing attack on weak minds the film half promises.
The plot is as corny as a country and western song.
Norton looks tortured and old before his time as the humourless Eisenheim.

[Arriaga] has an uncanny understanding of damaged human beings. He needs to step away to let them live.

Woody Allen's spoof of the Don Juan myth Vicky Christina Barcelona is his best film this century.

Mumbai's brand new skyscrapers sprout out of patches of mud; Jamal's old-fashioned principles will forever be out of synch with the slick, nightclub world that his older brother Salim inhabits. And so it goes. The romance? Fear not. It's fabulous icing.
Stuart Gordon's low-budget thriller is so compellingly perverse that it transcends its humble premise.
An impressive chamber piece by a director who needs watching.

Hitchcock's classic 1946 thriller Notorious is a terrific romantic tango between Ingrid Bergman's exotic and spicy socialite and Cary Grant's prim and proper American spy. It's also shameless war propaganda.

The weakness of Aronofsky's film is that these various sentimental crises are framed with as much subtlety as Randy's wildly overdue heart attack. The film lurches into a predictable panic about dying alone.
The young director fails to inject us under the skin of his plotless drama of overdoses and funerals, but he clearly has talent to burn.
It needs something quite special to save this film from toxic splurges of sentiment. Lisa Kudrow and Kevin Dillon duly oblige as a pair of fabulously awful foster parents.

Faintheart is a wild folly. It's a romantic comedy devised, directed, cast, and produced by the online members of MySpace. In this slender respect it's a genuine sensation. But it looks and feels as knock-kneed as the ingredients.

The tedium is almost as annoying as the sound effects.

A costly and bemusing disaster. Dull is too kind a word.
Despite moments of improbable whimsy, this is a hugely affecting film. Important, too. It engages with the complexity of the Holocaust in a language that can move children as profoundly as adults.

don't have the willpower, words, or energy to explain why a psychopathic CIA computer suddenly decides to take over the world. But that's the plot in a nutcase.

While it is a nice twist to make The Mummy a princess, Sofia Boutella's bringer of destruction feels like a sideshow in her own story.
Of course, there are some things you can always count on in a Sparks adaptation - sandy locations, star-crossed lovers and searing melodrama, all tied in a neat emotionally manipulative bow.

Finlay reminds one of a young Winona Ryder as she winsomely juggles learning to garden with letting her guard down, while the always watchable Andrew Scott once again proves to be a scene-stealer with his kindly cook.
A cross between Kiwi rugby documentary The Ground We Won and an Aussie outback horror film, Hotel Coolgardie is a compelling yet chilling watch.
This overlong, overwrought and once-over-lightly dramatisation of the life and death of US rapper Tupac Shakur feels like something cut-and-pasted from biopic-making 101.
Despite the coolest deity casting since Dogma's Alanis Morrisette, this faith-based fantasy won't win over many non-believers or cinematic admirers.
Surrounded by a solid supporting cast and making the most of a few memorable lines, Whittaker's skills help lift what would otherwise be just a solid, unspectacular drama.
A charming and charismatic coming-of-age story that's part Dead Poets Society, part Sing Street.
[It] should have been a lot for fun, [but] sadly it's almost "absolutely anything" but.
An entertaining slice of Disney Channel-esque subversive comedy that will appeal to both tweens and adults.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the depressingly episodic nature, predictable plotting and clunky dialogue, there are some bright spots to behold.

Filled with dramatic tension, complex characters, rich, memorable dialogue and uncomfortable reflections of the plight of many modern day Americans, David Mackenzie's contemporary western is a compelling watch from go to whoa.
Miss Peregrine is a breathless, rollercoaster ride of an action adventure that makes full use of today's special effects wizardry and the costuming genius of Colleen Atwood.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Feels slightly over-egged is with the script's repeated mantra of the importance of farm fresh ingredients.
Liberal laughs are guaranteed but memorable it ain't.
Hits all the themes, twists and turns without ever really providing anything memorable.
Filled with literal and metaphysical stone throwing between the religions, Agora is saddled with a muddy narrative and too many blokes who look alike.
Don't be put off by the golden-hued, overly saccharine opening to this seemingly twee December (in both senses of the word) romance, because it hides a final quarter that packs an emotional wallop.
This horse-sports-opera boasts all the ingredients for a successful run.
A star-studded re-imagining of a classic piece of literature that shoots for the moon, aims for laughs and misses both targets by a country mile.
...as dire a comedy as you're likely to see all decade.
The darkest and gleefully funniest Christmas movie since Gremlins.
This is light-entertainment with a message, with clearly defined goodies (the girls) and baddies (almost everybody else).
Provides a great showcase for Carell's brand of deadpan nuttiness.
This slice of science and sorcery feels like a throwback to the 1980s heyday of family films.
Keeps the focus firmly on the kids and their point-of-view - no cutaway scenes of evil generals plotting in their native tongue here.
'Greek' works best during the cleverly scored mayhem montage scenes (a highlight involves absinthe and a French version of Happy Together).
A welcome relief. However, it is still far, far away from the heights of the first two installments.
An interesting concept but it's a shame about the execution.
A charming and compelling account of Tolstoy's last year.
Coming hot on the heels of The Road, Eli is a far more conventional and formulaic vision of future hell.
Although based in reality, John Lee Hancock's tale never seems more than just a more serious version of TV's Different Strokes or Webster.
It's not without its charms... But, in the end, there's not enough bring-the-house-down moments to warrant gambling 90 minutes of your time by seeing this.
...rose-tinted, sun-dappled flashbacks and clever use of split-screens and slow-zoom dramatic reveals add to the fromage and homage factor to '70s TV.
Come back Bella and Edward - all is forgiven.
Even the most ardent 'adult' comedy fans will emerge feeling slightly dirty and more than just vaguely disappointed.
A prime example of romantic-comedy by the numbers.
Great and powerful? More like merely good and enjoyable.
Another excellent, less-than-flattering biopic of a Hollywood icon.
As an acting masterclass, it's educational and entertaining.
Drugs, exotic dancers, dodgy deities. This certainly isn't your usual po-faced, worthy Middle Eastern tale.
Surprisingly sentimental, superior stoner comedy.
The lucky ones will be those who give this a wide berth.
Pirates' attention to detail and determination to give the audience a rollicking good time is worthy of acclaim.
There's just something missing in translation from that most powerful book.
Fish Tank meets Skyline in this hilarious and arresting British sci-fi comedy.
Dafoe is at his inscrutable best, giving his gun-for-hire a sense of character via obsessions with opera and baths.
Veering from Amelie-esque whimsy to The Hours-like maudlin.
Those expecting something more cerebral will be deeply disappointed.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A joyless, overstuffed confection that seems designed more to maximise product placement.
Swingers for sexagenarians, Salt is perfect for older audiences who like a little spice in their cinematic offerings.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director James Marsh mines yet another long-forgotten slice of '70s madness.
A thoroughly entertaining movie that deserves to sleigh audiences both young and old this Yuletide.
...you can't help feeling this dreary tale could have done with a bit of fancy editing or narrative reconstruction.
Debutant director O'Connor's lively documentary goes some way to capturing the eclectic and eccentric nature of the label's management and recording artists.
movie_title: Upside Down: The Creation Records Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Read all the allegories and allusions you want into it, at its heart though War is innovative, intelligent and indelible cinema.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Screenwriter Shaun Grant keeps many of the novel's weighty themes, but delivers them with such verve and taut-storytelling that watching it all unfold is a joy.
While some of set-pieces feel awfully familiar, there's enough memorable moments to keep audiences and in particular primary-aged kids entertained and enthralled.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: No disrespect to either John Lithgow or Brian Cox, but this is the Winston Churchill performance from the past year to you need to see.
... the first must-see of 2018.
Andrew Garfield and Claire Foy's chemistry is what lifts this surprisingly inert period drama.
Beautifying shot, hauntingly scored and terrifically acted, Call Me By Your Name is a film whose imagery (particularly its final shot) and characters will stay with you for days.
Doubling as a fine critique of modern day Hollywood, The Hero is a terrific piece of counter-programming for those who prefer their long summer evenings blockbuster-free.
The first feature-length version of Munro Leaf and Robert Lawson's much-loved more-than-80-year-old children's book, Ferdinand is an amiabull, entertaining romp for cinemagoers for all ages.
Remake, sequel, reboot, reimagining - call it what you will - this return to the world of Chris Van Allsburg's much-loved 1981 picture book is actually better than anyone could have hoped.
Meticulously crafted, perfectly paced and brilliantly acted, the only thing that lets this terrific 1970s-set thriller down is too many ideas.
Let's just hope if there is a follow-up, that it comes with a few more three-dimensional characters and original storytelling.
A film not for the faint-hearted, easily-offended or frequently irritated by "kids these days", Florida is nonetheless a vibrant and vital slice of modern American cinema.
Yes, while it aims to combine celebrity voices, memorable music and Christian values, The Prince of Egypt this ain't.

In the end, Borg vs McEnroe feels like an excellent primer for those born too late to remember the pair in their pomp and an interesting character study for those who were gripped by their contrasting styles.
... a little gem that deserves to find a global audience.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Based on historian Les Standiford's book of the same name, The Man Who Invented Christmas benefits mostly from some smart casting and lively pacing from director Nalluri (Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day).
... as actor Paul Scheer said at The Disaster Artist's Toronto Film Festival premiere, "it's the perfect prequel for those who've never seen The Room and the perfect sequel for those who have".

Yes, there will be humbugs who suggest the plotting is a touch predictable, the action overly knockabout, the tale too twee, but this perfectly pitched, magnificently paced film is a delight for audiences of all ages.
As with the hilarious and highly entertaining 2014 original, Paddington 2 provides some of the best family entertainment you'll have at the cinema all year.
The battle of wits between humans and the assorted animals provides much of the laughs and most of the best scenes of this amiable but unmemorable animated adventure.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ponoc's Mary possesses the same strong female protagonist, weird and wonderful beasties and slightly surreal charm as Ghibli's best.
Spanish helmer Collet-Serra keeps the action, twists and conspiracy coming thick and fast, while also throwing in some artful editing and genuine jumps.
Anna Biller's bravura slice of burlesque cinema is at once deliciously innovative and delectably old school.

... while screenwriter Joe Carnahan (TV's The Black List, Smoking Aces) tries to inject some kind of debate about Kersey's actions into the story, director Roth decides to go more grand guignol the longer the story goes on.

Paramount executives were concerned Garland's movie was "too intellectual" and "too complicated" to appeal to wider audiences. What rubbish - Annihilation is the thrilling, smart science-fiction movie you need in your life...
... thanks also to a terrific commitment to naturalistic lighting and hand-held cameras, that focus pays off in spades come the final third of the film.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an impressive cast that also includes Sarah Snook (Predestination), the Spierig brothers' (Daybreakers, Jigsaw) haunted house horror never really compels or offers anything more than low-level chills.
A kind of a cross between My Weekend with Marilyn, An Education and the 1980s TV series Bread, Film Stars is a sumptuous slice of movie making that deserves to find a wide audience.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot to like about Finding Your Feet.

A cross between Death at a Funeral and a Mike Leigh/Woody Allen-style domestic drama, Potter's twisty-turny narrative never feels forced if, at times, it strains credibility by how action-packed one soiree can be.
A deserved nominee for Best Documentary at this year's Academy Awards, Abacus is as fascinating as it is likely to foment rage.

Similar in style to Listen to Me Marlon, Asif Kapadia's Amy or Brett Morgan's Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, Lili Fini Zanuck's look at life of Eric "Slowhand" Clapton offers plenty of visual treats and audio gems.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shot over five years, Sophie Fiennes' fly-on-the-wall documentary of the pop-culture icon-cum-provocateur Grace Jones is a fascinating look at the life of a true original.
So while, at times, it slavishly lives up its title, The Ritual does a great job of telling predictable horror tropes in a terrifying new way.
Entirely hand-painted by a team of more than 100 specially-trained artists, this animated historical mystery is a breathtaking achievement.
Throw in an effective orchestral score and a couple of genuine surprises, and the result is an unexpected delight.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you enjoyed The Social Network or Steve Jobs, with their psychological insights, compelling characters, clever soundtrack choices and non-sequitur asides, then you'll love this.
Bunch creators David Alaux, Eric Tosti and Jean-Francois Tosti have come up with an intergenerational animated action movie that is at its best in its moments of humour...
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... the result is a thoroughly entertaining and strangely thought-provoking watch.
... The Stolen does have the look of a high-class revenge movie, just one that's sadly let down by predictable plotting and overwrought and off-kilter final act.
At once almost surgically precise and gleefully messy, The Killing of a Sacred Deer is certainly not a film you can easily forget - and nor should you wish to.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... there's an overwhelming sense of deja vu about Coco.
... undemanding fare for under-sixes and bronies alike.
A solidly made reminder that the spectre of terrorism has been with us for some time.
An entertaining and enlightening watch.

This decade's Hustle and Flow, a funnier, female version of 8 Mile, Clerks 2017 - whatever your take on writer-director Geremy Jasper's feature debut, Patti Cake$ is a riff on the old A Star is Born plot unlike any you will have seen (or heard) before.
... I'm pleased to report that while Wind River doesn't reach the high water mark of those two superb tales it's still a terrifically atmospheric drama.

Gorgeous overhead shots of the plains and river beds contrast sharply with weed-choked tributaries and defecating cows as the film-makers highlight the link between the intensification of farming. . .in the area and river degradation.
Finally a corset drama that's also a bewitching delight.
The trio of leading ladies are all impressive and the script filled with dramatic and satisfying confrontations, but some scenes feel a little too staged to really hit home.
A kind of Phone Booth-meets-Enemy Mine by way of The Hurt Locker, Doug Liman's single-location drama is notable mainly for a fine acting performance and impressive evocation of space and place.

Filled with colourful characters, crazy situations, clever camera shots and choice soundtrack cuts, Logan Lucky's beautifully layered plot features more twists and turns than a Nascar race (which admittedly isn't hard).
After sampling the cuisines of the Lakes District and the land of La Dolce Vita, Rob Brydon and Steve Coogan are back for a third course of gastronomic delights and competitive celebrity mimicry.
A Date For Mad Mary feels like an Ireland-set cross between Bridesmaids and Muriel's Wedding.
This third cinematic adaptation of Dutch author Herman Koch's cynical 2009 novel feels like it has had a little too much Hollywood gloss added to it.
The second Wonder Woman origin story to hit cinemas this year might not have the same action chops as Patty Jenkins' blockbuster, but it certainly delivers on thought-provoking adult entertainment.
Before Sunrise/Sunset for baby boomers, your enjoyment of Paris Can Wait will depend on your tolerance for food porn, the French countryside and seemingly charming Gallic men.
By the end you'll be cheering for the surprisingly under-utilised sharks and marvel even more at just how good The Shallows really was in comparison.
A very entertaining, enjoyable and engrossing journey.
Diverting, but not essential viewing.

... while some of their footage is truly breathtaking, the bootcamps and mountain-top descents offer up an overwhelming sense of déjà vu, from both Man on Wire and last year's horrific Point Break remake.
There's a lot to like about this solidly made drama...
A timeless and timely look at love in all of its complicated forms, The Big Sick also examines parental sacrifice and the immigrant's dilemma of assimilation versus tradition.
[Florence Pugh] delivers one of the truly mesmerising and memorable performances of the year as the compelling, conniving and at times chilling Katherine.
Although, at times, the portentous dialogue threatens to overwhelm the fun factor, Battle succeeds thanks to the charisma and chutzpah of its two leads.
Ghost in the Shell reminds one of another adaptation with whizzy visuals and an ass-kicking leading lady battling an evil corporation while wearing a series of eye-popping outfits - Resident Evil.
... like its seven successors, this latest instalment of the horror franchise offers up the usual diet of gruesome visuals delivered with grim and grimy elan.

... Christine Baranski's Ruth (Amy's controlling Mom), Cheryl Hines's Sandy (Kiki's clingy Mom) and Susan Sarandon's Isis (Hahn's feckless Mom) nevertheless get all the best lines and deliver plenty of hearty laughs.
... Son of Bigfoot contains plenty of memorable characters and dialogue.
... Tulip Fever is simply a blooming disaster.
It all adds up to the cinematic equivalent of a warm, but slightly moth-eaten blanket.
To its credit though, Mountain doesn't end in an obvious place - an extended coda adding more poignancy and emotional depth than what a traditional Hollywood romantic action-drama might have.
Those of you who think television has monopoly on thought-provoking, quality adult drama should check out Benedict Andrews' cinematic debut.
Giacometti's endless delaying tactics and his prosaic nature means Final Portrait weirdly feels both once over lightly and somewhat slow all at once.

In the end, it's all fairly light and fluffy fare, but made with care and shot with aplomb, it sums up expertly how these furry Istanbul inhabitants embody the chaos and are part of the soul of that city.
... A Ghost Story feels like one of the most intimate pieces of moviemaking in years.
... it all feels a little bit like a sporting episode of Upstairs, Downstairs and comes off as overly twee to really compel.
So just when the familial schmaltz threatens to overwhelm proceedings, there's always a dated pop reference or scatological gag to leaven the mood.
Diverting, but hardly memorable viewing.
... The Changeover offers the rare sight of a fantasy that feels both distinctly Kiwi and contemporary and that's something to be celebrated and cherished.
Flatulent, but not fatuous fun.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At once a blast from the past and thoroughly modern moviemaking.
A nuanced, occasionally beautiful work, though not flawless.
The film falls short on tension, eloquence, spiritual challenge -- things that have made the original New Testament stories so compelling for 20 centuries.
It's a pleasure simply to hear a familiar story well-told.
It's a long, hard ride, but it's worth getting to the trail's end.

This hurry-up sequel delivers the same brand of paranoid, blood-covered, barely clinging-to-an-R-rating action as in '06, featuring a similar pack of desert-dwelling super freaks who wreak murderous havoc on unsuspecting visitors.
A summer movie trifle that's somehow shamelessly derivative and genuinely amusing at the same time.
Charlie's Angels 3 it ain't, but big up to director Corey Yuen for crafting a splashy and appropriately trashy fighting flick that chicks can cheer for.
Frederik Du Chau transforms the campy '60s and '70s cartoon into a mostly toothless, family-friendly action-comedy.
[A] clumsy supernatural comedy, dogged by truly lifeless plotting and a near-total lack of chemistry.

This music-driven melodrama aims to salute and promote a cultural phenomenon -- reggaeton music, in this case -- by slathering it all over an instantly forgettable, cliché-laden pop flick.
Feel-good themes of resilience, faith and family aren't sufficient to redeem this scattershot single-parent dramedy from the Diary of a Mad Black Woman auteur.

What is it good for? Absolutely nothin', unless you're in the market for 90-plus minutes of vacant macho brooding, dog-eared action-flick clichés and so-so fight scenes that squander the talents of its star players.
A big-screen outing for the small screen Nancy Drew-alike that puts the 'fun' into 'crowdfunding'.
Less a three-lane pile-up than a minor traffic violation in a residential area. Three points for Waugh, then, and a 60 fine.
It's a pacey, enjoyable yarn for the most part, but the franchise's key strength is its characters and the relationships, tired by part two, are seriously running out of steam.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Brawny but brainless techno-twaddle.
An enjoyable escapade and a great introduction to the forthcoming series -- just not the seventh Star Wars film fans were hoping for.
An engrossing story that plucks at the heartstrings just as hard as it pummels the fire buttons.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Less painful than having your chest cut open, but a disagreeable experience just the same.
This slick and sticky horror is the most accomplished treatment of vampire lore since Near Dark.
The payoff Bourne fans have been waiting for.
A large step backwards for a promising director and far from the return we'd been hoping for.
Charming children's adventure with some superb performances from the young cast.
A cool idea rapidly falls apart. A completely missed opportunity.
Unengaging, uninspired and unwatchable. A criminal waste of time and talent.
Undeniably funny and gooey to boot, Slither may not be groundbreaking but it is a rarity: a horror-comedy that does both its genre-parents proud.
It's this unwavering fidelity to the source material that is also the film's biggest problem.
Evolution's action sequences are as horribly bungled as its plot, resulting in a string of repetitive confrontations that feel toothless even by the last movie's standards.
An appropriately serpentine plot makes for an engaging thriller. It's a shame then that the final showdown is so daft.
Brainy, barmy and beautiful to behold, this is Stephen Hawking's Star Trek: a mind-bending opera of space and time with a soul wrapped up in all the science.
A severe portrait of fortitude under extreme pressure, somewhat marred by blinkered politics.
A competent procedural rather than the ground-breaking cybersaga we'd hoped for. But as with Miami Vice, Mann's boundless style does a remarkable job of disguising the lack of substance.
A fitting conclusion to Jackson's prequel trilogy and a triumphant adieu to Middle-earth.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Worth watching for the sight of Will Smith beating a fairy to death with a broom, but it takes a far more sophisticated grasp of the fantasy concept to really get away with Mordor.
Inoffensive fun, but unlike its paperback forbear, the cinematic Ferdinand is unlikely to stand the test of time.
Daft as a badger sandwich and twice as funny, this is vintage Waititi, and the boldest, most outrageously fun film Marvel has yet produced.

After the last film's ballistic finale, it would have been easy for Matt Reeves to sit back and hurl fur and fireballs at the screen for two hours... [but] War is a more subtle beast than its title implies.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Often confusing and far too po-faced, Kurzel's stabby period piece is redeemed by its sumptuous vistas and top-notch fight work.
This is a touching, heartfelt tale of loss and love for the Gravity generation.
The ultimate Star Wars fan film, it's short on whimsy but when it gets going there's enough risk-taking and spectacle to bode well for future standalones.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Radcliffe menaced by a hostile bush is far more entertaining as innuendo than actual drama. What might have been Deliverance in the tropics is rather a Dan versus wilderness yarn.
None of the tales have meat enough to satisfy alone. Together, though, they form a varied backdrop to showcase some respectable character work.
Instead of bringing much-needed clarity, Allegiant piles on yet more bamboozling mythology to flummox and confound.
Diesel is comfortably watchable as the unstoppable immortal (when not chewing on hand-me-down Wookiee chin fuzz) but even his rumbling charms can't save this, nor justify its sequel-bait sign off.
A bizarre and beautiful detour on the Marvel journey, which culminates in a mind-bending, expectation-inverting final act.
Neither a Medellin-style disaster nor an Aquaman-sized hit, this pays decent fan service but an Ari-centric spinoff might have been the smarter move.
Slightly overlong and glosses over certain aspects but a profound examination of a tortured artist.
A group more bulletproof than The Avengers, causing more mayhem than General Zod. Think Universal doesn't have a superhero franchise? Think again.

For a film with such a thinly worked conspiracy, The Gunman is inexplicably hard to follow, relying on lack of clarity to disguise by-the-numbers plotting. Still, if you're in the market for some well-wrought mayhem, you could certainly do a lot worse.
Claustrophobic and exhausting, Them fumbles its payoff but reminds us why French chillers are a rare but thrilling treat.
What's significant about this is that three of Asia's most creative forces have come together in a single project.
This is a breathtaking, thoroughly crafted piece of near-perfect filmmaking that's scarier than bloody hell.
A patient, naturalistic white-knuckled ride of terror.
A mediocre genre film that fails in both genres.
The events in Night Watch carry greater weight because they have a natural, historical progression to them.
Edgy, and hard-hitting, it's an important film of immense power and should be seen by everyone who cares about the youth of America.
The Vengeance Trilogy is a remarkable accomplishment not only for Park, but for world cinema and lovers of the extreme who finally have a collection of films they can truly call art.
Factotum, which means general servant, shows that Bukowski's stories are as interesting, funny, tragic, and relevant as ever.
Right from the opening credit sequence, District B13 makes it loud and clear that you're going to like this movie.
The Dardennes waste no time involving the audience in the narrative, through both their hand-held, cinema verité style of filming and by having events take place in real time.
The Hidden Blade is worthy of being loved by foreign film buffs and samurai film geeks alike.

What's wrong with the 2006 version? Well, it has none of the positive elements of the original, and there's no chemistry between Stiles and Schreiber. The acting, the music, the photography, and the technical elements are all fair to downright awful.
The Descent marks the arrival of a major horror talent. And it is, quite simply, one of the best monster movies in years.
Kirby Dick's film is a scathing indictment of the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA), and anyone with any interest in film should see it.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable debut of undeniable power.
Isn't anywhere close to perfect, but giving yourself over to its performances is wonderfully rewarding.
Showcases some fantastic photography, terrific acting, and a superb soundtrack, but it's not the masterpiece that Paris, Texas is.
Even though you might not think dummies are that creepy or scary it's rather the themes that are universal and that's what works.
It's not a particularly great thriller and even at 96 minutes is too long.
It aims for the status of psychological thriller but is not deep enough in either character or motivation and certainly it doesn't thrill.
Limited, undemanding and slight certainly, but ultimately sweet and inoffensive.
Unnecessary and inessential, this film is definitely, inarguably a film. Meh.
It's an odd dance of tones Moran is trying to work together here and he's to be admired for it, even if only for the bonkers nature of the concept.
There's an arthouse influence that's just as heavy as any horror or thriller elements and it's this that threatens to undermine the sense of slow build panic that Ashraf experiences
The real problem comes from struggling to figure out who would actually enjoy this.
This is filmmakers having a good time and making something eminently fit for a late Friday night's undemanding viewing, and sometimes that's all you need.
It never quite pulls together, never quite chills as it could do, but overall is a decent film that has ambition and is an agreeable enough way to spend an hour and a half.
That this sad, grim drama remains compelling to its end is down to the work of Wyss, Peduto, Stewart, and Hutson.
It has a commendable ambition to simply entertain and benefits greatly from its two central performances.
It's pleasing that adventurous filmmakers like Balderson and Spear are producing low-budget, competent, exciting movies that are made by film fans for fans of film.
1931's The Public Enemy is still at this stage one of the best gangster films ever made.
Whilst it certainly won't be to everyone's tastes, we enjoyed this twisted little meditation on loneliness reaching beyond death, and recommend you give it a try.
If you're a Franco fan or like interesting takes on how film is constructed, or how film can subtly comment on the world it exists in, then you're likely to get something out of this and for you.

If you do manage to catch this, you're not likely to be thrilled but you'll probably not hate it either. By no means is this inessential or worth seeking out, but overall, it's alright for what it is.
Whether you consider any of this good or bad or if you find Enk's experimentation compelling or irritating is entirely subjective. It's almost redundant to offer review for work like this.
If you're a Russell fan you should know what you're in for and, overall, it's a well-constructed, entertaining film.
movie_title: The Lair of the White Worm (1988)

movie_review_blurb: It's no salacious biography, so you're not going to find any mention of scandal or any dark side to the dream Taylor went after. It's instead more a celebration of his achievements and as such is going to be of most interest to Taylor's fans.

Karl, we hate to do things like this ... But really, no-one should think maybe because it's got you in it, or Pacino, or they like other films like Seven or that type of film, that this might be good, because it isn't.
There's some influence from the burgeoning giallo films, but here done with a drab, autumnal early '70s British approach, which is actually interesting.
movie_title: Fear in the Night (Dynasty of Fear) (Honeymoon of Fear) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dreadful misfire, alternately laughable and dull and never managing to become more than a cult oddity.
Curtis' 'hero' is an unmitigated swine who cuts a swathe of destruction through the lives of all around him. Highly recommended.

This film is one of those bizarre ideas that you're surprised in retrospect ever got off the drawing board. It's not especially funny, but it's hard to hate a film where a bad guy tries to kill Invincible with a machine gun hidden in a plastic fish.
Its appeal is certainly wider than simply a Blaxploitation curio and it transcends any labels to be a great thriller, horror film and social commentary.

The film itself stands alongside other contemporary films as an example of how science fiction can be used to comment on the world it exists in at the same time as being a very entertaining spectacle.
It's a compelling, bleak film that's well made and worthy of your attention.
movie_title: The Moose Head Over the Mantel (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bay assures us this is his last Transformers film but really, it doesn't matter, the damage is already done.
It's subversive, haunting, horribly compelling stuff, and that comparison with The Devils is one Witchhammer can well withstand.
Mirror, a new film by Andrei Tarkovsky, the controversial and unorthodox Soviet director, is delighting, puzzling, disaping serious Muscovite movie enthusiasts.

If you have the stomach, there's a revelatory performance from Vaughn beneath all the bloodshed. A master class in controlled rage, he's the beating heart of the story and the reason it is so affecting.

A hollow film that feels rushed and insincere, A Bad Moms Christmas is far from the festive satire it purports to be.
What happens on screen may never outlive what happened off it, but for around two hours Scott's thrilling ride will make you forget the headlines.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully filmed testimonies that tear at your soul.
the relationship between McCarthy and Bullock is spot on and makes the film worth watching

Too many times, a franchise has almost been taken by surprise at its success and produced a follow-up that is rushed and soulless. This film happily avoids that trap, but also might be one of the best movies of the year.
The film belongs to [Ryan] Gosling. He evokes the classic detective heroes of cinema, hiding his need for connection just beneath a hard surface.
There are many positive points to Brimstone, a brutal Western with a point to make about female subjugation. Unfortunately, that point gets lost due to an unnecessarily long running time...
It's a film maker seeing how far he can push you, not realising that the line was passed about half an hour in.
If you're looking for innovation you've come to the wrong arena. What Last of the Enforcers is about is taking likeable characters and creating an enjoyable excuse to spend more time with them.
Given the man himself is so interesting, it's frustrating that his portrayal is so bland.
As a film... The Dark Tower is a messy affair that lets fans, newcomers, and its own star down.
Combine that with superb direction, and it will be a must see for Art-House fans who need an intelligent antidote to Hollywood's drab summer offerings.
A forgettable flight of fantasy.
While it's passably interesting, England Is Mine leaves the impression that a true Morrissey biopic would have to have some input from the man himself.
The thin story isn't quite enough to stretch over an hour and a half, but The Wall has enough to make the majority of the experience nail-biting.
The Last Word certainly has good intentions, but can't prevent its spiky lead character going too far with her acid tongue, or her unrealistic plans.
Be sure to have a hanky to hand for a tale that tugs at the heartstrings in its own understated way.
More a list of bullet points than a life story, All Eyez on Me has its moments but fails to do its subject justice.
Nothing in the story really takes precedence over the action, but this is about the ride, which for the most part is enjoyable.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This drama seems more like a statement than a story.
The laziest visual gags are accompanied by a cavalcade of insensitive, vulgar jokes that never work no matter how many silly faces are pulled.
While sentimental at times, The Post has something to say about the world, and just happens to do it beautifully.
Tugging at the heartstrings from the first scene, this adorable family adventure mirrors its canine hero - overcoming any flaws by being utterly charming.

While the film loses some urgency in its final third, it's a thrilling, shocking snapshot of a moment in time that will live in history, a reminder of the very real threat that those in power can pose to the citizens they have sworn to protect.
Quite forgettable.

There have been far more detailed and objective examinations, most notably William Klein's Muhammad Ali, the Greatest, but I Am Ali at least gives a fascinating glimpse into the private side of one of history's most public personalities.
The plot stumbles lazily from one thriller trope to the next and, while it does provide some jumps, is predictable to the point where you can call the action before it happens.

Fascinating and thrilling, The Imitation Game keeps you gripped by always offering a reminder of what's at stake, as well as exploring the mind of a brilliant but unfairly treated war hero who should never be forgotten.
While hardly a revelation, it is a welcome return for the actor to the genre that made him famous.
You can't help but be drawn in by these empathetic, funny performances and the overarching message that there is no such thing as"normal".
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Energetic and stylish, the film is part action, part detective story, with acrobatic set pieces punctuating a plot that is intricate without being complicated.
Cynical and lazy, The Best of Me feels as if it's assembled from parts of other, better weepies.
In the end, it's the feel-good animal antics that will appeal and keep the audience on edge once peril rears its ugly head.
Let's Be Cops raises the occasional smile but is so generic it feels like a thousand other comedies that came before it.
The witty script and banter between the three makes for some very funny moments ...
The Inbetweeners 2 is unlikely to win over non-fans, but series devotees will find this a more than suitable last (?) hurrah for the kings of uncool.
Caine's heart-rending flourish aside, this often mawkish drama struggles to make a point.
A Haunted House 2 will satisfy only the basest of humours, while simply repulsing (or offending) the rest of us.
Creating something unique out of a much-explored subject, How We Used To Live is both a captivating piece of time travel and a reminder of the capital's ongoing evolution.
A spectacular film that, for once, lives up to the hype
By the movie's attractive but slightly hollow end, you are thoroughly entertained by this Hollywood A-lister's first feature, but frustratingly never floored by it
A movie on the road to nowhere
a film so preoccupied with style, (the stars) wander around the film without anything of note to do
nothing is delved into deeper than is necessary to get to the next gag
a far-fetched story, told in a rather unappealing way.
a paean to "First World Problems"
Dark and in moments engrossing, the film hints at shades of crime-drama classics but just falls short of joining their ranks
While the amped-up visuals and new cast members are fun (Jeff Daniels is a particular highlight), ultimately this is a confusing addition to a muddled saga.
Different enough to avoid becoming ridiculous, but not original enough to truly excite, Taken 3 may satisfy action fans but it's unlikely anybody will be begging for part four.
While the Wachowskis have not lost their visual flair, the disorganised plot loses your interest very early on.
a bloated but entertaining studio juggernaut.
The odd juvenile chuckle that results from this may sustain you, but in terms of originality and heart this business trip fails to seal the deal.
Whereas the original was filled with humour and gung-ho machismo, this Fast and Furious-style update is a joyless experience.
This over-the-top affair may be of some interest to those looking for late night schlock, but for most it will mark a low point in Lopez's career.
Could have been a mess of crass gags if not for the chemistry of the cast, particularly the two leads who have a rapport that wins you back even when the jokes inevitably stray over the line.
The Night Before stops short of being a holiday classic, but like its three charismatic stars you'll enjoy the ride while it lasts.
Much like the murmuring creature of Shelley's novels, Victor Frankenstein is a lot of ideas sewn together, that emerges without ever really knowing what it is.
While the storytelling is strong, the animation has to be seen to be believed.
Both leads give committed performances, but soon drown in overdramatic subplots and platitudes about love.
Good humour and a sincere message cut through the treacle to make an infectiously festive family movie, which wears its tinsel-covered heart on its sleeve.
A light but effective comedy that offers something new in a genre where almost everything has been explored.
It may lack any real reason to be made, but this sequel has enough about it to raise a few laughs and make the return worthwhile, if not memorable.
A fast, amiable comedy that never outstays its welcome, and will be great fun for fans of films such as 2008's Pineapple Express.
A shallow cavalcade of action scenes that will probably leave you as cold as 47's expressionless gaze.
A drab, juvenile misfire.

All but the most devoted Kevin Hart fans will feel slightly cheated by a lazy film from returning director Tim Story who seems happy to deliver another in a lengthy list of disappointing buddy cop sequels.
A film that, while watchable, makes little use of its stars or premise.
Animated segments should offer some nostalgic interest to Python fans, but it's scant reward for a wish-fulfilment comedy that doesn't fulfil anyone's wishes.
While it may not stray too far from familiar territory, Run All Night is a fast and entertaining example of just why its star's action rebirth has been so successful.
Fans of the source material may still be eager for the next chapter but for casual viewers this is a disappointingly bland sequel.
For all its flaws, by injecting the sinister into something we are all familiar with, Unfriended manages to deliver a uniquely unnerving tone in a surprisingly traditional way.
Neither a straightforward sequel nor a clean-slate reboot, the film simply drops Max into a perilous situation and floors the accelerator.
Amid the tonal uncertainly and occasionally blunt stereotyping, this is a likeable coming-of-age tale with both brains and heart.
There is a brutal simplicity to the action that will appeal to some, but in terms of non-violent content Sword of Vengeance seems stretched even for a relatively short film.
While there is little in the film that's repellent, there's even less about Survivor that's memorable.
It's about as lightweight a movie as you can imagine, but fans of the show will love this last bid for stardom from TV's favourite hangers-on.
There isn't much point to any of the madness, but that doesn't mean it isn't an enjoyable ride.
Ultimately, charm is not enough to gloss over the clichéd story, which may entertain for the short running time, but is about seven years too late to take anyone by surprise.
Lynch revels in showing woundings and torture, to the point where even the most hardened action fans may find themselves wincing.
No surprises, but plenty of laughs and gasps.
Redemption and comeuppance are divided accordingly in a bullet-riddled finale, thankfully polishing off enough of the cast to signal an end to this wreck of a film.
This unadventurous reboot can only highlight how recent epics like Ridley Scott's 'Gladiator' have already plundered the William Wyler film of its richest assets.
The supposedly erotic comedy fails to perform: the sex scenes are cautious and stilted, the humour desperate and obvious, and the romance woefully naive.
The Legend of Tarzan integrates state-of-the-art computer-generated animals and foliage into a shamelessly old-fashioned jungle adventure that regularly evokes King Kong and The Jungle Book.
The overbearing lack of subtlety and nuance is accentuated by Emilia Clarke's tone-deaf performance - a far cry from her commanding presence in Game of Thrones.
The big-screen treatment only magnifies the problems in this cliched and ludicrous crime thriller.
What could have been a biting satire pitting small-town conservatism against big-city liberalism, the film plays its suburban sexploits so safely it threatens to say nothing at all.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Laika has created here a genuinely enchanting fable of extraordinary artistic merit, and clearly respectfully enamoured of its subject matter.
Bier paints an impeccably bleak picture of her homeland, while Coster-Waldau sells the plot's more implausible moments with a nuanced performance of desperate realism.
The message remains, ultimately, one of female empowerment ... but here it's presented through an endless blizzard of latex genitalia, racial epithets and bodily fluids.
A Perfect Day offers few surprises, but manages to rise above its clichés thanks to committed, off-kilter performances, particularly from Del Toro and a back-on-form Robbins.

'The Last Race' seems less interested in Eric Liddell's story than in pouncing on yet another opportunity to dramatise Japanese wartime atrocities against the Chinese. ... Poorly conceived and wretchedly executed.

The plot [is] overly contrived yet preposterously shallow, with performances so underdeveloped you can almost hear the actors counting their pay over the expository monologues and incoherent scheming.
Abel Ferrara's reverent portrait of Pier Paolo Pasolini's last day alive serves as both a fan's impassioned eulogy and a speculative glimpse at what might have transpired.

Sing Street pays loving tribute to a decade of woeful fashion choices and the music of Duran Duran, Spandau Ballet and The Cure, while capturing the emotional vulnerability of adolescent artistic expression.
Despite its Euro-gothic pretensions, the film struggles to sell its far-fetched premise and is further hobbled by a slew of unconvincing performances.
Inside Men is a ... slick South Korean thriller exposing high-level corruption in equally brutal and compelling fashion.
Unfolding like Dog Day Afternoon meets The Big Short, the film attempts to hold the Wall Street elite accountable ... but operates more successfully when simply looking to entertain.
The film's zombies-on-a-train premise delivers plenty of bloody violence and breathless action, punctuated by social commentary, strong characters and a heavy dose of melodrama.
A film brimming with audacious spectacle from start to finish.
Josh Lawson's film does its best not to judge its characters, and his jokes occasionally probe some dark and daring territory.
By casting unknowns, Katis only ratchets up the tension more, leaving his audiences breathless throughout, unable to second guess who might make it out alive.
As the hapless loser transforms into the gun-toting hero of his fantasies, we are treated to one of the most joyfully entertaining horror movies in recent memory.
A baggy, laboured rehash that, at 123 minutes, lumbers on for an eternity.
An intriguing yet also frustrating picture of North Korea... Álvaro Longoria ventures far beyond the typical sites of Pyongyang's impressive architecture and deserted streets.
A heart-wrenching portrait of a physically and emotionally fragile artist, and the band of equally vulnerable, tormented misfits he assembled around him.
[The film is] a victory that transcends its formulaic shackles in powerful, life-affirming fashion.
The action uses plenty of martial arts and swordplay between the shoot-outs and fang fights, but characterisation barely expands beyond wardrobe or relationship status.
Gibson has clearly lost none of his talent for cinematic spectacle, and Hacksaw Ridge invariably looks incredible.
Galifianakis and McKinnon are genuinely entertaining, especially together, but when taken as a whole, Masterminds squanders its potential all too frivolously.
The film turns a potentially grating one-trick pony into a fascinating snapshot of America, the black experience and two future leaders in the throes of some kind of awakening.
Jean-Christophe Castelli's screenplay feels stilted and contrived, desperate to check off as many political points as possible, but without earning them dramatically.
A joyous, intelligent and moving journey, but above all else it's a celebration of music and its unique power to transcend boundaries and unite us all.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bursting at the seams with celebrity appearances and day-to-day drama, the appeal of The First Monday in May should reach far beyond the style-savvy and fashion-conscious.
Tsukiji Wonderland ventures deep into the bowels of the culinary Mecca, to study not only the Japanese love of all things fish, but also their exemplary work ethic and pride in fair trade.
The Age of Shadows [is] a joy to watch, its 140 minutes of action unspooling with barely a pause for breath.
While this should set politically correct alarm bells ringing, Up for Love manages to be consistently charming, genuinely romantic and often very funny.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A delightfully macabre sense of humour... helps alleviate the otherwise ghoulish subject matter.
movie_title: The Tenants Downstairs (Lou xia de fang ke) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely has Hong Kong politics been addressed as overtly as in Ten Years, a speculative science fiction anthology from a quintet of the city's most promising young directors.
Part action thriller, legal procedural, autism drama and mismatched romance, it is strong in parts but less than the total sum.
While too self-aware to eclipse the films of the '90s to which it is so clearly indebted, Mr. Right still manages to scratch the same itch.
Director Koji Shiraishi barely fulfils the obligations of his film's title, delivering an awkward horror-comedy that's a far cry from its eerie predecessors.
Brimming with magic, mystery and monsters, Tim Burton's family fantasy nevertheless manages to feel lethargic and discernibly lacking in any of the director's trademark visual style.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like all the best horror films, the grisly events unfolding onscreen are merely a cypher through which the filmmaker can address prominent social issues.
Yoshihiro Nakamura's first foray into horror in more than a decade proves a cracking return to form, both for the director and the J-horror genre.
movie_title: The Inerasable (Zan'e: Sunde wa ikenai heya) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Martial arts fans anticipating Sammo Hung Kam-bo's first directorial effort in close to 20 years will be left sorely disappointed by The Bodyguard.
When the action finally does resume, the climactic battle resembles [a not-too-expensive] episode of Ultraman, as men in rubber suits duke it out against miniature sets and green-screen FX.
movie_title: Attack On Titan: Part 2 (Shingeki no kyojin endo obu za warudo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Trier juxtaposes this tangled web of troubled individuals with a confident hand that gives his characters room to breathe.
While Veteran may resemble dozens of other recent South Korean thrillers, ... Ryoo imbues his film with a style and swagger all its own.
It's an occasionally touching romance that plays it far too safe.
The film is equally frightening ... in exposing just how much collectors are at the mercy of so-called experts, while raising valid questions about the true nature and value of art.

Despite the lack of innovation in the narrative, Chow has delivered a slick and polished production that holds the attention and satisfies far more convincingly than either of the writer and director's previous collaborations.
movie_title: Rise of the Legend (Huang feihong zhi yingxiong you meng ) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though it is never explained why a half-man half-octopus is in cahoots with a community of mermaids, the notion fits perfectly within Chow's skewed fantasy world.
Always feels like a cash-in, arriving 15 years too late.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cheang keeps the comedy, fantasy, adventure and spirituality on an even keel and guides home an almost perfect holiday blockbuster.
movie_title: The Monkey King 2 (San Da Bai Gu Jing) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Veering away from the series' breast-beating jingoism, Ip Man 3 trades the crowd-pleasing intensity of its predecessors for a more introspective portrait of its central character.
[Point Break features] a number of impressive action set pieces... However, fans of the original will mourn the lack of memorable characters, quotable dialogue and the now-legendary central bromance.
Packed with action and steeped in tradition, Chen Kaige's return to the wuxia genre is an exhilarating drama, as concerned with the philosophy behind martial arts as with their lethal execution.
movie_title: Dao shi xia shan (Monk Comes Down the Mountain) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Dragon Blade delivers on its promise of sprawling battle scenes, intriguing culture clashes and budding bromances, where its giddily high concept and unlikely casting may so easily have seen it fail.

Despite a conspicuous lack of ocean-bound action, The Crossing Part 1 is awash with romance, conflict and drama as Woo positions his major players on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in anticipation of the fateful sailing.
As a showcase for emerging international talent, the film is without equal, but as a stand-alone feature it does run a little long.
Rie Miyazawa gives a heart-wrenching performance ... as a terminally ill matriarch determined to reconcile her splintered family in her last remaining weeks.
movie_title: Her Love Boils Bathwater (Yu Wo Wakasuhodo No Atsui Ai) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For audiences seeking the same polished, vacuous grand scale spectacle that has become synonymous with both the series and its director, Transformers: Age Of Extinction gives the series a new lease of life.
A thoroughly entertaining romp that blends the Brothers Grimm with bloody violence to darkly comic effect.
Oozing Wong's trademark elegance, the film weaves the director's familiar themes ... around some of the most gorgeous martial arts sequences ever filmed.
Jackie Chan resurrects his maverick treasure hunter from the Armor of God series ... only to discover his edge has been replaced by a sickening line of self-aggrandising patriotism
[The Guillotines] offers a little of everything - action, drama, propaganda, romance - but spread frustratingly thin under a thick glossy sheen.
Dark Places has suggestions of a moody true-crime drama ... But languid pacing, poor directorial choices and a series of narrative dead ends make watching it a tiresome chore.
[The movie] twists an awkward encounter with an old high-school acquaintance into a cracking psychological thriller that offers some genuine surprises.
The best LA Christmas movie since Die Hard, Tangerine is destined to become a landmark in American independent cinema. It is absolutely essential viewing.
To see [John Woo] churn out such generic bilge provokes a mournful sinking feeling.
Tom Comerford's muted cinematography finds a rugged beauty in such an unglamorous region of the Irish countryside, while David Geraghty's evocative score is perhaps the film's artistic standout.
Too often, Steers would rather flash a stockinged leg or plunging cleavage to quicken our pulses, where a few quality scares would have been infinity more rewarding.
The final product stops short of being genuinely haunting, but its sensitive performances and mournful melancholia linger long in the mind.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly, Pacino just mumbles drunkenly as Green's camera drifts woozily in and out of focus and post-rockers Explosions in the Sky tinkle on the soundtrack.
While The Choice certainly isn't for everyone, there is something refreshing to be wrung from such an unabashedly earnest and wholesome world view.
Cow director Guan Hu pitches Mr Six somewhere close to Eastwood's Unforgiven, and the results are equally stylish, elegiac and impressive.
Tag has enjoyed a healthy run on the midnight festival circuit, but from the outset its sleazy tone is off-putting even by late-night horror standards.
It is no easy task to make Sandra Bullock unlikeable on screen, but director David Gordon Green manages just that in his toothless South American political satire.
Evoking ... almost every YA sci-fi offering, The 5th Wave will surprise nobody, introducing a procession of stock-character types into well-worn narrative arcs.
Haigh's direction is measured and reserved, allowing the talents of his two veteran performers to carry the weight of the unfolding tragedy.
A hugely entertaining yet emotionally draining experience, 100 Yen Love takes its audience from hilarious highs to tear-inducing lows. ... An adrenaline-fuelled euphoria.
Hasoda has developed a winning blend of escapism, charm and thoughtful narrative insight to back up his claim [to be the new king of Japanese animation].
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Love the Coopers reminds us that there are few things worse than booze-fuelled family gatherings, but one of them is definitely schmaltzy Hollywood movies about such reunions.
This is classic Romeo & Juliet stuff, featuring a light-hearted tone and charismatic leads that make it an easy, breezy watch.
The light-hearted and witty script ... incorporates everything from political corruption to media manipulation, painting a rich and vibrant portrait of the contemporary Indian experience.
Miss Hokusai is a thoughtful and visually resplendent anime with a playful interpretation of art and artists.
Poor writing and shaky performances, punctuated only occasionally by serviceable moments of gross-out horror, make this an entirely missable enterprise destined for iTunes obscurity.
In his best performance of the post-Governator era, Arnold Schwarzenegger stars ... in a film that eschews traditional zombie movie expectations in favour of a more character-driven drama.
The final starring role for actor Robin Williams is an uncharacteristically reserved performance in what proves a disappointing swansong for the late comedian.
Scouts dances a mostly successful line in splatter gore and gross-out humour, [earning] itself a sleeve-full of merit badges.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The 33 feels perpetually caught between championing this triumph of human spirit and technical innovation over the forces of nature.
There are hidden references sure to delight Anohana fans along the way, but otherwise this is a run-of-the-mill anime romance, hobbled by an unnecessarily contrived denouement.
movie_title: The Anthem of the Heart (Kokoro ga sakebitagatterunda) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kolstad's script does an excellent job of building a world rich in pulpy noir archetypes, hinting at entire criminal infrastructures operating just beneath the surface of society.
In its strongest moments, the film plays like ill-conceived fan fiction, but for the most part is wafer-thin, nonsensical and laborious to watch.
Sadly, this film struggles to escape the long shadow of Ghibli's past achievements, not least Kiki's Delivery Service - also about a young witch in training - as well as that of Harry Potter.
An adolescent love story tangled in angst and raw emotion.
movie_title: Tokyo Night Sky Is Always the Densest Shade of Blue (Yozora wa itsudemo saikô mitsudo no aoiro da) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is populated with so many ancillary characters, which are far more engaging than the central lovers, that their antics too often distract from the central plot.
While at times heavy-handed, Serkis' first swing at directing is efficient and effective.
Hazanavicius beautifully recaptures the anarchic energy of Godard's iconic early works.
Koreeda's deliberate pacing proves both challenging and meticulous, but patient and committed audiences will be richly rewarded.
Wonder's rose-tinted version of the world ... ultimately paints a naive world view in danger of doing more harm than good to anyone who suffers the misfortune of watching it.
While Ayame Misaki and Masatoshi Nagase deliver sympathetic performances, they can't compete with Kawase's overbearing sense of self-importance.
The best superhero origin story yet to be put on film.
The Spierigs give us gore aplenty, but nothing that can compare to a pit of hypodermic needles or the unflinching brutality of hacking off one's own foot.
Sheridan succeeds in delivering both an expose on the struggles of contemporary reservation life and a tautly executed procedural set against an epic backdrop of hostile beauty.
While it mixes red-blooded jingoism with romance and playful camaraderie in the hope of recapturing Wolf Warrior 2's recent success, the film struggles to take flight.
Some of the film's emotional effectiveness is lost in a tangle of timelines, but those familiar with the source material may find their way to the film's admittedly super-sized heart.
movie_title: The Miracles of the Namiya General Store (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Save for some impressive underwater photography and a scene-stealing cameo from J.K. Simmons, Renegades proves less enjoyable than a week at boot camp.
Colossal presents a wildly original concept that tethers absurd science fiction to very real social problems, all within the guise of an offbeat romantic comedy.
Often challenging and uncomfortable to watch, the ironically titled Good Time is a feverish head trip that seizes you by the throat and refuses to let go.
Song's brilliantly layered performance embodies the emotions of an entire nation, and is almost certain to garner the actor serious awards attention.
Wright has affectionately lampooned the horror and action genres in the past, but Baby Driver proves he is now a legitimate action director in his own right.
A scathing satire on the modern family, Survival Family also speculates humorously about our technological dependency and inability to fend for ourselves in the outside world.
As singalong hagiographies go, Oasis: Supersonic is rock solid.
Zhou's screenplay perfectly captures the frustrations of the new generation, but fails to make them any more sympathetic than their transparently detestable father.
The quality of Chan's recent films has varied wildly, and with this one he hits a new low in terms of the nonsensical garbage he is willing to put his name to.
Dramatic tension can swiftly be undermined when you're watching invincible characters battle it out. In Motohiro's less accomplished hands, Ajin: Demi-Human just feels repetitive and unfocused.
The barren yet tranquil countryside conceals the bloodshed that once ravaged it, but Boulghourjian is careful to omit politics or religion from his film as much as possible.
Any effort to compare scandals past and present fly by in this wastefully curtailed re-enactment of an impactful historical moment.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a ludicrous accent and implausible central premise, Lawrence's star presence ensures Red Sparrow is never less than entertaining.
Slick and accomplished, 1987 is also single-minded and forthright in its intentions, propelled by an exasperated nation which demanded more of its public officials.
The Square is satire at its finest and a hilarious takedown of snobbery and elitism.
Shipenko has created a claustrophobic and unrelentingly tense experience, further heightened by gorgeous cinematography, strong effects work, and a stirring score.
Fifty Shades Freed offers attractive leads in various states of undress, against picturesque locations, but precious little else to entertain or arouse us.
Narratively uninspired and visually flat - no mean feat considering the beautiful mountain locations.
A gritty police procedural that blends bloody gangland savagery with wicked gallows humour to thrilling effect.
The film is frequently scary (especially for coulrophobics) and always absorbing, with a measured yet affectionate nostalgia for the period.
Whenever the dust is allowed to settle, Jailbreak's cracks and seams quickly become visible, but it does show undeniable promise for Cambodian action cinema.
[This] montage of America's explosive history of racial intolerance makes for compelling, if at times uncomfortable viewing.
The enigmatic poetry of the [Japanese] original has been lost in this clumsy reworking.
Gens repeatedly commits the ultimate horror-film crime, supplanting genuine fear and dread with cheap and loud jump scares.
Na gives a wonderful performance, revelling in the opportunity to play such a despised yet complicated individual.
A story of desperation and revenge as darkly funny as it is tragically bleak, Three Billboards expertly undermines expectations, pushing characters far beyond their traditional archetypes.
Unfortunately, the creative team behind Kidnap appear more interested in staging traffic pile-ups than giving their Oscar-winning lead something substantial to chase after.
The Disaster Artist is a comedy that is frequently laugh-out-loud funny. But it is also sympathetic towards Wiseau's insatiable desire to create, to find fame.
Inevitably, Along with the Gods is engulfed by melodrama towards the end, but along the way there is fun to be had.
movie_title: Along With the Gods: The Two Worlds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The computer-generated demons ... prove no match for the tangible reality of an abusive father with a murderous temper.
The assured, at times bombastic direction, as well as the passionate performances, help distract from the more implausible aspects of the plot.
The action is edited to ribbons, and an over-reliance on CG augmentation starves the more ambitious set pieces of any sense of threat or physicality.
Diehard gear-heads may be appeased by the sight of beautifully restored Bugattis and Alfa Romeos, but those looking for genuine thrills should steer well clear of this under-cranked lemon.
Kim transitions effortlessly between moments of slapstick comedy, bone-crunching action and genuinely upsetting drama with the sure hand of a seasoned veteran.
While The Wasted Times is not quite the ordeal its title may suggest, it nevertheless makes for convoluted, impenetrable viewing.
Japanese filmmaker Sion Sono takes encouraging strides towards a more feminist outlook in Antiporno, his entry in film company Nikkatsu's ongoing roman porno reboot project.
A sweet-natured tale of regret that yearns for simpler times in a country struggling to keep up with its own evolution.
Silence is a sombre, introspective meditation on faith and resilience that often makes for demanding viewing.
Discarding the spandex and playful camaraderie of the X-Men for a grizzled, dustball future where mutants are all but extinct, it is also the series' most nihilistic chapter.
The Girl with All the Gifts resists the temptation to become a young adult reimagining of 28 Days Later, instead emerging as an effectively atmospheric and often grisly horror film.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A relentless 136-minute tirade of shouting, slapping, shooting and stabbing.
The space between us and this excruciating nonsense isn't nearly far enough.
While never allowing events to spiral into full-blown farce, the French comedy News from Planet Mars constantly tests the limits of its somewhat absurd reality, to mostly winning effect.
movie_title: News From Planet Mars (Des Nouvelles De La Planète Mars) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than drawing from established classics to develop new ideas, A Cure for Wellness frustrates by offering little more than slightly quivering lip service.
The culinary strengths of East and West go head-to-head in Raymond Yip's cheerfully frivolous new comedy.
For anyone who has ever felt the touch of another, the series remains dull, cold and almost endearingly frigid.
Loyal fans should find the conclusion of the Resident Evil series satisfactory, but audiences yet to be won over won't find anything new to sway them now.
Director Matthias Hoene's The Warrior's Gate plays like a relic from a bygone era, when broad Asian stereotypes were commonplace and went largely unchecked.
Land of Mine carefully sidesteps the clunky pun of its title to tell a powerful, moving story of young men sacrifiiced to war and its equally violent aftermath.
A high-octane action thriller [set in] the corrupt world of finance and big business. But beyond the glamour, action and exotic locations, it's a shallow, superficial endeavour.
[Jackie] Chan's familiar blend of action comedy is undercut by a persistent line in wince-inducing pro-China rhetoric.
Solid performances, impressive effects work and the bruisingly heart-wrenching story at the film's centre ensure A Monster Calls will have viewers in pieces.
The Great Wall, while big, brash, and achieving cross-cultural understanding on only the most basic level, shows the director's flair for visual grandeur.
This spiritual sequel to Plisson's award-winning documentary On the Way to School proves to be a contrived, manipulative and wholly insincere exercise.
A Silent Voice resonates as an authentic depiction of adolescent vulnerability and the uniquely cataclysmic perils of teenage life.
For all its potential, Fabricated City remains a patchwork of half-realised, undercooked ideas crowbarred into a generic formula.
A riveting web of intrigue and suspense to rival any cold war thriller.
It is a pity that the director's vision often feels at odds with the film's more commercial obligations.
While this chaotic mash-up of sci-fi and period drama aesthetics triggers a relentless sugar rush of visual stimuli, Gintama proves an exhausting and alienating experience for the uninitiated.
Øvredal builds on a pair of strong performances to craft an unnerving chiller with a genuine sense of mystery.
I.T. is a film to turn off - and never turn back on again.
My Uncle is a typically heart-warming affair, anchored by strong performances from Ryuhei Matsuda and young Riku Ohnishi.
It's a pity that Ryoo insists on prioritising violence, melodrama and shameless jingoism to the point of exploitation, wringing this real-life tragedy for every tear - and dollar - he can.
Rather than exude a stylish swagger, the film reeks of a smug self-satisfaction that undermines Theron's considerable efforts and the genuinely impressive moments of orchestrated carnage.
Mon Mon Mon Monsters offers plenty to delight horror fans, with a dazzling visual style, a number of standout set pieces and compelling performances from a mostly young cast.
Despicable Me 3 marks the low point of a series now in desperate need of new ideas.
Kei Ishikawa's enthralling adaptation of Tokuro Nukui's notoriously complex novel is by turns a grisly whodunit and scathing takedown of the respectable middle-classes.
Una broaches the volatile subjects of paedophilia and the reintegration of sex offenders in compelling fashion, thanks to excellent performances from Mara and Mendelsohn.
Gerard Butler is given a rare opportunity to show some dramatic range, but despite his best efforts, A Family Man remains a cliched and painfully by-the-numbers offering.
Let's Go, Jets! tells its wholly predictable tale of teamwork and acceptance with dedication and undeniable charm, earning laughs - and even a few tears - along the way.
movie_title: Let's Go JETS! (Chiadan: Joshi kousei ga chiadansu de zenbei seihashichatta honto no hanashi) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Emulating such classic thrillers as Blow-Up and The Conversation, Who Killed Cock Robin soon becomes entangled in a web of contrived mysteries and implausible coincidences.
The film's stilted dialogue, relentless exposition and 'uncanny valley' animated performances prove far more unsettling than the virus-infected ghouls lurking in the shadows.
Cruise runs and shouts his way through set pieces, while others mumble mythological explanations, and Ahmanet simply stands around showing off her hieroglyph tattoos.
Afterimage exudes an energy and clarity that elevate it above its familiar cold war setting, to serve as a worthy statement from a true master of the cinematic arts.
Beyond the sun burn and baby oil, the film's similarities with its source material can barely squeeze into its little red trunks.
A Man Called Ove is Sweden's answer to Frank Capra's Yuletide classic It's a Wonderful Life.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As Irving, Timothy Spall is wonderfully loathsome. What brings an emotional complexity to the story, however, is Rachel Weisz's bold characterisation of the unsympathetic Lipstadt.
After making waves with 2012's Confession of Murder, Jung Byung-gil's follow-up delivers some of the most kinetic action sequences ever witnessed in a South Korean film.
It is well crafted, ably performed and even strikes the occasional chord of emotional resonance, but my inner science-fiction nerd was unable to let go of its illogical central conceit.
movie_title: If Cats Disappeared from the World (Sekai kara neko ga kietanara) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: When it chooses to be -- which, thankfully, is often -- the film is so funny as to induce tears. Then, on a dime, it's appallingly sad again.
This film tackles thematic material of familiar enormity which has been routinely, politely, civilly neglected for too long.
The picture purveys a relaxed and relaxing sense of innocence, radiance, hope, and chaste sensuality.
movie_title: L' Argent de Poche (Pocket Money) (Small Change) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Ossessione is the fully achieved work of a matured artist, and in the last analysis it heralds nothing but the oracular career of one of the very greatest of the elect in that still small clutch of film masters.
It isn't as tense as the first film, and sometimes you do wish it was as simple as its predecessor. But it's certainly a must-see horror sequel.
While flawed, few will go see Skyline and not have fun.

Star Wars is, indeed, a movie that dares to be different, not only in setting, but in theme at a time when imagination has surrendered to realism in motion pictures. If you don't enjoy Star Wars, you are not as young at heart as you think you are.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Call me impatient, but the fact that so little happens in the film's latter half at such a ponderous pace, compared to the charm of the former, means the credits can't roll too soon.

Matching Jack's conclusion is a hopeful one (some may say thankfully) but it's much too tidy and rushed, a pure cookie-cutter Hollywood happy ending that betrays the realistic, at times poignant portrayal of childhood terminal illness that came before it.
Centurion isn't perfect but Marshall does bring a fresh spin to the sword-and-sandals genre giving it a modern sensibility; from rapid-fire action sequences to no-nonsense parlance.
With plenty of charm and humour, Boy is shaping up as the feel-good film of the year.
An engrossing, chilling portrait of a psychopath unraveling.
A film that satisfies equally as police procedural and social commentary.
movie_title: In the Heat of the Night (1967)

movie_review_blurb: A box-fresh comedy both real and romantic, That Awkward Moment rarely has any of its own. Date night sorted, then...
A jaw-plunging blend of physical dexterity and bravura moviemaking.
