Dropping acid must be far more entertaining than watching this pretentious mess ...
While Cuban Fury is a jolly enough film, you never really feel enough's at stake here.
A masterly Coen screenplay - up there with A Serious Man and The Man Who Wasn't There for its portrayal of male neuroses and failure.
Raising a host of questions about how we interact with technology and each other, Her is an elegantly constructed piece that seamlessly interweaves drama, design and dialogue.
Arriving with the original's charm intact, the laughs may be on the squishy side but a versatile Vaughn is good value here. Fertile family fun.
As dull as a dreary daydream.
With some narrative threads suddenly dropped, it's raw-edged and sometimes jarring. But as a reminder of how fragile life is, it's spot-on.
Delivery Man has charm to spare.
Elba is full of gravitas and Harris laced with fire, and both crucially add a human touch to a story that threatens to become engulfed by politics. They alone make this worth a watch.
It's hysterical and hard to watch, but grimly compelling nonetheless.
He's alive! But you might wish he wasn't after seeing this knuckle-headed fantasy.
Following the deft In The House, Jeune Et Jolie is another compelling study in youthful rebellion from director François Ozon.
A stage-to-screen Brit-com that retains its charm.
Not so much World War Z as World War Zzzz.
A fascinating life story, The Railway Man is doubtless a better book than a film. Firth and Kidman are not at their best, although Irvine proves his true talent.
Led by first-rate work from Winslet and Brolin, Labor Day is a skilful, old-fashioned drama from a maturing director. Cynics, however, need not apply.
For the most part Nymphomaniac is compelling and achieves exactly what von Trier set out to do: a multi-faceted exploration of sexuality, in all its bizarre, twisted glory.
Even low expectations won't help you here, with a story that's neither amusing nor dramatic.

Largely set to go down as an embarrassing footnote in the careers of both its screenwriter Bret Easton Ellis and director Paul Schrader - unless, by some miracle, it gains cult success for its awfulness.
BHCIII features one great stunt but a dearth of laughs.
A few lowbrow laughs... but far too many one-note characters, performances, and plot points to make them worth showing up for.
Right down to the sunburn and chapped lips, Tracks is an authentic desert drama. A little more psychological insight wouldn't have gone amiss, though.
A film that blends the hallucinogenic beauty and horror of the desert. What's more, it's all true.
Extracting naturalistic performances from all his young stars, Moodysson seems to revel in these spirited characters. And you should too. It's a delight from start to finish.
OK, it's not Baz Luhrmann-inventive, but Bloom's playful Romeo and Condola Rashad's sweetly virginal Juliet are beautiful to watch.
There's something compelling about Dolan's supreme self-confidence, even when misplaced. He takes risks - and that's attractive.
Fascinating and frustrating.
Cheesy dialogue and predictable plotting make for a derisory experience that even adolescent males - the film's target audience - may spurn.
Quillévéré's elliptical plot isn't always spot-on, skipping years to a near maddening degree. But treading a fine line between poetry and realism, it's still heartfelt and harrowing.
The cars are hot, the action is decent, but the characters and plot need a serious tune-up.
A coming-of-age fable driven by naturalistic performances and a poignant atmosphere of loss.
A nifty lift-off and a tense first hour lead us, disappointingly, to a very bumpy landing. While Neeson and co. do their best, the script just doesn't deliver where it really matters.
Shepard's film is fun but forgettable in the first hour, then disappointing in the final third. But Law's raucous turn keeps you watching.
For the most part Nymphomaniac is compelling and achieves exactly what von Trier set out to do: a multi-faceted exploration of sexuality, in all its bizarre, twisted glory.
It's hardly Working Title-slick, but Sagnier is appealing in her first real romantic role and there's Gallic charm galore.
Mostly, this is empty, ugly and pretentious.
It's probably Payne's most poetic work yet, a quiet, subtle study of the highs and lows of family life.
Old pals Spielberg, Scorsese, Schrader, Lucas and Coppola pay tribute, before the final reel adds genuine poignancy to the life of this unique storyteller.

While there's a lot of love in the air, the filmmakers don't shirk from addressing his more objectionable side - hard line right-wing politics and a love of guns that, he believes, stalled his studio career.
A sweet-natured film that kids in the 8-12 age bracket will fall for.
movie_title: Justin and the Knights of Valour (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If this is hardly groundbreaking (just swap James' character from Jesse Eisenberg's in the similar theme-park set Adventureland), what works is how Faxon and Rash show the angst isn't all adolescent.
Kick-Ass 2 doesn't quite have the heart of the original. Just a lot of blood, guts and (very) rude words.
A pleasingly intelligent picture.
Fans of Steve Coogan's enduring middle-aged middle Englander will be gladdened to find that Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa is a resounding success, not tarnishing or diluting the character in any way.
What it lacks is a moral core and characters who are more than just cipher.
Fuelled by their energetic tunes, including the annoyingly catchy title track, the story chugs along amiably enough.
It's hard to see who the film is aimed at, teenagers or nostalgic forty-somethings? There doesn't seem enough for either.
It'd take a cold soul not to warm to a film that, for all its conventional approach and picture-postcard visuals, proves poignant in the final act.
Emerges as a confusing mix of action and arthouse. Sadly, it fails at both.
Amongst the sequins and sass, Soderbergh finds a tenderness that has sometimes been missing in his films.
Imagine if Reservoir Dogs' Mr Blonde hooked up with Hannibal Lecter and they went for dinner with the nutter from Wolf Creek.
Kneel before Shannon. His primal, powerhouse turn drives this criminal biopic.
A survival story, pure and simple, the characterisation is non-existent and the blood flows in rivers. It'll appeal to the gorehounds with a sense of humour ...
There's no mystery, suspense or intrigue. Worst of all, there are no real scares - though that may be due to the Young Adult market it's trying to tap into.
What emerges is a film of missed opportunities, as if Meadows had a backstage pass but squandered it drinking in the beer tent.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As ultra-efficient as its sociopathic subject, The Iceman knows exactly when to pull the trigger.
Like all of Bay's work, it's over-the-top, brash and exhausting to watch. But like the lifestyle its characters aspire to, there's an allure too.
The results are revealing rather than revelatory, but chats with Ryan Gosling and Coppola, Scorsese and Polanski flesh out the fun.
Crafted with much TLC and sympathy, it's perfectly tailored to the tongue-tied teen in us all.
Full of ear-pleasing lines and obscure R&B tunes, it's colourful, casual and full of flavour. An unexpected treat.
As a stepping stone for both Larson and Cretton, it leaves you tantalised as to what they'll do next.
Like the title suggests, this is an astronaut adventure whose pull is hard to resist. By the time 90 stomach-shrinking minutes have elapsed, you'll feel like you've been bumped around the heavens.
Now where did we put our gold watch?
Van Groeningen blends the happiness and tragedy of life like a master alchemist, using music as an emotional life-raft, which is just as well: the bleak final third will test the hardiest of souls.
Most of the gags fall flatter than a Knoxville belly-flop.
As blockbusters go, it's a considered, rather than thoughtless, ride.
As personal as the film gets, it never becomes overly sentimental or nostalgic; rather, it's a celebratory work alive with simple pleasures.
Assured, adult filmmaking from a writer/director who knows her way around the ups and downs of relationships. It's also a fitting tribute to the talent of the gentle, grizzly Gandolfini.
It's competently assembled, and certainly engaging, but it's hard to see what the point of Parkland is.
Frears directs events in his usual unfussy, unpretentious manner - letting the actors explore the scenes to the max.
No stranger to solo outings like Cast Away, even amid the grandstanding, Hanks is well-equipped to carry the film, and his showdowns with Abdi are particularly riveting.
An accomplished, bittersweet drama that's more bitter than sweet.
Evans has a feel for mood, but it'd be wrong to mistake atmosphere for psychological depth; Kelly + Victor could've been so much more than what it ultimately achieves.
Dark, depraved and deeply funny, it sees director Jon S. Baird capturing Welsh's spirit, from its relentless pace to its soaring soundtrack.
With Michell anchoring proceedings in his usual unfussy manner, what stands out most is Kureishi's perfectly polished diamond of a script.
Aided by two punchy lead turns, an Oscar-worthy script and stunning in-car footage, Howard's race film delivers top-gear drama. A piston- and heart-pumping triumph.
Contrasting the picture-perfect backdrop, Saul Bass' title sequence and Juliette Gréco's rendition of the title song add to the melancholy.
Capturing the essence of the source novel, this is a superior adult drama. Harrowing, heartbreaking but utterly compelling.
A political drama, a portrait of a marriage, a Hollywood tale... Grace of Monaco doesn't quite know what it wants to be.
It refreshes to see Burton tackle more personal fare, but Big Eyes doesn't quite cut it. This is never as amusing, dramatic or emotional as it should be.
It's absorbing to a point, but adds little to what's gone before.

Much of the problem with Queen of the Desert lies in its casting. Nicole Kidman, as Bell, may fare better than she did as Grace Kelly in the risible Grace of Monaco, but she hardly looks desert-hardened.
There's almost nothing cinematic about Down Dog, which might've felt more at home in a television slot.
A daunting challenge for any actor, Oyelowo rises to the task, in a film that eschews the traditional biopic approach.

With each episode produced by its own individual creative team, the lack of continuity can disorientate. But it's this daring mix of styles that gives The Turning its creative energy and distinct off-kilter flavour.
A richly intoxicating brew of humour, violence and melancholy.
Injecting fun and fairground thrills back into the spy movie, Kingsman is a blast. Firth is sensational, Jackson rules and newcomer Egerton surprises.
Seven years on, and with three episodes of The Expendables leaving the geri-action flick well and truly spent, Taken 3 feels as dozy as a pensioner in the midday sun.
For all the intense, arm-gripping fun, an all-too-familiar denouement means that, much like their car, it runs out of gas late on.
A gem.
Gripes aside, F&F6 delivers where it matters: exhilarating, non-stop, jump-out-your-seat action.
A rollicking adventure about the indefatigability of the human spirit that falls some way short of its cinematic inspiration David Lean.
The gags are pelted ferociously by the Farrellys, a relentless onslaught of crude puns and sick-trigger sight gags. Some hit. Most miss.
Horrible Bosses 2 passes the time, but that's about it.
An intimate epic, Winter Sleep is right up there with the Turkish director's best.
A film that puts a fresh, female spin on the western.
Boseman - who played baseball legend Jackie Robinson in '42 - does everything right.
This peek into the elaborate world of a unique cultural icon hits enough high notes.
Heller captures the era well, and her cast are never less than convincing. Insightful and important, this diary is well worth a peek.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mockingjay merits the split - it perhaps even gives some balance and rhythm to a story that might've felt rushed were the events crammed into a single movie.

Granted, the unhurried pace will frustrate some, while those looking for a really brain-teasing mystery will also be disappointed. But if you like the idea of a meditative, melancholic Holmes, this is for you.
One of those empty, know-it-all tales about grifters working scams, and each other, wrapped around an equally vapid love story.
A charming blend of whimsy and romance, Julian Jarrold's new film is a beauty.
Top Five is packed full of zingers even if, at first glance, the familiar tale of a comic-turned- actor desperately seeking credibility promises to be an indulgent 102 minutes.
The problem with I Am Big Bird is simply that Spinney's story may be heartwarming but it entirely lacks drama.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For all the bucolic beauty and ravishing romance, we're reminded that violence is never far from the surface - and Vinterberg captures the brewing tragedy magnificently.
Logic and cohesion don't really apply here - Andersson's bizarre world just wouldn't allow it.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most exciting cowboy movies to clip-clop onto screens in a while.
Hardy is immaculate as Leo, from accent to demeanour. Now on his fourth film with Hardy, Oldman is a pleasure to watch, and even the smallest of roles have been carefully cast ...
Curtis' film stumbles in its digressions, lacking clear direction, along with the emotional impact it so desperately needs.
Hawke is on fine form - angry, volatile and confused. But for all Niccol's grappling with moral complexities he misses the target, veering into an overwhelmingly melodramatic subplot ...
There are times, particularly when the bland Madden is on screen, that the wholesomeness gets a bit much. But kids will likely have a ball.

You can sense the director's struggle here, wrestling with how to take on such a story. Like Thomas, you suspect he started out with a very different film in mind; the problem is, what he's ended up with is a mixed bag.
The result is a pleasant surprise, and just goes to show: if it ain't broke, don't fix it.
A genuine disappointment, given the talent involved, and a rare misstep for Penn, who can't save this moribund vanity project.
It's crass, clumsy and sometimes shockingly bad.
Cinderella is a balmy but beautiful take on both the 1950 cartoon and the original Charles Perrault fairy tale.
With A+ acting, a solid script and sensitive handling, there's enough here to move even the hardest of souls.
Be sure to pack a hanky.
This British tale of the difficulties of adolescence and adulthood is a sweet rather than saccharine tale, quietly told and lent emotional heft by a cast led by Asa Butterfield.
A finely etched character study, with Cumberbatch on towering form. Set coordinates for the Oscars.
It's hardly explosive or revelatory, and hinges on more contrivances than it should, but there's a rambling, ambling charm to the film, as if Shelton is channelling early John Hughes.
Profits from the cast's amiable chemistry amid the A-B storytelling. Just don't expect it to define a generation.
Puerile, pleasurable and perfectly executed.
Inoffensive as living room wallpaper, though that's hardly a recommendation.
Gondry-ites will be seduced, but this is as undisciplined as it is inventive.
Noer draws energetic turns from these non-pros, while demonstrating a real grasp of the grimy milieu. Just a pity the plot is so by-the-numbers.
Brilliant performances, wondrous comic timing and the greatest pay-off line ever written: this one's still red hot.
Hot off Blue Is The Warmest Colour, Seydoux again offers a frank turn, while Rahim and Ménochet add real class.
However under par it gets, it's impossible not to shed a tear as the final chapter in Ballesteros' oft-magical life unfolds.
Modest but moving.
Despite the unimaginative title, How To Train Your Dragon 2 arrives full of its predecessor's invention, wit and flair.
Age Of Extinction transforms into a typically bombastic Bay offering. If it's major-league spectacle you want, though, look no further.
There's nothing perfect or planned about Diane Kruger's madcap scheme in this belatedly released 2012 Gallic romcom.
Jeunet fans will surely lap it up, particularly those who loved his 2001 standout movie Amélie, but others may find it all a bit much.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A good little midnight movie.
Favreau is sometimes too heavy on the schmaltz. But, largely, Chef will leave you hungry for more.
It's ragged around the edges, but this remains a stirring tribute to Grant. And coaxed by the assured Coogler, Jordan delivers a performance that will long be remembered.
All told, it's perhaps best seen as a celebration of a man who stands up for his beliefs - almost like a testament to Loach himself.
If it proves to be Loach's swan song, it's a graceful note to bow out on.
Wade through all the flares and flare-ups and you'll be rewarded: the ending is absolutely killer.
Mildly entertaining at best, don't expect it to contribute to your own quest for contentment.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not as groundbreaking as the original, nor as expansive as all the best sequels are. But with some excellent cast additions, and Miller on murky form, this still sizzles to the touch.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Frustrating. Measured and masterful to begin with, Night Moves is let down by a second half that never capitalises on the promise of the first.
The back-and-forth narrative saps the story of tension, while Irons bumbles around like a dippy Dumbledore.
'That's better than good,' says Pitt, slugging on some whisky he's saved. Same goes for Fury.
Madness and death hang over Herzog's Wagner-scored vision like a black cloud, while Kinski adds much poignancy to Dracula, the lonely immortal.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: The influence of Georges Franju's horror classic Eyes Without A Face looms large, more than half a century since its release.
With a distinct visual sensibility, Gia proves she's one more Coppola to watch.
Toothless.
You're hooked to the very final frame.
The cast sink their teeth in but the resulting film is surprisingly bloodless.
It's tailor-made for Allen; not only is he as funny as he's been in years, he and Turturro make a wonderful double act, lacing a seedy-sounding script with warmth and humour.
This trawl through the band's history has enough guile and guts to keep you watching.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Pawlikowski paints his world with disarmingly delicate brushstrokes.
A script written in venom, Cronenberg on bullish form and a cast on full power; this is one of the best Hollywood take-downs ever mounted.
Fuqua expertly cranks up the tension, while conveniently overlooking any pesky moral issues that McCall's behaviour raises. It's about as subtle as a bulldozer.
Lacking - perhaps deliberately - its predecessor's hipster edge, WIWH functions as a grown-up weepie, following Aidan on a journey of enlightenment.
More concept that complete movie, despite serious style from the director and the cast's considerable conviction. Sadly, there's no masking the plot's piano-sized holes.
This rather picaresque tale of an Indian family opening a restaurant in rural France never really indulges our senses.
Only the hardiest of souls will make it through the film without wincing, retching or squirming.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is so grimly compelling that even if you want to look away, you won't be able to.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The story gets tiresome, but there is an anarchic sensibility on display, bolstered by M83's score, that suggests Gonzalez is going places.
movie_title: You and the Night (Les rencontres d'après minuit) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Between Roth and O'Connell, there is an amusing chemistry - though the script lacks the sheer aggression of Sexy Beast or foul-mouthed word play of In Bruges, two other fine examples in this arena, to be ranked alongside either.
Lustig strains for poetic meaning but comes up empty-handed. Unless, that is, you happen to like cod-Freudian naval-gazing.
Funny, twisty and thrilling, this is shellhead's most entertaining solo flight to date.

A highly impressive historical epic, Red Cliff shows just how John Woo got his mojo back after a bumpy ride in Hollywood. Full of stunning action sequences, the only shame is how the international version leaves westerners wanting more.

Consistently funny, The Hangover proves you don't need a big-name Hollywood cast to get big laughs. Destined to appeal to the lads everywhere, that the film doesn't only resort to gross-out gags means female audiences should give it a go.
With less of the grit but still plenty of the earthy humour Loach is renowned for, this walks the indie/ commercial line with assurance.

Given the source novel, Podeswa's attempt to adapt Fugitive Pieces is admirable in itself. Yet despite an enthusiastic cast, this fails to transport you in the same way. Tying itself in narrative knots, the end result is stilted.
A lot of effort is put into an intriguing first half by writer-director Nebbou. Unfortunately, this never quite pays off in the finale which fails to leave its mark on you.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like a poor man's Fight Club, Fighting is hardly a heavyweight. But with an enjoyable performance from Terrence Howard, the film is no disaster.
A film that treats its audience as adults, this is an extremely rewarding work that handsomely pays off the concentration required to watch it.

After a promising start, The International is an increasingly disappointing experience. Hampered by a weak script which peaks far too early, all that's left in the finale is a steely performance from Clive Owen. Mildly entertaining at best.

Intelligent and incisive, Doubt is a credible attempt by Shanley and his cast to adapt his play for the screen. Powered by finely tuned dialogue and performances, the result, while never explosive, is a gripping and engaging.

As a portrait of Harvey Milk, Van Sant's film is a sincere work, bolstered by an unquestionably outstanding turn by Sean Penn. While some of the other actors don't match up, this is a minor quibble in an otherwise impressive piece.

Intricate, artfully constructed and utterly assured, Love And Honour is essential viewing for anyone who has seen Yamada's earlier samurai films. If you haven't, don't miss the chance to see what is a finely tuned example of the genre.

Compared to the likes of Adaptation and The Player, What Just Happened? is flyweight. De Niro is amiable enough in the lead role, but he's left to trot around a story that not so much bites the hand that feeds it as licks the palm.

Solid yet unremarkable, Pride And Glory will never win points for originality. With committed turns from Norton and Farrell, it does enough - just - to keep you interested. But this is one film that neither covers itself in pride or glory.

Stephan Elliott's best film since Priscilla, Queen Of The Desert, Easy Virtue should satisfy fans of Coward, despite its differences to the original. A pity then that, despite Biel's sprightly turn, it feels better suited to the small screen.

With a preposterous plot that does not bear close analysis, Eagle Eye should fall short. But such is the breakneck pace of proceedings the holes in the story zoom by too fast for you to notice. And for all its flaws, it's an enjoyable slice of hokum.

If you want to see a gangster film that isn't all about stylized violence, then Gomorrah is for you. More thoughtful than most gangland films, its attempt to show how organized crime has infiltrated every level of society is impressive.
Transcends its initial culture clash comic riffs to evolve into something altogether more moving by the end. As a result, it's a work of considerable power and pathos.

The sort of film even an A-level student of Charles Dickens would find redundant, Julian Richards' slapdash effort is staggeringly inept at times. Best suited to television, it feels so archaic it certainly merits the moniker 'Dickensian'.

A well-meaning comedy that undoes all its good work in the final act, Good Dick would've been better served with further development in the Sundance Lab. That said, Jason Ritter delivers a breakthrough performance that saves the film.

Featuring good work from the dependable Denzel, The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3 is hampered by hyper-kinetic visuals from Scott, an over-zealous turn from Travolta and a thoughtless script from Brian Helgeland.

Crystallized by the functional - rather than fantastic - turns by its two leads, The Time Traveler's Wife never really takes flight. While the film makes a decent enough date movie, you'll find it will disappear from your mind before too long.
From script to editing, this Witch doesn't float.

The early promise of Henry's Crime wanes as its efforts to splice crime caper with backstage drama becomes increasingly laboured. But with the cast on their game, the film just about gets away with it.
Inventive, assured and absurdly entertaining, Rodriguez's latest retro-exploitation movie is a gloriously gratuitous ride.
Your appetite will be whetted for what promises to be an almighty showdown before the curtain comes down on Harry Potter for good.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever the truth, Affleck's film makes for a sharp critique of celebrity culture, as vicious vloggers lead a tirade of abuse against Phoenix, only serving to increase his angst.
From the corny 'see what we did there?' title to a plot that's as predictable as a transatlantic flight-path, this is a truly join-the-dots romcom.
High-minded and ambitious, Agora is also resplendent and rich, full of striking images.
A fascinating science lesson for anyone interested in either deep-sea -- or outer space -- exploration.

Powered by a convincing Matt Damon, The Informant! is a quick-on-its feet comedy that never outstays its welcome. If it has a problem, it's that it's neither funny enough nor emotionally resonant to make a truly lasting impact.
A competent, polished outing for Heslov and his cast. But despite its undoubted qualities, its slightly smug attitude means it never quite matches the bite of earlier military satires.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Rather like an unsuitable partner, Couples Retreat starts out fun before gradually getting annoying and then becoming downright aggravating. While it's not the worst film ever, there are times when it feels as irritating as sunburn.

As a romance story, Love Happens is nothing special, with the spark between Eckhart and Aniston almost non-existent. But as a drama about grief, it's much more interesting, though the blend of both does not always sit easily.
The plot is threadbare and the style is knockabout, but the improvisation, especially that of Considine, lends it an energy and spirit that's hard to resist.
Complex and striking, Guédiguian's film is an impressive new spin on a topic that has been oft explored.
It's a bit like ouzo: seems like fun at the time but you'll no doubt regret it in the morning.

As a tribute to these fearless freedom fighters, it's a worthy effort - and as a welcome, and sobering, antidote to the knockabout silliness of Inglourious Basterds, you couldn't really get any better.
The Soloist brings to life its story with genuine compassion, neatly avoiding many of the traps that afflict Hollywood films about mental illness. And Jamie Foxx's transformation will simply astound.

A charming, quietly satisfying work, Adam is a commendable film. Sensitively written and directed by Mayer, it's given shape and dimensionality by Dancy, who delivers a tremendous performance that lends the film genuine humanity.
A classy cast juice up this workmanlike but compelling courtroom saga, with Matthew McConaughey - so long starved of a decent lead - on fire.
By no means a classic from David Mamet, Redbelt is authentic enough but fails to dazzle. The casting of Tim Allen is imaginative but too much of the film is underwhelming.
With its fast action, cute critters and schoolyard antics, children and fans of Kung Fu Hustle should enjoy Stephen Chow's CJ7, which further cements his reputation as a commercially gifted director.

As you would expect from a writer like Mike White, Year Of The Dog is a smartly scripted, darkly funny work. But from Molly Shannon's performance to White's own ability as a director of actors, there are plenty of pleasant surprises here.

Unhurried in its pacing, Ferran's film is gentle in its nature, allowing the narrative to unfold as gradually as the feelings between Constance Chatterley and her lover. An intimate expression of love and sexuality, it's a triumphant piece of work.
Encouraging the audience to draw their own conclusions, this moody masterpiece is up there with David Fincher's best.

A film of two halves, while the first is original, bleak and psychologically disturbing, the second couldn't be more conventional if it tried. By the end, we're the ones feeling like we've been drugged and duped - into watching this nonsense.
While fans of Eric Bana may get a kick out of his meaty, manly performance, Drew Barrymore is a huge mistake.

The type of film that will be looked back on as a notable starting point for its young star, Like Minds is a perfect showcase for his talent, but less so for writer-director Read, who allows the script to career out of control in the second half.

While Steven Shainberg and his collaborators should be congratulated for eschewing the traditional biopic route, Fur is a noble experiment that goes awry. Sad to say but this is not a film for anyone wishing to learn about Diane Arbus.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Incoherent, pretentious and boring, Aronofsky's film appears as terminally stricken as its female lead. While a re-edit is unlikely to help, it may be better served on DVD, where its jigsaw-like structure can be more fully appreciated.
Not robust enough to deliver on its early promise.
Bonding convincingly (as you might expect) with his own son on screen, Smith delivers his most compelling performance since Ali.
A stunning drama.
Bertolucci's best film for a long time.
Slick romantic comedy from Joel and Ethan Coen.

Innovative, frustrating, powerful, banal, indulgent, this is an experiment that succeeds more than it fails, partly due to the pay-off, which - while a long-time coming - goes for the jugular in a decidedly unsentimental manner.

An important film for Wenders and New German Cinema, Alice In The Cities is compulsive viewing for any fan of the director. A freewheeling look at friendship, loneliness and life, the only thing black and white about it is the film stock.
movie_title: Alice in den Städten (Alice in the Cities) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Stone should be justifiably proud, for he has crafted a compulsive piece of cinema.

A courageous and utterly unique world-view that will haunt you for days after you have seen it, Tarr's film -- despite the obscurity of its meaning -- remains a stimulating and daring piece of cinema to the end.
An early contender for the 2008 Oscars.

The sort of film that real too-cool-for-school teens wouldn't be seen dead watching, Wild Child is aimed at those younger than its protagonists. Loud and obnoxious, like its lead character, it deserves to be expelled.

Revolving around two very different but equally impressive performances from its leads, James Mangold's remake is everything you want from a western: stunning vistas, gripping shoot-outs and a morally complex core that is compelling to the end.

Compared to the likes of Election and Rushmore, Blitz's film is hardly top-of-the-class, but nonetheless in Hal Hefner - partly thanks to Thompson's fine work - he has crafted an enduring cult figure who deserves a sequel all of his own.
Stiller gives one of his broadest and best performances to date, and the jokes ping around the screen as fast as the balls on the court.
A bit of a lightweight.
Turteltaub manages to stitch it all together well enough so that the ludicrous nature of the characters' quest doesn't hit you until the final credits roll.
As low-budget as the film looks, Stillman overcomes financial limitations by providing a learned script and eliciting polished performances.
An epic retelling of the Pocahontas story that, despite its flaws, leaves you slack-jawed with wonder at times.

Distancing Stop-Loss from other Iraq films by highlighting an American military tactic that has been little talked about, Peirce has crafted a credible but hardly outstanding effort that may disappoint those expecting another Boys Don't Cry.
Awash with sentimentality, this meandering tale falls way short of Crowe's usual standards.

An uneven drama that uneasily mixes Hollywood satire and coming-of-age tale, Flashbacks Of A Fool is hampered by its adventurous attempt to link the two. Much like its central character, Walsh's film is stylish but empty.
Minimalist, moody and morose, Lonesome Jim is a minor gem.
A damning indictment of the Catholic Church that lingers in the mind long after if ends. Angry, compassionate but never hysterical, this a true cinematic achievement.

After the somewhat hysterical Mystic River - a flawed work dominated by a powerhouse performance from Sean Penn - this is a far more balanced piece, anchored by three terrific turns and some lean direction from Eastwood.

Gruesomely satisfying, fans of both Burton and Sondheim are equally liable to be pleased with this marvelous meeting of minds. If the film sags a little at times, its technical prowess and superlative cast ensure we don't dwell on this for too long.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Not quite the British Magnolia it wants to be, Chromophobia's melting pot plot is too often little more than overheated melodrama. But aided by Damian Lewis's strong turn, it still manages some unexpectedly poignant moments.
A film that deserves attention, if not your full respect.

A problematic period movie, Silk is anything but finely spun. Unaided by lacklusture performances from the leads, director Francois Girard seems more interested in crafting a beautiful travelogue than he does a moving melodrama.

Snappy exchanges, smart acting and slick directing go to make up a wickedly entertaining work that's hugely enjoyable. A deft story about modern-day celebrity culture, it also proves what a talent Buscemi is as a director.
Led by Jodie Foster, The Brave One is an adult Hollywood thriller a notch above most vigilante movies. Powerful and provocative, it will keep you thinking long after you've left the cinema.

If Winterbottom struggles to shoehorn his documentary style into the form of a thriller, Jolie has no problems in bringing Mariane to life with a vibrant and vital turn. This honourable film is worth seeing for her alone.
Infinitely superior to a Meet The Spartans-style spoof, chiefly thanks to a first-rate cast, Highness ticks all the bawdy boxes. But if you seek sophistication, raise the drawbridge.
Better than the woeful Scream 3, partly thanks to the influx of new faces and the return of Williamson. But really it's more of the same, as the franchise slips further towards total self-parody.
All hail the mighty Ed Helms for yet another masterclass in comedy and pathos.
With Laurie and Meester on credible form, The Oranges remains a juicy comic odyssey, pithy to its core.
The result is dusty, drab and dreary.
movie_title: Confession of a Child of the Century (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cartoons from the DreamWorks stable always feel rather calculated and overcooked - and Rise Of The Guardians is no different.
Dolan never flinches across this bold, brassy piece; it's confidently directed, stylishly shot, passionately acted and evocatively scored.
Two fine performances - particularly from an unhinged Winstead - almost elevate Smashed to greatness.
Director Bill Condon makes up for his rather lacklustre adaptation of the first half of Stephenie Meyer's concluding novel Breaking Dawn with a full-throated Part 2.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While it boasts the precision plotting of, say, Intolerable Cruelty and the odd Coen-like caricature, it lacks the plain weirdness that typifies their output.
With Avatar's Moore on inspiring form, and Biggs the best he's been since early Pie, this is still worth your vote.
From references to past 007 movies to unexpected twists and top-grade action, Mendes' movie feels like a well-wrapped birthday gift for Bond fans.
Despite an undeniable shambolic charm, the result, while not exactly off-key, could've cleaned up its act before it went on the road.
What goes in favour of the film is the authenticity with which Affleck captures events - notably the raid on the US Embassy that opens the film.
Perhaps it explains too much in what is a grisly finale, but this is both skilful and scary; as such, it's one of the best horrors you will see this year.
Like Calvin, you'll find it hard to resist Ms Sparks.
It may lose its way on occasions, but thanks to a committed cast and a script that captures the Kerouac vibe, Salles' adaptation never ends up on the road to nowhere.
It's not groundbreaking, but the impressionistic approach at least strives for more than your standard-issue bio.
One of the best films of 2012. You'll immediately want to see it again.
A surreal head-scratcher that'd make Luis Buñuel smile, it may not be perfectly formed, but there's no denying its fierce originality.
There's humour and heart here, but it's an overlong tale as meandering as the Ganges.
You couldn't care less about who lives and who dies.
The past has never seemed so inviting as it does in Colin Trevorrow's DIY time-travel romance.
Peter Jackson returns to the Middle Earth he rendered so faithfully in Lord of the Rings, and it's never looked so glorious.
By Nichols' already high standards, this feels a minor work - but it's been made with love.
Oblivion may impress with its scale. But rather like Kosinski's depiction of Earth, it feels devoid of humanity - and that's a major design flaw.
Utterly assured, breathtakingly executed and riotously funny, this is a delight.
If nothing else, you get to see McGregor as a human-sized sausage roll - and it's not often you can say that.
For the most part it's Neanderthal compared to the Pixar stable.
Side Effects boasts a fine cast, an authentic milieu and a script that flirts with the experimental. But it also underwhelms in the crucial final third.
While the use of animation recalls the tone of Terry Gilliam's work on the old BBC shows, the big problem is just how whimsical it all feels.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A brave, soul-stirring and sensitive work.
There may be the odd bum note but Williams' film is largely on song and full of genuine, heartfelt emotion. Stamp's masterclass in melancholy is something to behold.
A grand folly that makes the Wachowskis' The Matrix trilogy look prosaic, Cloud Atlas is a fascinating if flawed work that will leave you gasping one minute and gagging the next.
A grimmer-than-grim tale of murder, incarceration and mayhem.
Eschewing the cheap shocks so many horrors use, Axelgaard sustains the tension and dread until the end.
One of the more sophisticated studio offerings of late.
Zero Dark Thirty is a gripping, authentic-feeling account of the dark side of the war on terror.
If you only see one 'slavery' film this year, make it this one.
The problem with American Mary - aside from some pretty atrocious B-movie acting from the support cast - is that it lacks a compelling third act.
Sleek, stylish but superficial. Easy on the eye, even easier on the brain, it doesn't last long in the memory.
A superior thriller, with Cruise and McQuarrie slotting together like a bullet in a clip.
There's much here to enjoy, even if the incessant upbeat soundtrack and picture-postcard locales add a slightly too-jaunty sheen to three fine central performances.
Even with low expectations, you'll find this a wretched experience.
Writer and director Tony Gilroy, who penned all three previous episodes, has come up with an elegant solution that manages to widen out the story without feeling like a Hollywood cash-in.
From top-grade 3D to a multitude of monsters and a welcome influx of acting talent, this is pure popcorn pleasure.
This is Cardellini's film, and she dominates with a terrific, tough-minded turn.
Holding its middle finger up to '80s retro-hounds, this remake gets it largely right. Fast, filthy, fresh and funny, Jump is worth a punt.

Predictable, plodding and paltry, Folkson's film looks cheap and like the mock wedding, nothing in it - especially the emotions - feels real, with the quality cast looking understandably disinterested.
Supremely led by Liam Neeson, The Grey may be a wilderness tale, pure and simple, but it's as compelling as they come.
With stellar turns, particularly from Jones, this is your Valentine's Day date sorted.
Wholesome with a capital W, it's the sort of film you can take your mother, aunt, grandmother - hell, even your great-grandmother - to, without fear of offending delicate ears.
It's up there with the very best of Hollywood hoofers.
Mann Jr shows plenty of promise in a film that doesn't tarnish the family name. But hindered by niggling flaws, it hardly revolutionises an over-saturated genre.
Not keen on kook? Get ready to fidget. But those up for a sweet-natured romance full of idiosyncrasies will undoubtedly forgive the rather flyweight feel.
An amazing true story for sure, but this earnest dramatisation is so wholesome, it feels like being stuck in a never-ending Activia advert.
A passable shake-up, even if its 'Aroma-scope' experiment stinks. Like Ricky Gervais, the Spy Kids franchise could drone on - sorry, go on - forever.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As lightweight as a salad and about as filling, this is amiable but predictable.
Guaranteed to divide audiences, this is an intoxicating, disturbing and unforgettable piece of cinema, and announces Julia Leigh as a filmmaker to watch.
However much goodwill you chuck at it, this isn't quite the instant cult classic you want it to be. But now and then it's as blinding as those alien gnashers.
If the trajectory of Atonement director Joe Wright's career went a little off course with his last film, touchy-feely US debut The Soloist, it's now firmly back on track with Hanna.
You'd think the Fast And The Furious franchise would've run out of gas by now. Think again.
Gratuitous gore, contrived plotting... and Ray Winstone's butcher cameo deserves to be filleted.
While it's just the sort of film Hollywood likes to embrace, one can only imagine the horrific hash a studio would've made of telling this sensitively told tale.
Hawkes has bags of technical talent. If only he'd applied it to a script where we cared about the characters.
With Yakin's all-action plot operating like clockwork, an on-song Statham proves anything but expendable in a genre he dominates. Predictable, sure, but equally pleasurable.
There are only so many three-way nose-tweaks you can take, and the Farrellys' idea of splitting the film into three nominal episodes doesn't really solve the problem.
The finale, as Ai's Twitter tirades lead to a serious human-rights breach, will make your blood boil.
Even if it lacks a stand-out turn it's still a grippingly authentic slice of life.
Gerwig charms, but the laughs fall flat under the incessant naval-gazing.
A story as heart-warming as it is genuine, as the humble Rodriguez gets his long overdue recognition on a triumphant return to South Africa.
Emotional, epic and entertaining, this is the end you've been waiting for.

Never patronising nor begging for sympathy, it attempts to show how this couple experience the world, from the sensual delights of walking along a seashore to the very real ordeal of changing a light bulb.
Not the promised insider's peek but Assayas and Binoche are still a potent combo ...
Full of fizz, filth and fun, I'm So Excited! is like an '80s retro-blast. Its scattershot comedy may not impress latecomers to Almodóvar's career, but old-school fans will love it.
While it certainly meanders at times, even lacking dramatic punch, The Giants still stands tall when it needs to.
One for the fans, Weide's doc is a pleasant career overview but if you're looking for something more probing, it'll drive you Bananas.
Wes Anderson's seventh film feels like a Greatest Hits package. Which if you're a Wes fan will make you very happy.
While the wheels start spinning in the film's overly drawn-out launderette sequence, they pretty much come off by the final act, when the pacing sags like an old mattress.
Jarring, grimy and a searing indictment of Broken Britain.
If close-to-the-bone humour is your thing, Sacha Baron Cohen's latest is just what the dictator ordered.
Smartly scripted by Seth Grahame-Smith, Burton makes the 70s work for the film.
Cool cast, hip directors, but a movie that's less than the sum of both. Like its title character, Jeff is gentle, warm but a little forgettable.
Melding Mel, Mexico and mariachi, Grunberg's debut is a watchable action-comedy, if a little throwaway. Good Friday-night fun.
Twisted, tense and trashy, it's glorious fun.
Sneakily satirising our fascination with celebrity culture, it's a crafty story that doesn't outstay its welcome.
While there are some undeniably engaging moments - the surreal twists and savage dialogue - the film unveils a soft centre in the final third.
It feels like a missed opportunity.
Muso heaven.
You will never look at a Big Mac quite the same way again.
[A] chaotic, stunt-heavy and decidedly silly reprise of the action franchise MIA since 2005.
It's a sensational performance (or performances) from McAvoy, switching between many of these oddballs as they struggle to become the dominant force inside their host.
You might call it Cannibal Holocaust meets Jacques Tati, though really most descriptions don't get to grips with Slack Bay, a period crime caper with outré performances and bizarre humour.
Desierto is a brutal, relentless and pared-back survival thriller bursting with primal energy.
Less a treatise on extremism than an exploration of western fears and prejudices, this is potent and provocative - and packs a skin-prickling finale.
As a portrait of a struggling mum it's spot-on.
Side-splitting stuff from Key and Peele, and little Keanu's a star. But the finale is by no means purr-fect.
It's a flat farce, offering cheap gags about erectile dysfunction and trouser-swapping. The Big Short proved humour could make economics accessible, but this is tasteless.
Amid all the screaming adolescents and mangy dogs, there's little sense why we needed a remake. Surely the target demographic is capable of tracking the original down?
Its core values are undermined by some amateur-hour acting, poor production values, and director Harold Cronk ensures it's all as subtle as being whacked over the head with a King James Bible.
The Safdies pull off this episodic plunge into a scuzz-nik world with brash, bracing immediacy: but it's Holmes' innate charisma that keeps you there.
With robotic depictions of Iran's 'morality police', the political subtext is strictly one-dimensional. But with ace choreographer Akram Khan on board, the dancing is powerful.
Meandering like a jazz riff, Miles Ahead is a curio that doesn't quite come off. But credit Cheadle, both in front and behind camera, for refusing to play the easy notes.

Veering off in a totally unexpected direction, it features a key role played by House Of Cards' Reg E. Cathey as a local crazy... but to say more would ruin the pleasures this barbed comedy has to offer.
A tough watch, sluggishly paced, but youll be fighting off the tears by the end.
It's Rebecca Hall that arguably deserves the greatest praise; she practically devours her role in a way she's rarely, if ever, been allowed to do on screen before.
Cumbersomely scripted and scored ... about as subtle as a Sun headline.
Far from destroying its predecessor's legacy, T2 builds on it with characters that are older, sadder and definitely not wiser. Heroin chic is making a comeback.
Frank, unsentimental but fuelled by good nature and an earthy humour, the film reminds you of Loach's great works in the early '90s like Raining Stones and Ladybird, Ladybird.
It's a dirty, sweaty, violent, tragic tale, but vigorously realised.
As for the voice talent, Homeland's Mandy Patinkin is the standout, as Papa Smurf -- his warm tones are perfect to play the aged patriarchal figure.
Amma Asante's third film is a tastefully made true-life story, based around a forgotten romance that caused familial, national and international strife.
Purely for a visual standpoint, Ghost in the Shell is a thing of absolute beauty.
While a dyed-blonde Jones does gamely with another thinly-sketched role, the real fun of [the film] is watching Kingsley and Hopkins deliver two of the more off-kilter performances of their careers.
Heart-pounding tension spoilt by jarring plot holes.
Under Condon's watchful eye, a whole new generation of children will fall in love with Belle and her Beast.
It's Only the End of the World is a familial drama with emotions pitched to hysterical levels, and it's quite a trial to spend 97 minutes in its presence.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts strikes a fine balance between action, drama and humour.
A textured, nimble work, Elle will leave you gasping at its brilliantly bad behaviour.
If the first film tapped into the chemical generation, T2 deals with our addiction to nostalgia. ... A marvellous sequel.
Ade, in only her third film as director, blends familial drama, comedy of embarrassment and a social critique of sexism in the workplace into a unique comic cauldron.
Cult status beckons.
Adopting a jigsaw-like structure, as past memories impinge on the present, Lonergan layers his characters with an enviable emotional complexity.
Logan is full of juicy surprises. But what impresses most is how, for once, this is a comic-book film that has the guts to wrap things up.
If you enjoy relentless bouts of gun-fu and Reeves at his taciturn best, then this is the follow-up for you.
With the upcoming Justice League film alluded to, you're left wishing its director Zack Snyder was using Lego bricks and not humans.
This is the sort of nostalgic, dreamlike family film parents and grandparents will find -- perhaps more so than their offspring -- perfectly pleasant viewing.
The Fate of the Furious is an engrossing, lightning-paced fairground ride.
Endlessly intriguing.
Both actresses are fantastic, yet the film suffocates, over-egging the pudding in the final act.
Space travel has never seemed so soporific as it does in Passengers, Morten Tyldum's slick but empty vessel of a movie.
Avoiding the usual schmaltz that accompanies most modern-day cartoons, Sing is funny, warm and touching. And you'll definitely want to burst into song.
Brookner captures his uncle's unique spirit and courage.
While the principal characters are new, Edwards ensures there are enough significant nods to the Star Wars universe to enchant fans.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fortunately, even in its most insipid moments, Café Society is gorgeous to look at.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople might just be Waititi's most triumphant moment to date.
Filled with half-baked laughs, don't expect much in the way of Christmas cheer here.
Neither romantic nor comic enough to be a great romcom, but still date-night worthy.
Alongside Sheehan's charms, it's Belleville's intoxicating visuals that truly fire the imagination. India has rarely seemed so seductive.
Stone's heart is in the right place.
An impressive directorial debut - and acting turn - from Parker that deserves to be seen, despite the PR firestorm.
As a testament to a forgotten wartime hero, it's a credible, well-crafted portrait.
It's an intriguing moral dilemma, even while stretching the boundaries of credibility.
The intent is there, but Bad Santa 2 is a tired sequel that lacks the first film's festive freshness.
Oyelowo and Pike capture their characters' courage, but never the romance that kept their belief burning.
Schrader has fun, wallowing in the lurid detail and bloody violence.
Writer-producer James Schamus' elegant directorial debut.
The back story, with the pursuit of the Apple, is vague and frustrating; the back-and-forth between present and past hampers the film's fluidity; and the characterisation is weak.
Hou puts the art in martial arts with this ravishing but strangely authentic actioner. Some will baulk at the pacing and plotting, but this needs to be seen.
Any film that takes literature this seriously deserves some credit.
Jason Bourne is a superior summer blockbuster -- bursting with brawn and brains.
The resulting drama offers a great showcase for Dyrholm, whose slide towards instability is the film's core.
Spot-on Solondz, full of his trademark bite and bile. Dog lovers beware, though: this one's not for you.
For all its undoubted curiosity value, this Valley runs dry too quickly.
Messy for sure, and the boho backdrop will alienate/irritate, but Foggin adeptly captures the flush of first love.
Enjoyable enough but no more, please.
Depending on your feeling towards felines, this is the sort of film that you'll either find dangerously mawkish or utterly charming.
While it struggles to find rhythm, you can't fault Sarif's ambitions.
Beautiful and bold, rebellious and riotous, its sexual frankness puts E.L. James in the shade.
Subtle and skilled, this simmers for long periods until its highly satisfying finale.
Artfully made, tender and touching.
The result is a sparkling, cheeky delight.
It's an increasingly bizarre story, but Trapero keeps you engrossed with a well-crafted script and terrific performances.
Conveying a (sur) real sense of what sex, religion and TV would look like through alien eyes, it's ambitious, artful and unique.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Amalric jigsaws the pieces, conjuring a taut, tense air of Chabrol as he does.
Monahan adeptly captures an air of faded, stinking decadence -- but after an unforeseen murder, the third act never really materialises.
With the original cast back, and Vardalos scripting again, it doesn't stray far from the 'overbearing family' formula that dominated the original.
A smart gen-gap tale with loveable characters.
Maybe it's churlish to be so harsh about what is, after all, a jungle fantasy. But with such a surfeit CGI, the film is more hollow than heroic.
Huppert's subtle portrait of a woman trying to stem the flow of a life crisis remains engaging, humorous and powerful until the very end.
Funny, tender and touching, this is a well-crafted story with plenty to offer.
From the obligatory Stan Lee cameo to the also-obligatory post-credits sequences, Marvel knows its audience.
The spirited sequel Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a smartly engineered family film with plenty to make you smile.
This is an emotional ride all right, an incident-packed epic that introduces new characters, reacquaints us with old friends, answers some questions and raises some more.
A powerful portrait of horror, hope and humanity emerges.
It's unevenly mounted but kept watchable by the lively script and classy cast.
Truly epic.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Directed by Roger Mainwood, who has worked on many Briggs adaptations, the hand-drawn animation is as tender and gentle as the characters and their simple yet beautiful love story.
The tension of the Christie novel ... never really emerges in a film that seems dazzled by the refined costumes, the train's luxury trappings and far too much CGI.
For all its quirky touches, the narrative doesn't spare its ire when it comes to the plight of refugees and the treatment many endure. This is a film bursting with humanity.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Justice League, for all its flaws, is a vast improvement on the lumbering Batman v Superman.
A superb satirical swipe at the worst excesses of the social media generation. Deserves a lot of 'likes'.
It's as poetic as mafia movies get, with its symbolic gestures towards fairy tale ... An unmissable film.
Harrelson cuts deep into his character, leaving a deep, dark impression.
It's impossible not to be swept up by the artistic achievements on show. Van Gogh's distinct brush strokes, lovingly recreated frame by frame, bring this animation vividly alive.
Jordan Peele's Get Out is one of the more intriguing and provocative horror movies to come out of Hollywood in recent years.
Whether or not you're a fan of Wonder Woman, this tale of her creation is rich, evocative and enlightening.
Only Craig's turn really leaves an impression, and you're left with the feeling that, for all its brio, Logan Lucky doesn't amount to a hill of beans, as they say in those parts.
A diverting - if hardly life-changing - doc.
It is a brisk finger-snap of a film that glitters momentarily, then is gone.
A group of kids head off to the 'Isle of Sound' music festival to cut loose and give their parents the shakes in this mildly entertaining romp.
Cooper's western may be too meditative for some, but its grit, beauty and honesty are too potent to ignore.
Grappling with Churchill's inner humanity and steely resolve, Oldman has offered a portrayal for the ages.
A story about soul-searching, it should appeal to folks old enough to remember the 60s, and to those who wish they could have been there.
Day-Lewis, in what he claims to be his final role, is quite marvellous: cruel, vulnerable, humorous and preening. Impressively, Manville and Krieps hold their own.
A fun romp with a great comic performance from Oyelowo. Doesn't linger, but you'll enjoy it while it lasts.
Mine is a film that is nowhere near as clever as it thinks it is...this directorial debut from Fabio Guaglione and Fabio Resinaro is all conceit and no substance.
Of course many a good idea in Hollywood falters before the final reel. But this latest DreamWorks animation is more comforting than a warm bottle of baby milk.
Beautifully photographed and capturing the famous region in all its glory, this is a gentle breeze of a film.
movie_title: Back to Burgundy (Ce qui nous lie) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: When the film's more explosive moments come, Dibb has earned them, partly through the emotional credit accumulated by a uniformly excellent cast.
A surgical dissection of a volatile affair, between free-spirited archaeologist Elliott Gould and married woman Bibi Andersson, it's an unsettling, sometimes ugly experience.
Its love-in-later-life insights are well-worn, but with Staunton on song, Richard Loncraine's film mines genuine feeling.
Hi-tech gadgets, jungle combat, vehicle chases, ready-made quips, casino hookups - there's something very James Bond-esque about Black Panther.
Spielberg injects real urgency into the film, which feels utterly relevant as we move into Donald Trump's second year in office.
A smart, thought-provoking miniature piece.
A salty road trip tinged with sadness, sensitively handled by Linklater and his cast. Unfocused in places, but never less than diverting.
Ball's enthusiasm for James Dashner's series of books shines through - perhaps slightly too much, with the final act taking a little too long to find closure.
The film has a bigger budget than the previous outings - glitzy European locations, star cameos and so on - but none of the charm.
Have a Nice Day is a welcome change from the primary colours that dominate most Hollywood animations. It marks Liu out as a filmmaker of distinction, if not originality.
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There are some fine actors aboard The Commuter ... but they're obliterated amid the carriage carnage and cheap lines. This film is expensive-looking trash.
Largely gung-ho nonsense, but it's always a pleasure to see J.K. Simmons in ball-busting mode, barking words like "simpletons!" at his men.
Aesthetically brave, narratively chaotic, this casts a singular spell.
Aided by an astounding Vaughn, Zahler's ultra-violent genre mash-up is bloody terrific.
With its heart powered by Led Zeppelin's Immigrant Song, this is superhero rock 'n' roll with lashings of Waititi-led comedy.
Todd Solondz is back to his savage best with Wiener-Dog, an episodic movie following the life of a little dachshund.
For sheer fun, Spider-Man: Homecoming is hard to beat.
Against the odds, Homecoming breathes new life into the character.
The film is, of course, aimed squarely at 13-year-old boys, and with that in mind, it fills its purpose.
[Cox gives] a star turn, even if it doesn't quite have the film it deserves to accompany it.
A film noir with a difference, Pete Travis' City of Tiny Lights is an intoxicating brew: dark and dangerous, but also achingly romantic.
It's a richly thought-provoking attempt to bring Barnes' story to life.
The staging of Fuller's work (notably her Serpentine Dance) is beguiling, even if some patchy editing has been used to switch between the actors and their body doubles.
With incoming co-directors, fresh faces, surprise cameos and a rollicking script, this fifth instalment sparkles like pirate booty.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A striking drama that rigorously deals with themes of corruption and moral decline.
Spark: A Space Tail is a real mishmash of a movie.
Hunnam is eminently watchable as the Excalibur-wielding Arthur, here revealed to be born in very humble surroundings. Likewise Law ... gives a menacing turn as the evil King Vortigern.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Stewart is placed in far scarier circumstances than in the vampire-driven Twilight franchise that made her name.
'Alien' fans will revel in the terror.
Cotillard does what's required, and she dovetails well with actor-turned-director Garcia. But this is substandard material for both.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's predictable but pleasurable enough - an inoffensive charmer that doesn't outstay its welcome.
Delivered with humour and pathos, this is a literary film in more ways than one. ... Those who find pleasure in the written word will discover much to enjoy here.
It's refreshing to see a blockbuster that - until the end at least - isn't all about carnage and mayhem.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the end result is not quite as punchy as earlier films, a minor Dardenne work is still something that demands your attention.
No war film you've seen before - from Das Boot to Saving Private Ryan to The Thin Red Line - comes close to what Nolan has created here.
The film is more a series of isolated high points than a united whole, but it has bags of charm.
When the fires start raging, the director stages the action with real confidence. Even if the patriotism is poured on like kerosene, this one burns with intensity.
... fritters away a cast headed by Michael Fassbender and Rebecca Ferguson.
Maybe she's weighed down by the big hair but [Brie] Larson is left with the least interesting role.
The final act is mushy without ever really earning the right to be, and Elba and Winslet - despite a steamy love scene - have zero chemistry.
It's a competent and credible work, even dipping into fantasy with a couple of subtle animated moments that bring alive the enchanting illustrations featured in the Pooh books.
This is really Villeneuve's film: he surpasses even his own 2016 sci-fi Arrival with this stunning visual masterpiece.
With Harry afflicted by amnesia, it is as if the same brain fog has fallen upon Vaughn and his co-writer Jane Goldman. They have forgotten what made the first film great.
The razor-sharp comedy sees both Coogan and Brydon play exaggerated versions of themselves as they travel to various gourmet eateries.
Julie Delpy, who co-wrote the script with Eugenie Grandval, directs with the minimum of fuss, keeping the farce fast and funny.
Cuesta injects vitality where it's needed.
Aronofsky's maternal horror is the most out-there studio movie of the year. You won't believe your eyes.
A stinging rebuttal to all the deniers and detractors who tried to discredit the original Davis Guggenheim-directed film.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the more enjoyable Cruise outings in a while, at least for those who prefer to see him sacrifice his indestructible alpha-male persona.
Lacking any real scares, its ghoulish terror feels muted; but Medina's depiction of Victorian London-- particularly the music hall scene -- is amply atmospheric.
A buddy film that borrows heavily from the much-better Midnight Run (1988), The Hitman's Bodyguard is foul-mouthed and foul-tempered but rarely raises a pulse or smile.
A blend of the corporeal and the cerebral, Hungarian writer-director Ildikó Enyedi's first film in 18 years is a mysterious, poetic and sometimes baffling piece.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing minimal CGI with plenty of in-camera visuals (furniture flying, demonic creatures, fingers snapping), it's a horror cauldron that simmers away nicely, before bubbling fiercely.
Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is a visual banquet that leaves you feeling sick.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's surprisingly effective.
The Wailing isn't quite dynamic enough to truly terrorise, but ... there are ferocious moments that puncture the stillness.
Redmayne is superb in the lead, and there's real emotion, comedy and romance in his blossoming friendships.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Solemn flashbacks sink the plot.
From the crashes of Vivaldi on the soundtrack to the static shots of clanking machinery in the nearby ski resort, it's an oddly unsettling experience.
It's not John le Carré, but Spy is more than just an excuse for guns and gags.
Mommy forces you to give in to its relentless energy. Dolan conducts it with gusto, leaving us with a cathartic reckoning with his own demons.
You won't see any high-speed chases or fire-breathing monsters - just a beautifully simple cartoon that truly captures the spirit of the originals. This is true Moomin heaven.
Both revealing and good-natured, it's a very inviting exploration of one of the 20th Century's major artists.
Irreverent and incorrigible, Deadpool pricks the pomposity of your average Hollywood comic book movie with a delicious laugh-out-loud script.
Allegiant ... is an underwhelming encounter that feels as drab as the ruinous, walled-off Chicago setting of the preceding films.
A film about backstory was always going to struggle. But while the narrative loses power as it unfolds, the cast and FX give it some sparkle.
Not since Frozen has there been so much on-screen ice as there is [here]. It's all thanks to Emily Blunt's Freya, the blue-eyed villainess who spews it out like a broken fridge-freezer.
Some fairytales 'never truly end' intones Liam Neeson's narrator - unfortunately, this franchise feels like it has indeed run its course.
Only the appearance of Christopher Walken, as Peary's one-time coach, feels ill-at-ease with the bonhomie. Otherwise, Eddie the Eagle takes flight - and stays there.

Vincent's innate paranoia is reflected in the film's unsettling atmosphere, with Winocour cunningly ratcheting up the tension, while shadows and darkness come into play when it lurches into home-invasion territory.

In recalling 1970s Hollywood classics such as Dirty Harry, The French Connection and Serpico, it is heartening to see that Hollywood still has the guts to deliver a film where redemption is a dirty word.
Woodley ... struggles with a character that, unlike Jennifer Lawrence in the Hunger Games films, is getting less interesting with each passing movie.
Zootropolis is a colourful, creative and charming film, full of wit and invention.
It'll leave you buzzing.
The movie slips towards disease-of-the-week terrain.
If you're a fan, it'll feel like a gathering of old friends. And if you're not, maybe start with the TV show.
More Blue Steel than Magnum, this is a perfectly serviceable sequel, but dogged by repetition, it lacks the original's speed and sizzle.
Taylor seasons the loopy narrative with some jaw-dropping 3D action, whether it's demolishing San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge or somersaulting a schoolbus.
Sachs understands [Lithgow and Molina's] consummate skills as actors; putting them together, the result is wonderfully warm and wise.
DreamWorks has arguably produced its strangest animation yet with Trolls, a bright-and-breezy sing-a-long fairy-tale cartoon musical.
The big name on the credits is Catherine Deneuve, but it's newcomer Rod Paradot that will grab your attention.
Sarah Gavron's film is, amazingly, the first ever to be made about the Suffragettes.
The opening sequence, recreating the Day of the Dead festival in Mexico City as 007 grapples with a target in a helicopter, is worth the ticket price alone.
Violent, uncompromising and superbly executed, this is visceral filmmaking of the highest order.
Not that you should be surprised by the cliché-riddled dialogue in this tiresome fantasy film - a world of spells, incantations, necromancers and meaningless mumbo-jumbo meant to pass as exotic.
For all its feeling of a throwaway penny dreadful, Crimson Peak looks gorgeous ... Still, it's the film's smaller moments that set the mind racing.
Whether you loved her music or loathed her presence in the tabloids, Amy is a film that lingers long after you've left the cinema.
Painting Neverland in such drab colours, with a story that revolves around child labour, is hardly a blueprint for a fun-packed movie.
What a shame Delamarre's sense of occasion couldn't be used for something less inane.
Fortunately, this is a film geared towards its older characters (something Meyers ... excels at). De Niro hasn't had it so good in years.
Rather like one of Wilson's records, it's a film of surprisingly effective layers, building towards a hugely satisfying crescendo.
In the end, it's perhaps Mother Nature that gives the best performance; she's never been more majestic on film.
Co-written by Bogdanovich with his ex-wife Louise Stratten ... the story is brisk, breezy and executed with panache.
Pixels feels like a wasted opportunity. Kids today won't care, while big kids will just despair.
Sophisticated and slick, Ritchie's film is far more appealing than his take on Sherlock. ... The dialogue is crisp and as elegant as the film's fashions, production design and Italian locations.
The action scenes are plentiful, with a colourful globetrotting story that bounces from Minsk to Vienna to Casablanca to London.
The colourful 3D animation is as first-rate as you'd expect, with Coffin and co packing the film with rich sight gags.
Unfortunately, for the most part, it feels like the Sleepwalking Dead.
Loud, lewd, inventive and outrageous, Deadpool is a delight.
The result won't astound but it will intrigue - at least for a time.
Bar the occasional faint-smile-raising line, just about every gag, set-piece or quip meets with dead-eyed, stony silence.

Trank's origin story brings nothing new to the party, apart from a rather muted, real-world aesthetic that counters the colourful worlds dreamed up by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby in the original Marvel comics.
What goes wrong? Lack of humour, for starters. Dry and drab, Trank's film sacrifices the primary-colour aesthetics of the comics for a gritty 'real-world' environment.
For a story that could so easily have got it wrong, A Royal Night Out seems to hit the right notes time and again. Bright, breezy and charming to the last, there's not an ounce of cynicism here.
Too many Minions can lead to overkill.
A rollickingly old-fashioned caper from Matthew Vaughn.

Despite lacking any nods towards Salgado's artistic influences, The Salt of the Earth leaves you both traumatised and tantalised; his work can be difficult to take in at times, but there is no doubt you're left wanting more.
True, the novelty factor of the original has disappeared. But if you're looking for a shamelessly puerile comedy, you won't find anything lewder or louder this summer.
The ending has one WTF moment that lacks credibility, even in this logic-defying loopy universe. But by then, you'll have most likely given in - and just accepted this as the barmiest Terminator yet.
Making good on its XXL, the Magic Mike sequel delivers what you'd want in a follow-up about male strippers: more flesh, more abs, more dances, the phworr factor cranked up to eleven.
The film has rather lost the sweetness of its predecessors.

Slow West is too irreverent to be instantly iconic or truly heartbreaking, undermining its most potentially poignant moment in amusingly emphatic style. That's not to say that it isn't striking or stirring.
The dialogue rattles along at a tremendous pace, with the gags feeling organic and largely sophisticated.
Punchy, provocative and just plain sad, whether you're a fan of Winehouse's music or not, Amy is a film you'll be thinking about for days after.
It's not hard to see why Russell washed his hands of the unfinished cut; it would've been better left as the mysterious movie we never saw than the half-baked one we're lumbered with now.
For once, more of the same is no criticism: it's exactly what fans of the show would want, even if newcomers will be left unmoved.
Jurassic World is a fiendishly crafted blockbuster: old-fashioned thrills, heroism and romance, locked inside a smart, self-aware shell.
Punchy, provocative and packed with attitude.
Too much of the film feels one-note - like a cursory sketch rather than a developed idea.

Shot in stomach-knotting 3D, it has the same white-knuckle intensity as Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity. Placing you firmly on the mountain, the film makes you feel the vertigo, the rush of blood to the head.
Bubbling over with anger at the ever-increasing wealth divide, it's searing, sensational stuff.
The problem is, the film seems entirely pointless.
Without wishing to over-hype it, it's up there with that classic study of Nixon-era investigative journalism, All the President's Men.
Cruel, lazily scripted and ultimately spineless ...
The efficient script hides its secrets well, with Moretz an ever-watchable presence.
Harking back to the franchise's glory days, it's a movie hardcore Rocky fans will love.
It won't be for everyone - the pacing is glacial at times - but At Any Price certainly deserves attention.
Maybe it doesn't amount to a whole hill of beans, but you'll have immense fun while it lasts.
This is a real 'What would you do?' movie, the sort you'll be turning over in your mind for days after, and the result is first-rate.
This so-called 'regeneration' is a real hotchpotch.
What's really surprising too is just how emotional it all is. More than just nostalgia, The Force Awakens earns its tears. Star Wars is back in a big way: as C-3PO might say, thank the maker.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: McAvoy's high-energy turn will keep you watching, at least, but only just.
Boasting a script that's been polished by the Coens, the end product is taut and engaging. Hanks is as dependable as ever but it's Rylance who shines.
An A-list guilty pleasure.
Don't miss.
movie_title: Tell Spring Not To Come This Year (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The narrative plods in the final third, the twists are obvious and even Lawrence feels like she's outgrown this role. All in all it feels functional rather than fantastic.
If he were alive today, Thomas would almost certainly approve.
There's a day-dreamy quality to Paper Planes that makes it a pleasure to watch.

Amid all the camp craziness of Wright's vision, with Jackman twirling his moustache as if his life depends on it, Miller is the one truly watchable element of the film. The rest could have done with drastic pruning.

That bare outline doesn't even begin to capture the sheer wild ambition, beauty and savagery on show in The Revenant. Far more challenging than even Iñárritu's bravura Oscar-winner Birdman, this is his Fitzcarraldo or his Apocalypse Now.
Helgeland's film falls way short compared to Peter Medak's 1990 film The Krays, which elevated their story to an almost poetic level. Next to it, Legend feels like a cartoon.
The pace picks up as Katniss traverses a city laced with booby traps - an oil flood and a tunnel full of mutants provide the film's best action scenes.
This is more than just a nostalgia trip: Star Wars is back and it feels beautiful.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unsurprisingly, Streep hits all the right - or should that be wrong? - notes, with a marvellously tragi-comic turn.
Direct and full of energy, you'll laugh and feel guilty for doing so.
Joost and Schulman manage to weld this hi-tech story into one about the fragility of pubescent friendships and that very Hollywood theme of being true to yourself.
Uplifting it isn't, but there's poetry to be found in these desperate lives, and Riccobono never judges or sensationalises his subjects. Sensitive, if slightly unfocused.
What's really remarkable is how you'll forget this is a one-take wonder as the characters and story takes hold. Brilliantly engineered, coolly executed, Victoria is a triumph.
The barbs are scissor-sharp, making this a threequel that delivers what you want while throwing in some surprises.
It's penned by the screenwriters behind the hopeless Dracula Untold and The Last Witch Hunter, who must be really good in pitch meetings because this is utter nonsense.
Playing the BFG, via motion capture technology, Mark Rylance inhabits the giant with real humanity and warmth, his own soul shining through the digital makeover.
For those looking for some unpretentious midnight-movie thrills, Collet-Serra's film works on the most basic primal level.
The result is a cool, crucial indie of the sort that now feels all too rare.
A knockabout adventure that has all the zaniness of a Looney Tunes cartoon and none of the charm.
This oestrogen-packed incarnation of New York's finest ghost hunters turns out to be an affectionate homage to the 1984 original, never straying too far from its source.
