A hugely enjoyable romp. Alien hordes, Enterprise annihilation, ass-kicking females, emotional goodbyes ... this one has it all.
Never preaching, Rosi leaves it for us to soak up these revelations. The result is sometimes wayward but peppered with images that sear the brain.
This tale is intriguingly structured and expertly executed, and wholeheartedly embraces the moral complexities of one of the most divisive issues of modern military combat.
Billed by some as a lurid lesbian potboiler when it premiered in Cannes, The Handmaiden is much more lavish than this reductive description suggests.
Even films with the best of intentions can go horribly awry. ... [This is] a narrative that can't decide if it's a disease-of-the-week drama, a gay rights story or a courtroom battle.
Call it All About Her Daughter if you like, but this tale of a mother and her fractured relationship with her offspring is up there with Almodóvar's best.
Crucially, Resurgence lacks the heart-pounding tension of the original. The first film, after all, showed we could beat the aliens. There isn't much here to suggest we won't do it again.
With a white-haired Hanks on rock-solid form, it's a finely etched portrait of an ultra-modest hero.
Ultimately, it pays off with a nerve-shredding finale every bit as shiver-inducing and despairing as the original.
If Shane Meadows had made Breakdance: The Movie, it might've looked like this amusing account of how Nottingham rivals The Assassinators and Rock City Crew busted out the big moves.
movie_title: NG83 When We Were B Boys (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The engrossing 3D visuals are superbly conceived, like Inception times 1,000, as buildings start to fold in on themselves, kaleidoscope-style.
A tightly controlled prison drama that has little interest in the clichés that usually afflict this well-worn genre.
Cumberbatch fits Doctor Strange like a pair of snap-tight surgical gloves, in yet another MCU triumph. Beautifully designed, brilliantly executed.
It's entertaining enough, even boasting the odd moment of dry wit, and the rooftop finale amid a New Orleans Halloween parade is arresting.
Rarely makes an unpredictable move. But it has warmth, a lively sense of pace, and a fine breakout turn from Madina Nalwanga ...
Rebecca Miller's New York-set comedy-of-manners is far removed from the traumas of her earlier works.
Unlike recent zombie efforts such as The Girl with All the Gifts and Train to Busan, Williams' work offers little in the way of originality.
Jean-François Richet elevates the predictable action with swagger, while a grizzled Gibson gives us glimpses of his glory days

Fortunately, Blunt keeps the film anchored. Playing drunk convincingly is no mean feat, but she cracks it, maintaining our sympathy for a character who has gradually slipped towards becoming a functioning alcoholic.
It's heavy-handed, but with such fine performances from the youngsters, aided by the ever-reliable Shirley Henderson, that it's hard not to get sucked into this tragic tale.
Luchini's excellent, but this is guilty of gross tonal uncertainty.

The man himself is the sole interviewee -- a risky strategy but one that pays off here; whether dissing his Obsession star Cliff Robertson or conceding mistakes on The Bonfire of the Vanities, he's illuminating, hilarious company.
Radcliffe, with shaven head, is solid.
A franchise that's run its course, the satire feels limp and the anger muted.
Not only are the visual effects spectacular, Berg truly captures the mounting horror of being engulfed in a disaster like that.
A new direction is needed or Malick's aura will surely evaporate.
To his credit, Doremus is a subtle director, who prefers exploring human feeling to mechanical action.
Luca Guadagnino is expert at conjuring a pungent, sexually decadent atmosphere - a ringmaster in full control of his circus.
From cats squeezing themselves into random receptacles to dogs chasing aimless balls, the delight of Pets is in the YouTube-inspired detail.
DeHaan captures Dean's essence impressively, while Pattinson delivers his best work since David Cronenberg's Cosmopolis.
Mirren and Rickman are outstanding, and Hood complements them by juggling theme and pace with aplomb. The result is as thought-provoking as it is nerve-shredding.
The script lacks the religious or philosophical depth [of The Exorcist]. But there's nerve-tingling tension aplenty, expertly choreographed by Wan, right up until the grand cliffhanger finale.
Nothing short of an unmitigated disaster.
It's a film therapists could spend years analysing on the couch. [Kaufman] has, once again, succinctly captured that very modern problem of how we live. Sheer genius.
This being Sorrentino, the film has an almost symphonic feel; images and music are perfectly choreographed. ... It's a perfect cinematic cocktail -- dizzying and dazzling.
Brooklyn is an old-fashioned, beautifully measured story about family, independence and the pain of separation.
Abrahamson is never less than sensitive in his handling, never close to exploitation. It's a tough film, not easy to watch but equally hard to take your eyes off.
By the end, even the hardest of hearts will find it difficult to hold back the tears.
It's always a pleasure to see Stiller and Wilson inhabit these characters, goofing off with guest stars that range from Sting to Marc Jacobs.
Vikander ... brings real empathy to her role as Gerda -- a woman who supports Lili through her traumatic and painful journey.
Forensically written and directed with restraint, it's a film of huge social importance -- never sensationalistic, always spot on.
The torment is captured well enough in the faces of the actors, their characters locked inside an indifferent, inhospitable world.
It's a fine feat of screenwriting, particularly given its 'heroes' are bankers about to get rich on public misery. ... This is one Hollywood film that doesn't come up short.
Keen to follow the Judd Apatow formula -- crude gags plus big-hearted sentiment -- Dirty Grandpa winds up losing the courage of its gross-out convictions. Offensive in all the wrong ways.
Revitalising the tired notion of a biopic, this three-act miracle is unquestionably the best-written movie of the past year.
Comparisons to Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver are obvious but valid: the shocking finale will leave you stunned.
It's just another likeable Russell-Lawrence knockabout.
Credit Vallée - one of the best actors' directors working in Hollywood - for going out on a limb here, depicting the unusual ways inner turmoil can manifest itself.
Even if the kids are left wanting more, purists will doubtless be pleased with Mark Osborne's reverential take on Antoine de Saint-Exupery's 1943 tale.
Boasting stunning photorealistic CGI, the 3-D visual effects are nothing short of incredible. Right down to the droplets of water nestling in the animals' fur, every detail is perfect.
Frot is particularly telling in what might also be called Marguerite's last act - her voice both heartfelt and horrendous as comedy gives way to tragedy. The result is quietly heartbreaking.
Warcraft: The Beginning is less a complex immersive digital experience than a simplified sub-Lord of the Rings tale, pitching humans against a race of Orcs.
It's hard to hold back the tears for a story that has the courage of its convictions.
For a knockabout farce, The Nice Guys scores high on the charts.
This second live-action film [is] a blend of kinetic violence, bizarre aliens and actors the calibre of Laura Linney wondering what on earth they've got themselves into.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Here's a rarity: a summer sequel that's far better than its predecessor.
Mon Roi feasts on an energy that lifts it above the usual boy-meets-girl tale. ... For Maïwenn, injecting real urgency into an age-old subject, it's a real feather in her cap.
If you're looking for an adult maturation story, told with real panache, you could do a whole lot worse.
Never mind Elba, this might be Watkins' 007 calling card.
It's a melancholic delight.
Some will balk at the macho sexism that runs rife, but Linklater perfectly captures the lust for life that accompanies those early college days. It's magical.
This is contemporary - not Cold War - le Carré, but no less compelling for that.
Nanni Moretti returns with ... one of the most quietly personal films of his distinguished career. ... By the end, you won't know whether your tears are those of laughter or of sorrow.
As a way of melding sport and politics, biopic and historical document, Race is an impressive achievement - and one to be savoured.
The story of five orphaned sisters as they teeter on the brink of adulthood, Mustang is a tale pregnant with conflict and one that, despite its languid, naturalistic style, bristles with tension.

movie_review_blurb: "Casino Jack" works as a political film, it works as Shakespearian tragedy, and it works on the level of just plain Kevin Spacey goofiness.
One of Disney's most underrated films, and I can't for the life of me figure out why, unless it's the absence of a big-name star.

There are absolutely no surprises in "Twelve." None. And the characters are as familiar as the story--a stock collection of "prep school" males and females that look as if they've never sat through a class in their lives.

"Father of the Bride" should bring a smile to anyone who's been in a family that's had a wedding-regardless of your point of view. But the sequel doesn't offer quite the same level of comedy and insight.
Because the pace and trajectory changes so noticeably, "The Rum Diary" almost feels like three different films. Some may like that; I didn't.
In tone and in the way that the narrative unfolds, it's a throwback to a more romantic era of filmmaking-when making feel-good movies wasn't anything to apologize for.
I don't think I'm too demanding. All I ask for in a comedy is that it be funny. And in "The Sitter," too often gross-outs and foul language substitute for humor.
I love it when a film surprises me, and "Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life" won me over in the very beginning and held me for the full 122 minutes because of its quirky passion and intelligence.
Its status as a low-budget cult film seems secure. I just don't think it's as good a film as it might have been with more restrained storytelling or art design.
"The Descendants" goes on too long, but that's its only flaw. And frankly, I can see why Payne and his editor decided to go with this print instead of making some awfully tough decisions.
I may be one of the few who prefers the original Swedish TV version, but Fincher does a nice job of staying faithful to the Larsson novel and infusing it with his own sense of style.

movie_review_blurb: Fans of mythic adventure may want to see for themselves, but the storytelling is too disjointed for it to measure up to a film like "300" or "Troy."

Disney's "The Muppets" is a solid family movie that breathes new life into an old franchise. Who'd have thought that were even possible?

I never expect much from a small-studio or low-budget thriller because they're usually disappointing. But "A Lonely Place to Die" is a cut above them, with only minor logic plot points getting in the way.
"The Lion King 1 1/2" is a very clever "syncquel" that's entertaining in the beginning but weighed down by a premise and format that seem ill-suited for a full-length feature.
If you like this film, the sad truth is that it's yet another visual upgrade, and it does contain what Gilliam called "the only reason for buying the Blu-ray"-those lost animations.

"Men in Black" still holds up after 15 years. It's as fun, funky, and edgy now as it was in 1997, and HD breathes even more life into it.

A wonderful blend of timeless romance, wholesome adventure, and breathtaking animation.
As corny as it sounds, Up soars to new animation heights.
This is bleak terrain, but Weisz's performance helps us get through it. And as real-story films go, The Whistleblower is as accurate as can be.
Be Cool isn't the biting satire that Get Shorty was. It's lighter, hipper, and, yes, more fun.
Deneuve's performance and the artistic design make this film work, despite shortcomings in humor and plotting.
The test for a decent family film is whether the kids want to watch it again, and both of mine were ready for a rerun the very next day.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A spellbinding film that charms with its quirkiness in almost every sequence.
If the plot were more original I'd have given this a 7, because it should entertain the target audience of teens and 'tweens.
movie_title: Wizards of Waverly Place The Movie (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For its intended audience, G-Force is a winner. Only a shopworn plot keeps it from being a solid seven.
An entertaining romp of a crime caper flick that wants to be funny more than it wants to be dangerous or mysterious.
This is the best movie version of Zorro to date, and High-Definition makes it that much more exciting.
The cameras take us where few people dare go.
"Wyatt Earp's Revenge" is like a throwback to B-Westerns, with their no-name casts, low budgets, and everything else just a few steps closer to Boot Hill than their big-budget kin.
If I had to watch one low-budget movie over and over again, I'd pick this one over Clerks.

Like Chillingworth's investigations of the minister Dimmesdale in Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter," Sambath's conversations with Brother Number 2 and other killers aren't just reporter's interviews. They're attempts to cleanse and purge the heart.
Poor writing and inconsistencies sink this film. Let's hope that Zeta-Jones and Bartha can rebound.

In "Manhattan," Allen has more to say about people, relationships, and human nature than he does in "Annie Hall" . . . but what he says, apart from a handful of hilarious lines, isn't as consistently funny.
As indie films go, "5 Star Day" has good production values, strong performances, and compelling cinematography. It's the premise, plot, and character development that keep it from being successful.
"Amadeus" is glitzier and gets all the attention, but "Mozart's Sister," like its ignored namesake, is also aesthetically pleasing . . . just on a different level.
This Oscar-winning Best Picture still has the power and appeal that won audiences over back in 1960.
Wake Wood at least shows that Hammer is ready to be a player again in the field of horror.
An enjoyable film that tries to move beyond the standard thriller.
Thompson offers an unflinching portrait of the good, the bad, and the ugly of volunteerism.
Although snubbed by the Oscar machine, "The Skin I Live In" is a solid drama-thriller that offers the best contemporary take on the Frankenstein tale that I've seen in a long while.
Offers some amazing footage and a surprisingly cohesive narrative, considering that this was old film stock newly discovered and reassembled by contemporary Swedish filmmakers.
This is a film that ought to be watched by all youngsters hoping for a career in dance.
Cyrus will appeal to the same audiences that have admired the Mumblecore directors and their work, even though it's more polished.
Russell is at his understated best in the film, which stands as a living tribute to Coach Herb Brooks.

The characters model some wonderful behavior for youngsters%u2014things like tolerance, restraint, persistence, good manners, and good sportsmanship. Things that, sadly, seem to have gone the way of knickers.
Despite its flaws, this 1982 TV movie offers an enjoyable version of the Sir Walter Scott romance.
For a true-crime story, there's surprisingly little dramatic arc.
It's not the definitive version of The Hunchback of Notre Dame, but then again, I'm not sure there is such a thing.
Live in Rio is a solid concert, though not as energetic and memorable as Live in Paris.
Great animation, but a narrative disappointment.
If only they had told that Predator dude to go back to the right set . . . .
You can't be too hard on a film that blows up a Rainforest Cafe, can you?
Sleeping Beauty has been regarded as a minor classic for too long. This restored edition should reinforce that it's a classic, period.
This is Hawaiian music at its best, and in Blu-ray the concert is stunning.
Despite a second-act sag, the visuals make The Adventures of Baron Munchausen a worthwhile film.
Ice Age has an unexpected warmth and enough funny lines to make this prehistoric road trip a family-friendly journey.
It's solid, but no showcase for HD.
Reiner's film breaks the romantic-comedy mold because it's not so much about Harry and Sally as it is about men and women.
I wish that all of the film's 144 minutes were spent alone with Hanks.
This series makes explorers of us all!
My Disney princess gave it an 8 out of 10, my son gave it a 7 out of 10, and my wife and I gave it a 6 out of 10.
The Deep doesn't exactly give you the bends, but when you come up for air you realize that this was one cinematic dive that could have been deeper . . . and better edited.
A TV-movie that feels like TV and replaces tense scenic construction with talk and reaction shots instead of focusing on the action.
There was probably more action at the bar where Crowe drank after shooting stopped for the day.
A fun yet enlightening film that's part Mexican and all human.
Though it may not rock with quirkiness or roll with side-splitting humor, Adventureland still is a respectable slice-of-life film.
Even teens might have a hard time identifying with the level of melodrama we get here.
As a fan film, Hannah Montana: The Movie rates a 7 or 8 out of 10, but if you judge it straight-up it's probably closer to a 6.
In the overall realm of Disney magic, Pete's Dragon is a card trick rather than a grand illusion.
As a cop-action flick this isn't bad, but it fits the mold so thoroughly that it feels more familiar than it should.
The most authentic and honest film about high school students and teachers to date.
Thornton offers a subtle, thoughtful script, generally sensitive direction, and an understated performance, uh-huh.
George Bailey and Bedford Falls never looked so good!
It's not just the pacing. The Tigger Movie just doesn't show a lot of imagination.
Bridges' portrayal of Starman can be as hard to take as the lapses in logic.
Eight stories that are fascinating examples of possibility--examples which raise hope both for the future of our planet and religion as well.
When a story's this strong, even weak storytelling and acting can't completely spoil it. Or the music.
movie_title: Mr. Rock 'n Roll: The Alan Freed Story (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A predictable, formulaic, dumb comedy that has about as much depth as Bobby . . . unless you think of it in Forrest Gump terms, and then it begins to get a little less offensive and a little funnier.
Unlike Lumet, Mikhalkov doesn't seem to trust 12 angry (or disturbed) men in a room to pull this off.
A solid prison film that feels so real that if you heard a voiceover you'd swear it was a documentary.

Sherritt has been in a lot of movies, but the role of Rev. Maclean seems like one he was born to play. He owns it, the way that Pitt and Sheffer own theirs, and as a result it takes no time at all to believe this group as a family and become involved.
Like a rotten vaudeville act, this one deserves the hook.
movie_title: I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Starts out strong and has potential, but then deteriorates into soap opera and endless montages.
Other than Hal Holbrook's Mark Twain, I can't think of another literary figure that's brought so realistically to life.
movie_title: Louisa May Alcott: The Woman Behind Little Women (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Proves that Americans don't hold the patent on familial dysfunction, but it's also a sincere personal essay about writer-director Trapero's Argentinean family.
Despite inconsistencies in audience and humor, there's enough to like about Open Season.
Nine Lives isn't a master work, but it's still a fascinating piece of filmmaking.
Even for formulaic TV crime drama, it's below average.

Kids will still like it because the storyline is engaging, the color palette is bright and cheery, the songs are upbeat and pleasant enough, and the messages about good behavior, perseverance and belonging are worthwhile.
movie_title: Stuart Little 3: Call of the Wild (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As consistent and nearly as understated a performance as Robin Williams would give later in Good Will Hunting.
Reese Witherspoon really takes her acting to another level with this film, bringing an electricity to the part of June Carter that deserves more than a little Oscar buzz.
The actors shift gears effortlessly, playing their parts with seriousness when the situation calls for it, but also enjoying those moments that are intended to be fun.
There are killer lines and exchanges, but not the overall consistency you'd hope for, or the kind of energy that could drive a stake through our ennui.
A solid slice-of-communist-life film that succeeds because it avoids the pitfalls and cliches of the typical, bittersweet coming-of-age film.
movie_title: Do You Remember Dolly Bell? (Sjecas li se Dolly Bell) (1986)

movie_review_blurb: O'Toole is the one who really carries the film, an old veteran delivering on a part that, in retrospect, seems as if it couldn't have been played by another.
Provides some unintentional laughs and genuine bursts of adrenalin, however hokey it gets and however Harry Potterish the snakes.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In satirizing history, Wilmott lays down a gauntlet, indicting ingrained attitudes and prejudices, and daring us all to do something about it.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: So, how big is Clifford's Really Big Movie? Maybe too big for a toddler's britches.
What do Ernest Hemingway, Carl Sandburg, Albert Einstein, and E.T. have in common? The eyes, according to Spielberg.
Characterization, plot, and speculations on life and reality take a backseat to the martial arts shoot 'em up sequences, which seem overly long and decidedly ho-hum.
Master and Commander offers the most meticulously researched and realistic depiction of life at sea ever shown on film.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The sequel's a caricatured and clichéd yawner. And the tone is all wrong.
the script and Martha Coolidge direction are so play-it-safe formulaic that the film lacks fairy-tale luster. It's as predictable as an Elvis movie-without the music.
It may not have the epic scope and complexity of Forrest Gump, but Breakfast on Pluto a small gem.
Proof that not all comedies in TV's infancy were slapstick or family oriented.
Brimming with fabulistic charm, this joint BBC/WGBH adaptation of Gerald Durrell's memoir offers the most lovable family of bona fide eccentrics that's been brought to film.

Though the stories themselves are slight, when you compare The Toy Castleto existent programming for pre-schoolers it's refreshing to see an awareness of gender balance and an appreciation for the arts.
An intelligent script that keeps in the spirit and tone of Britain's House of Mountbatten-Windsor, and yet slyly manages a wink at the audience every now and then.
Part road picture, part epic, and part spiritual journey, Seven Years in Tibet is a beautiful film with a story so typical-yet-unusual that it could only have come from autobiography.
Takes us closer to the Bond that Fleming created. We see more vulnerable moments in him, more man than superman. And surprisingly, that makes the legend even stronger.
It's slick and it honors firefighters as obviously as the first wave of WWII films paid tribute to America's fighting men and women.
Foster is a master at portraying a woman in terror who's trying to balance her fears with a survival instinct that drives her to somehow prevail.
It might be aimed at teens, but Sky High is fun for parents, too.
Like Hoosiers, this Jerry Bruckheimer film is a David and Goliath sports saga that holds just as much suspense and interest no matter how many times you watch it.
A visual treat, with characters that look like caricatures and a house that's as much of a monster as anything Hollywood has given us.
I'm not going to beat around the glacier. If you liked Ice Age, you're going to like this sequel.

Though the set-up in this light romantic comedy is a bit strained, once you get into the main interaction with the two stars you get both the laughs and the emotion that you hope for in a film like this.
The human interaction is just a little too precious and the digression away from the dogs and the main story is just too long for it to feel like anything but a major detour.
It's the small details, like dino-skin, that Blu-ray really brings to life.
A Knight's Tale looks and sounds pretty darned good in Blu-ray.
A good old-fashioned melodrama with more twists than a gigantic corkscrew.
Casting Greg Kinnear (As Good As It Gets) to play the straight man to Brosnan's wacked-out whack-man was a stroke of genius.
Yes, the deck is stacked, but the converts that Jarecki presents are pretty convincing.
This charming film paints a lively and convincing portrait of family eccentricity.
Syriana really makes viewers work to try to understand the complexities involved in protecting (or resisting) U.S. interests in the Middle East.
Lucky Number Slevin moves along nicely, and it's easy to get caught up in all that style. But style and cheap tricks are two different things.
Until I saw Tyson, I wouldn't have believed it possible to film a one-sided documentary that felt truthful and complete."
Sugar makes my top ten list of baseball films. It's not your typical sports film, it's emotionally honest, and it's delightfully detailed, yet subtle.
For those who don't have the time to watch all 11 episodes of the BBC series, Earth is a nice alternative.
This beloved 1991 film has never looked better, and seems even more magical in Blu-ray.
The artwork and backgrounds are so wonderful you could care less whether it's fairies onscreen or bullfrogs.
movie_title: Tinker Bell and the Great Fairy Rescue (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Laugh-out-loud funny.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There are easily twice as many songs here as in the original film, and twice as much energy.
While Prince of Persia is no Pirates of the Caribbean, it's also nothing Bruckheimer or Disney need to feel ashamed of. My kids loved it.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As my son says, 'The books were a lot better.'
Despite the cliches and predictability, strong characters and writing make Cougar Town fun to watch.
Oh, the horror! It's the writers who deserve to be sprayed by skunks for giving us this stinker.
Oh, the horror! It's the writers who deserve to be sprayed by skunks for giving us this stinker.
If you don't go into this thinking you're going to be laughing constantly, Date Night is a funny film and a fun time.
If you don't go into this thinking you're going to be laughing constantly, Date Night is a funny film and a fun time.
A melodrama that's aimed at teen girls, but the cinematography and performances make it palatable for others as well--if you don't mind someone toying with your emotions.
If you like I Love Lucy you'll like The Mothers-in-Law. They're cut from the same cloth.
A wonderful period film first and secondarily an interesting mystery-romance that keeps you guessing about the big questions until late in the narrative.
As a film in general, Uncle Nino would probably be no more than a 6 out of 10, but as a family film it merits a 7.
An art-house version of a historical drama that takes plenty of risks--some of which are more successful than others. But you can't say enough about Giovanna Mezzogiorno's performance.

Even if you want more from a film than a depiction of reality, you'll still appreciate the stars' performances. But you'll find yourself thinking it could have been so much better if rendering grief effectively didn't seem like the only goal.
I couldn't get past Brody as an action hero, and I didn't jump from my seat once. I wanted at least that much from a film that spent so much money on bullets and bazookas and bombs and bombast.
It may be darker, but favorite moments abound in this film--Pixar treats that make "Toy Story 3" a fun film to watch over and over.
Despite its budget and other shortcomings, Mad Max is still worth watching and worth adding to the post-apocalyptic section of your home video collection.
Moulin Rouge! is a movie that works hard to earn that exclamation point after it.

I also love it when a plan comes together, but as well-intentioned as this film might be, 'The A-Team' never gels for me. It's so awash in constant action that it takes all the fun of the characters right out of it.
The dance numbers are high octane, and the characters are likable enough to make us want to hang with them through a plot we've seen so many times before it's like movie muscle memory takes over.
Painful as it is to watch, "Rabbit Hole" engages you, imploring you to care about the characters and think about how complex the human psyche can be.
Casting two lookalikes and coaching your young actors to mimic the trio from 'Twilight' isn't enough to make for a great parody.
A highly enjoyable, breezy action film. Cruise and Diaz are fun to watch.
A warm, funny and irreverent Christmas movie that ought to become a holiday classic alongside films like 'Elf' and 'A Christmas Story.'
The nature scenes are nothing short of magical in this film.
Well-paced and full of anecdotal information, clips from the brothers' movies, and interviews with people who worked with them . . . . It's rich with history, and not just personal history.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Servillo carries the film with his very capable performance, and the cinematography and scenery make it visually interesting. If only the ending packed a little more punch.
movie_title: La Ragazza del lago (The Girl by the Lake) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is the 'untold story.' And apparently there's not much more to tell.
It may be the scariest, but it's also one of the strongest in the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Sorcerer's Apprentice is a great family film that packs PG-13 excitement into a PG-rated film.
This film merits both a lump of coal and a candy cane for its mixed results.
Captures the spirit of the Beverly Cleary books and offers a Ramona who's a believable combination of mischief and innocence.
The 1951 Alastair Sim version still ranks as the Number 1 Christmas Carol, but this mo-cap CGI animated version comes in a close second.
Lisbeth is as much of a scourge as Clint Eastwood's Man with No Name, and just as mysterious, cool, and resilient.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Sound of Music has one of Rodgers and Hammerstein's best scores, and that's saying something. It's a warm and wonderful movie that has "timeless" written all over it.
Luhrmann would use the same techniques with better results in Moulin Rouge!
Restrepo comes closest of any film I've seen to fully suggesting what being a soldier is like.
Watch this film and you won't drink another bottle of water.
A fascinating film that shows us just how crazy we are for even trying to answer the big questions.
The weakest entry in the Lonesome Dove series, redeemed only by some Emmy-nominated cinematography . . . and some decent acting.
What's not to like about alien leeches that attack the brain and turn people into zombies?
With the always edgy, slightly demonic, and predictably unpredictable Jack Nicholson as the wolf man, it actually works . . . almost.

This TV adaptation isn't the best that fantasy has to offer, partly because the situations become less believable the farther we get from the main characters. But we've seen much worse on television, and the series is well produced.
O'Horten won't be for everyone, but if you enjoy character-driven films that also treat the landscape as a character, this one has a certain charm and appeal.
I'm inclined to give it an 8 now. The more you watch, the more you appreciate how Branagh was able to faithfully retell Shelley's novel while still managing to make it fresh and make it relevant.

The Proposal doesn't blaze any new ground, but it doesn't raze any old ground either. It's a solid, old-fashioned romantic comedy that's more interested in the romance than in being silly or raunchy. These days, that's refreshing enough.
Great movie, great treatment, but if you're particular about your collection, know that the combo pack is available in both DVD and Blu-ray packaging.
movie_title: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)

movie_review_blurb: This one is destined to take its place alongside films like Evan Almighty and Wholly Moses!.
This time, Disney created a "world." From the magical opening sequence that shows fairies helping animals prepare for winter and ripening corn, you know you're in for some stunning animation.
movie_title: Tinker Bell and the Lost Treasure (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You come away from it wishing there were more laugh-out-loud moments, a little less contrivance, and more enthusiasm curbed.
Henson's vision and the wonderful bag of puppetry tricks he turns to are enough to make "Labyrinth" a winner.
Kendrick needs to learn that didacticism isn't a film aesthetic.
Despite it's tonal split personality, Iron Monkey is a fun Hong Kong martial arts action-comedy that offers a heck of a climax.
Zatoichi is a bloody film that also manages to be beautiful and funny.

Anita Mui all but pulls a heist herself in every scene she's in, but make no mistake. This is Chan's movie, and he holds his own, whether it's using his comedic talents to feign drunkenness or strike a goofy face, or showing off those impressive martial a
movie_title: The Legend of Drunken Master (Jui kuen II) (Drunken Fist II) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Sam Raimi does a lot of interesting things in The Quick and the Dead and Sharon Stone plays a convincing female gunfighter, but the one-horse plot with no subplots to generate additional interest becomes a drag.
Easy Virtue makes subtle comedy look easy. The ensemble is brilliant, and Noel Coward's play-brought-to-film is just good enough . . . .
It's Disney, and it has magic in it, but for me it's a stretch to call the film 'magical.'
The Muppets are back in near-top form this outing, buoyed by the energetic performances of their human special guest stars.
movie_title: Letters to Santa: A Muppets Christmas (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe "Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps" doesn't pack the punch of the original because there's no revelation.
More than anything else, the thing that gives Easy Rider its legendary status is that it's an indie film that became the spokesperson for a decade when Hollywood was preoccupied with other concerns.
Frears does a fine job of capturing the look of turn-of-the-century France, as well as the essence of Colette's story.
The performances are strong--even the minor characters--and the atmosphere and tone are spot-on for a dark comedy.
A stylish mystery that both conforms to the genre and departs from it in interesting ways.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A great family film, with just the right measures of action, mythological allusions, humor, and adventure.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Crazy deserves a place alongside such films as Walk the Line and Crazy Heart.
Predictability ultimately hurts it, while the creature itself and the battles and special effects save the day.
Despite its flaws, there's something likeable about The Mini. . . . If I were to run afoul of the law and the judge ordered me to watch the same movie for a year, I'd choose The Mini over Clerks.
Pattinson broods the whole time in this only okay film.
A hypnotic journey through the world of The Doors that chronicles their meteoric rise and fall in memorable fashion, using original footage.
Like the dancers themselves, this documentary has heart.
Beneath the Vegas glitz beats the heart of a cheap B-movie porno in Showgirls, a movie that truly is so bad it's funny.
When I saw the trailer for When in Rome I laughed like crazy. I wish the movie were as funny.
For a teen film, StarStruck has great music, a solid romantic-comedy backbone, and decent performances. Only the illogical moments and shortcuts keep it from being an unqualified success.
A fun film with awesome visual design. I think that over time detractors will mellow and Burton's Alice will become a classic. Bandersnatches and Futterwackens not withstanding.
A solid film that reminds us of how America is perceived throughout the world, and what a loss it was that director Nemescu died so young.
I was completely caught up in this gritty Western.
Toy Story 3 has an extremely tough act to follow.
Though some of the animation seems dated compared to later Pixar efforts and not nearly as detailed, what's here is done impeccably well.

A stylish film with a solid cast and equally solid acting. But it feels like an exercise film, the kind of filmic monologue one might produce for an assignment not unlike the story that the young hero concocts.
I can't remember seeing an animated feature so dark and funny and bizarre and sad, all at the same time.
Everything about this film is painfully familiar, except, perhaps, for the vicious-but-comic catfight between Latifah and Missi Pyle, who plays a high-society gold digger.

The first act may be a little slow, but once this animated comedy gets rolling, it's a rollicking good family movie with upbeat messages and a happy ending-with enough eye-popping peril to interest even the most jaded of your teen video gameplayers.
There are better action comedies out there.
Small children might find their antics funny, but those who remember the Rascals will see hit-or-miss moments that either capture the spirit and characters or miss the mark entirely.
movie_title: The Little Rascals Save the Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The problem isn't the animation, which has been accomplished and, at times, jaw-dropping. It's the concepts and the writing.

Hanks, as a stranger in a strange land, gives us equal portions of laughs and insights into the worlds of both adults and adolescents. Big also offers up a very funny satire of corporate ladder climbing.

Disney animators had fun with this one, coloring mostly within the lines of the Pixie Hollow movies but slipping outrageously outside the margins every now and then as they offer a rollicking prequel to Peter Pan.
Mattel-Universal has gone to the well way to many times for a mermaid-themed Barbie movie, and The Pearl Princess feels trapped at the bottom, mired in repetition and sameness.
With a few distorted facts, Saving Mr. Banks takes on a life of its own, and there's enough truth in it to make you swallow the rest . . . with or without a spoonful of sugar.

The characters giggle too much (as hyper-cute Saturday morning animated offerings will do), the music isn't as well integrated into the story, and the humans come across like an Indian version of The Cosby Show.
Given the strength of animation, the memorable characters, and a killer soundtrack ... it may well be one of Disney's most accomplished animated features from the past 20 years.
There's more action this time around, and less deliberate manipulation of the Marvel universe. The result is a film that flows better and gives the characters a little more room to be themselves.

The plot and pacing may be nearly as lazy as the sloth bear Baloo (Phil Harris), but animators use that to their advantage, developing the characters so that even minor ones seem majorly entertaining.
To enjoy Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 you'll need to relax and just enjoy the colors and creative visuals. The animation is eye-popping and the menagerie of food critters is truly inventive.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Almost from the beginning it's structured like a chess match between Phillips and a Somali pirate (Barkhad Abdi as Abduwali Muse) who feels pressured to make a big score.

...remains faithful to the spirit of the Peanuts world, choosing to surprise viewers not with twists or deviations, but with the clever rendering of familiar elements from the Peanuts gang repertoire...

Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters is a good special effects family movie that's every bit as accomplished as The Lightning Thief and possibly better-even if it doesn't follow the Rick Riordan juvenile fantasy novels like a road map.

While there is much good to say about this outrageous reboot of The Lone Ranger, there are also flaws that keep it from being totally successful, starting with a frame story that just doesn't make sense.
Van Dyke and Andrews have great chemistry together, but it's really her interaction with the children and the magic of the story and the visual effects that charm audiences.

The pacing is fine but the dialogue is trite. Older children and adults will also find the main plot and Smurf gibberish tedious, redeemed only by Azaria's performance and a sideplot involving Gargamel.
Teenage role models for little girls aren't all that easy to come by, so it's easy to overlook a cultivated wholesomeness when the underlying message is so positive.
Somehow, out of a no-win situation, Stiller manages to make a likable movie that entertains while also providing a little get-out-of-the-basement inspiration.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Aimed mostly at girls ages six through 16. But the acting is solid, the trick riding captivating, and the situation interesting enough to where it might appeal to the whole family.
The second half of the film it's especially fun watching this Australian roughneck deal with local customs, traffic jams, subways, streetlights, and a rival for Sue's attention-her boss.
This winning indie comedy-drama splits those two genres as neatly as an atom but gets the most energy out of the comedy side.
For a comedy of manners, The Philadelphia Story is awfully screwball.

Shedd and Foster play with the reality that viewers experience -- a reality that changes right before our eyes. It's almost magical. Unfortunately, the plot twists and turns aren't nearly as effective as the stylistic ones.
Apocalypse Child is a wonderful slice-of-life drama that thrives in the space between truth and fiction. It's enriched by layers of nuance and made memorable by the characters themselves.
The King of New Orleans is most successful when it sticks to understated narratives and small moments.
Sexual orientation aside, it's the kind of film that can have you looking past family member faults and focusing on what's important.

The Bond films never feel dated, and neither does Agent Cody Banks. It still plays well, and for that credit the special effects that compare favorably to today's films and the fact that high school never seems to change.
Fifteen years after Zoolander . . . Zoolander No. 2 feels like an uninspired knockoff rushed into production to take advantage of the first film's popularity.

Turbo is much stronger than Disney's Planes, and while parents may wonder if it's the right message to send youngsters that no dream is too big for the dreamer, Turbo is still a solid pick for family movie night.

While critics have taken this WWII-era film to task for its blatant historical inaccuracies and eyebrow-raising plot, I feel compelled to say, Relax. This isn't The King's Speech. It's Adventures in Babysitting meets Roman Holiday.

Though Nine to Five played out as an ensemble film, The Other Woman is totally taken over by Mann, who swipes every scene with her hilariously sympathetic portrayal of a needy, ditzy, and slightly manic wife.
The characters are engaging, and the film is about things that concern young girls: getting along with friends, frenemies and siblings; building confidence; and working hard to make dreams come true.
movie_title: American Girl: Isabelle Dances into the Spotlight (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If Rio showed that 20th Century Fox Animation had finally moved into Disney's neighborhood, with Rio 2 they've taken off their shoes and propped their feet up on the coffee table.

Infusing Noah's story, however fictional or true you believe it to be, with the kind of rock creatures we saw in GalaxyQuest is like trying to tell the story of Geronimo with an E.T.-like alien turning up in the Apache desert to offer his assistance.
Along with Pillow Talk it's one of Doris Day's most delightful and enduring romantic comedies, and the kids get a two-for, since she's paired with pop culture icon Clark Gable.

A fun lightweight adventure, one of the better Cary Grant films, and a darned good "starter" romantic comedy because of all the other distractions and a world that threatens to tear this couple apart before they can even come together.

A curious blend of charm and tooth-obsessed strangeness, with a wholesome message about friendship that's somewhat tainted by the characters' Butch and Sundance antics, but illustrated in a gentle style with wonderfully subtle-yet-vibrant music.
There are three types of people who will go for Sophia Grace & Rosie's Royal Adventure: people who are charmed by the duo's YouTube videos, fans of Toddlers & Tiaras, and Ellen DeGeneres.
movie_title: Sophia Grace and Rosie's Royal Adventure (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A trio of writers led by Lawrence Kasdan put the fun and fast-paced serial adventure back into Luke Skywalker's galaxy, and, just as importantly they give us new characters that we care about.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Bond on valium? This game of Hopscotch is a low-key but entertaining affair.
Man of Steel chooses breakneck speed over character development, and there are times when everyone in the room will be looking at each other to see if anyone is following what's happening.

There's not much in the way of character development, and the acting, though competent, isn't a selling point. The special effects are decent, but not incredible. If you buy "Chronicle," it's because of the concept itself.

It's a clever variation on the buddy cop picture, with Jackie Chan showing both his comic chops and his martial arts skills, and Owen Wilson doing what he does best-playing a laid-back, chick-magnet California surfer dude.
...so many similarities [to The Lion King] you begin to wonder how they got away with it.
It's a wonder narrator Meryl Streep didn't put herself to sleep, the lines are so pedestrian and the delivery so very, very somnolent.
Call it a sanitized version of The Commitments.

Even when you think you know the outcome, this film still has you on the edge of your seat. It's another underdog story, only this underdog is a has-been robot piloted by a has-been fighter and his cast-off son.
The plot is a hokey, muddled mess about a young falcon who wants to go to a fabled city of Zambezia, where all birds live in harmony and under the protection of the Blue Falcons...

The Sandlot is just a fun, funny film that holds plenty of family appeal because it has a wholesome Norman Rockwell vibe and, as with any good sports film, you don't have to love the game to love the film.
...children, like the adults, may be fascinated by the historical details that Spielberg includes, for Lincoln oozes authenticity.
...the whole plot can be confusing to people who aren't somewhat familiar with the different ballets.
There's plenty of action here, as George ends up canoeing (bad idea, right?), skateboarding, swinging, frolicking, and running into all sorts of animals.
Helen Mirren is perfectly cast as Hitchcock's wife Alma, with whom he often collaborated.
"Life of Pi" isn't just a visual effects movie stuck at sea. There's a compelling story here as well.
Disney animation depends on captivating music, powerful villains, and effective comic relief, and Mulan has all three.
It's clever, but manic. Watching Who Framed Roger Rabbit is like spending a weekend locked in a room with the looniest Looney Tunes characters.
Some cheesy moments (is there a '70s movie that escaped them?) date the film, but Westworld is a fun futuristic thriller.
As my wife put it, The Hunchback of Notre Dame is "too dark and too dirty for kids."

Wreck-It Ralph plays out a little like a screwball comedy, with Vanellope absolutely vexing Ralph because of her energy, her enthusiasm, and her wide-eyed naiveté, with Ralph coming around as reluctantly as Cary Grant in Bringing Up Baby.

It may not be as compelling and tightly edited as Ben-Hur, but Cleopatra is still a Hollywood epic that tells a grand story in a grand way. Save it for a night when the family feels like a four-hour spectacle.

Ohana means family, and family in this fun and feisty 2002 animated Disney feature means a little Hawaiian girl, her caretaker sister, the sister's boyfriend, and a mutated monster of an alien that little Lilo adopts, thinking he's a dog.
Our little science-minded guy was hooked, and it's easy to see why. It's the kind of film Disney usually produces as a live-action blockbuster.
The Emperor's New Groove is a little sassier, a little hipper, and maybe just a little crazier-as if the cartoon cast drank some of the old Warner Bros. Kool-Aid.
The Little Mermaid launched what could only be called a second Golden Age for Disney.

Iron Man 3 soars above first sequel and might even rival the 2008 debut for overall entertainment value. You laugh, you sit on the edge of your seat, and you marvel (yes, Marvel) at some of the visual effects.

His Majesty O'Keefe was intended as a follow-up to Lancaster's 1952 huge hit, The Crimson Pirate, but the pirate flick has more acrobatics, more humor, more rousing music, and a narrative that seems somehow more crisply paced.
Disney has made a number of features by cobbling together shorter stories, but none more cleverly and successfully than this one.
movie_title: Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe this was a film that didn't need to be made, but parents with small children will be glad that Disney did, because it's a kinder, gentler trip to Never Land than the original, and a much safer bet for young children.

The film's chief strength lies in its depiction of a new and exotic world and appreciating how Fox animators envisioned and created such a world. Epic is epically gorgeous in its art design and animation.
The action picks up in the third act, but by then most young viewers-even the readers among them-may have already lost patience.
The film's strength is its visual style and Luhrmann's daring high-wire act.
It's like an animated Revenge of the Nerds, but without the vulgarity and compromising situations.
All the road trip conventions are here, but the fun is in the puppetry, the puns, the sight gags, the interaction between Muppets and humans, and the exceptional music.
To a degree, Shane employs the good-guy/bad-guy stereotypes that characterize Westerns. But it's more complex than that.

At just 74 minutes, Oliver and Company is one of the shortest full-length features from Disney, but there's a lot packed into it. While no one will ever mistake Oliver and Company for one of the Disney's golden oldies, it's still doggone entertaining.
Without The King, Love Me Tender is a decent horse opera that has more stand-and-talk moments than shoot-'em-ups....But Elvis really does add interest.
...a movie about Arthurian legend that had the misfortune of being released on December 25, just a month after America's version of Camelot died with President John F. Kennedy.
For all its flaws, Greystoke is still better than the romanticized live-action versions of Tarzan that Hollywood has produced.
movie_title: Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes (1984)

movie_review_blurb: It's about as original as two kids meeting on summer vacation and finding adventure together. But The Dragon Pearl has solid enough execution to make it enjoyable anyway.
Simon's The Odd Couple is proof that smart writing and adult themes can still make for a fun evening at your family home theater, if your children are older than 10.

Disney spent more than $200 million on this special effects film, and while the pacing and the visuals captivate, it's really James Franco's performance as the Wizard and an abundance of allusions to the 1939 classic that make it fun.
Of all the animated Disney movies from the '70s, Robin Hood had perhaps the most potential, but suffers from a mild case of "averageitis."
Harry may be tough, but in Curtiz' hands he's basically a nice guy in noirland.
Though Face 2 Face can't break free of its contrivances, viewers still somehow find themselves unable to turn away.
Because Frantz is 99.9 percent domestic, ponderously paced, shot in black and white . . . it plays like a film version of an Anton Chekhov short story.

Deepwater Horizon is pretty solid, with a cast that bridges three generations of moviegoers. Though disaster movies are all about the action and special effects, they still depend on actors to 'sell' the disaster.

Queen of Katwe isn't your typical feel-good Disney movie or biopic, but that's another strength. With winning performances by the two stars and young Nalwanga, it's the kind of film that sticks with you.
Both a classic and underrated Disney film, if that's possible.
There's no denying that the work Lorius does is fascinating science, unless you're a U.S. politician who denounces anything that gets in the way of the economy. But it's not very compelling as drama.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Is it as good as the first two films? No. But because of the formula there are still pleasures to be had, and director Howard does a good job of integrating the medieval images and keeping viewers off-balance.
A G-rated inspirational film that has a lot going for it: exotic setting, gorgeous cinematography, a likable teenage protagonist, a special father-daughter bond, and a natural dramatic arc.

It's not exactly a caterpillar-to-butterfly tale. More like a grub to a beetle--a different kind of coming of age story, yet one that's oh so familiar as Nadine learns to appreciate the people right there at arm's reach.
Benedict Cumberbatch might not fit the leading man profile, but he wears the Doctor Strange uniform well.
The first third of this film can seem like a downer, but the performances are absorbing and in no time at all it takes an inspirational, feel-good turn.

I didn't think it possible, but in terms of looks, Moana finds a comfortable middle ground between traditional animation and 3D CGI animation . . . with a story that features Disney's strongest female hero to date.
If this were live-action, I think it would be a yawner. Even Glee had more plotting. But the animation sells it and makes it entertaining for all ages, despite the tired premise.

If you're no big fan of message films . . . or contrived plots . . . or melodramas where you know the whole point of a film is to make viewers feel something, then you probably won't care too much for this 2016 drama.
Anyone unconvinced that J.K. Rowling is a brilliant storyteller needs to see Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This most recent and faithful adaptation does the most spectacular job of exploiting the scenery and Heidi's natural capacity for unbridled joy.
It's all pretty formulaic and the characters are stock types that we've seen many times before.
Can I just say that I liked Rogue One: A Star Wars Story better than the last four Star Wars stories--even The Force Awakens, which was the top grossing film of 2015?
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest problem with A Cowgirl's Story is that everything is too far-fetched, familiar, or unbelievably easy.
As tension builds inside the pilot who made headlines . . . so does the tension build in this film by director Clint Eastwood. Before you know it, you're wrapped up in the drama....
Trace Adkins looks like a character you'd see in the Old West, but he's not much of an actor. Neither are some of the others who mouth poorly written lines or chew scenery....
While the birds in the film take flight, the film itself never really gets too high off the ground....
Suicide Squad isn't as fun of a ride as Guardians of the Galaxy. It could have been, with more performances like Jared Leto's and Margot Robbie's....
Using documentary-style interviewing techniques and three narrators, Konchalovsky's work brings to mind well-known literary naturalists like Jack London and Stephen Crane.
A solid sequel that's as glitzy and stylish as the first--even though it may be a little harder to figure out.
It's a little bit of a stretch to accept 57-year-old Ball and 63-year-old Fonda as fertile parents, but they still make for believable parents once you get over the initial shock.
Compared to other Westerns, Johnny Guitar is high art--richly atmospheric and with noir elements that will remind viewers of such dramatic films as Key Largo.
Hart and Johnson actually pair up nicely, and Central Intelligence is a fun action-comedy largely because of their antics and the chemistry that they manage.

There is no 'intense rivalry' between girls, and the 'underdog tale' never has a chance to wag because the girl's injury seems so slight and such a non-factor. Plus, this made-for-TV movie is clearly aimed at a younger audience.

The MacLaine-Lange pairing is good but not great, though I'd be hard-pressed to tell you exactly why. Maybe it's because you don't feel any depth to their friendship, and they're supposed to be best friends.
This formulaic, straight-as-the-crow-flies romantic comedy can feel plodding and downright dull at times....
If you isolate the performances and compare them to baseball cards, there isn't a dud destined to be traded or clipped to the spokes of a bicycle wheel.

If all you require of a horror-thriller is that it scares you, then Lights Out does the trick. If you need it to make complete sense, well, it's not here. But hey, that's the world of the supernatural. As with magic, do you really want to know everything?
Adds a nice infusion of originality and energy into an old, familiar story....
A great first nature film to introduce children to, and even those who don't respond well to the survival-of-the-fittest world of nature films will find this a welcome change of pace....
If you remove the hokum--the overly obvious and period-wholesome nonsense that frames the main narrative--Suddenly is a taut thriller in the Key Largo mold.
There isn't a scene that needs work or a concept that wsn't sufficiently milked for laughs or another emotion....
Hollywood legend Tony Curtis gives one of his best performances in Houdini, a colorful biography set in the 1890s through 1920s, and he does it playing opposite his then-wife Janet Leigh....

Take away the over-the-top sequences and you'd probably have a tamer feature that wouldn't engage children as much; add them and adults roll their eyes. But at least the adults can appreciate the superbly animated sequences and pet-owner touchstones.
What Pete's Dragon lacks in originality it makes up for in visual and special effects....second-tier Disney, but I suspect it will be viewed as an underrated film as time goes by.
The kind of film you appreciate for its technical wizardry but maybe don't like as much as you think you should....
Apocalypse proceeds so confidently that you feel assured that it all fits together and makes perfect sense, even if you're not getting it in the instant.
A solid thriller right up until the end, when the director decides to play to his fans and his own indulgences, rather than tying things up for viewers in a more satisfying way.
La La Land is a bit like its Oscar-winning song, City of Stars: it may seem slight, but in the end, it's the little things you remember most.

From a critic's perspective, A Mermaid's Tale is a C- at best. But young Caitlin Carmichael is likable as the female lead and the playful relationship she has with her father plus surprisingly good production values helps a little.

Matthau and May are the main reason to watch this film, as they make the most of every scene with nuanced mannerisms and reactions. Compared to today's comedies, this one feels less contrived and more leisurely paced.
The action is non-stop, the jokes (though aimed a little lower than usual) are rapid-fire, and the Lego world of bright colors and mechs and machines is something that Lego fans can enjoy.

Pilgrimage is an average movie with above-average atmosphere and cinematography, thanks largely to the Irish landscapes where it was mostly filmed. It's also a movie that plods along into eye-rolling territory . . . .
It's the Salazar show, and Javier Bardem does a good job of bringing him to life--even if his appearance seems to be inspired by Alice Cooper or Edward Scissorhands. . . .
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A thought-provoking drama that's worth watching if for no other reason than to be aware of this culturally significant film. It did, after all, give us the name 'Shangri-La,' which has since become synonymous with a utopian paradise on earth.
That rowing scene? It's the equivalent of watching a ventriloquist work his dummy while drinking a glass of water. Such technical wizardry abounds in Emmet Otter's Jug-Band Christmas.

There's very little in this film that you haven't already seen in other boxing films, but O'Connor and his cast and crew really put together a sports drama that's every bit as gripping as Rocky, and they manage to do so within the bounds of a PG-13 film.

A powerful film that falls somewhere between the spontaneity and anti-establishment defiance of Captain Fantastic and the fierce independence and tough love amid squalor of Beasts of the Southern Wild.

Nolan employs minimal dialogue and in media res camerawork to plunk the viewer right into the thick of things so you feel like you're experiencing the chaos of war and the reactive drive to escape it.

The Miracle Worker structurally has much in common with a Western. The plot turns on a stranger who comes to town, confronts a problem the townspeople cannot solve, and leaves when that problem has been addressed.
For the first 15 minutes or so Cars 3 seems like a dash-for-the-cash affair. Then Disney does what they do best: they get viewers emotionally involved with the characters.
How much you enjoy Despicable Me 3 may depend on how much you like Gru's 'minions'--those capsule-shaped little guys in blue overalls that speak in their own gibberish language.

The cover makes it look like a telenovela . . . but this film by legendary Mexican director Arturo Ripstein has more in common with classic, tense psychological Westerns like High Noon and the original 3:10 to Yuma.

First-time full-length feature director Samir Oliveros knows how to tell a good story and doesn't allow his auteurist impulses to get in the way. A few artistic shots here and there feel like just the right amount. . . .
Viewers who notice such things will find it extra creepy or clever or both that It returns 27 years after that first 1990 TV adaptation . . . .

Nowar uses the Wadi Rum setting in much the same way as American director John Ford used Monument Valley: as an iconic symbol, but also as such a dominant presence that it takes on the importance of character . . . .

Blade Runner fans will love every minute of this homage and its richly imagined futuristic world, but younger viewers who are more into Gosling than they are sci-fi will find the beginning slow-going. . . .
If Hollywood is the dream factory, Demy's The Young Girls of Rochefort is one heck of a factory knock-off. And being French, it has an oblique ending that also seems to have influenced [La La Land].
movie_title: The Young Girls of Rochefort (Les Demoiselles de Rochefort) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: The problem . . . as is so often the case with non-Disney animated features, is the concept itself--and that includes a live-action 'frame' that seems gratuitous, even clunky.
Skyfall gets off to a fast start. I can't recall when I've enjoyed a pre-title sequence more.

A strong entry in the comic-book superhero action film genre, with a plot that's compelling without being confusing, great special effects, strong villains, some inspirational 'girl power' scenes, crisp pacing....
By balancing comedy and drama and focusing on real solutions to real problems, Lee creates a film that pulses with the feeling of real life.
Funny, clever, action-packed, and rocking with music and kaleidoscopic graphics, but it's the underlying messages that make it a great family film.

Our family watched Beauty and the Beast separately . . . but we all had the same reaction: We loved it. Disney excels in creating movie worlds, and to create this one they decided against straight live-action and incorporated 1700 visual effects.
Like most comedies from the fifties, Money from Home is corny and depends on sight gags, slapstick, and a few good one-liners . . . but you find yourself getting caught up in the action.

If only the filmmakers decided to be more ambitious and plant a few things for older family members to enjoy . . . or work with a familiar narrative framework so part of the fun is watching the variation unfold.
One of the film's strengths is that we hear the poems read in voiceover after an event that likely inspired them, or at least is thematically compatible.

Though not as funny as Road to Morocco and Road to Utopia, this 91-minute comedy is a good place to start for families with younger children because it is color and because Road to Bali is a kitchen sink film.
There's something in The Lemon Drop Kid that's endearing enough to make it a nice alternative to the usual Christmas movies....
Best. Kong. Ever.
The acting is bad, the cheerleading acrobatics take a backseat to online insults, and the characters are so cardboard you could knock them over with a little finger or hearty belch.
The second half is entertaining enough, the three stars and Ann-Margaret are endearing, and the situation is one that many Americans can identify with, no matter what political party they support.
This 2015 documentary from Quino Piñero could very well do for traditional music from Ethiopia what Buena Vista Social Club did for Cuban music and musicians.
The premise is a fun riff on Mark Twain's The Prince and the Pauper.... but there's enough here to make the formula different and entertaining enough, even for contemporary families.
There are some absolutely marvelous sequences, but because confusion reigns with an even tighter fist, you don't have enough context to really appreciate what's happening.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If it seems plot-starved (and it does), that's because it's basically an expansion of the popular story song....
More contrived than organic....
A great documentary for families!
movie_title: With Great Power: The Stan Lee Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Castle-Hughes' performance is so amazing and she plays off of the veteran Maori actors so well it's hard to believe she was plucked from her classroom when a film crew came by looking for a non-actor....
Dialogue is just as crisp, the visual look of the film and CGI effects are just as eye-popping, and the characters' personalities may shine even more brightly in this sequel.
A tense and satisfying Western. But you do have to check your realistic expectations at the door.
It's funny, the characters are endearing, the monster world is cleverly developed, and the Pixar gang really has fun with this one.
Much better than you'd expect for a film that did not do well at the box office in China and drew a 39 percent 'rotten' rating at Rotten Tomatoes.
Like Tom Hanks before him and Leonardo DiCaprio, Damon doesn't shrink from the burden of being alone onscreen for so much of the film-he owns it....
The first "Ice Age" is still the best, but as fabricated and Saturday morning as this installment is, it's still an accomplished bit of animated filmmaking.

"Halo 4: Forward unto Dawn" may have had a goal of broadening the audience beyond gamers, but the film is so close to watching a video game for the second action-filled half and the set-up so pedestrian that I don't see non-gamers becoming fans.
A throwback to the early Disney live-action films that coasted on their premises and were content to provide lightweight entertainment and nothing more.
Really the lifestyle of these people takes center stage. It's hard not to appreciate their joie de vivre, or the believable performances these non-actors give. They're both "beasts"!
"Dick Tracy" isn't in the top tier of comic-book adaptations, but ingenuous art direction and set decoration and some crazy make-up jobs create a film that's still a delight to watch.
For some, the message of "The Odd Life of Timothy Green" will be rewarding enough. I wanted more complexity, and less melodrama and movie-of-the-week messaging.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "MIB 3" doesn't have the same see-it-for-the-first-time magic that the original had, and tonally, with Boris, it's a totally different animal. But it's just as strong of a film.
The humor is light (and light-headed)-so much so that you'd have to say it's a stoner movie with no pot.

Detail is what holds your attention from frame to frame: the panorama of soft and hard corals, the different textured sea bottoms, the undulating seaweed, and the schooling sardines that look flashy and real as can be.
Under Nunn ("Cats," "Les Misérables"), the story takes a much darker turn and, surprisingly, makes more sense in the process.
It may be directed by the pair that gave us "Little Miss Sunshine," but what makes this one work is writer Zoe Kazan, who doubles as the female lead.
The late Jim Henson would have been proud of the job that his son did directing this production. It's a solid Muppets feature. Call it "The Muppets Take Dickensian London."
A terrific documentary that entertains and informs in equal measure.

"The Amazing Spider-Man" isn't as dramatically revisionist as Christopher Nolan's "Batman Begins," but it's as good as Raimi's first "Spider-Man" film and darker, while still being tongue-in-cheek. That's a tough tone to master.

It may be legend, and it may be romanticized, but "Lawrence of Arabia" feels authentic. It's as stirring an epic as Hollywood has ever produced-one reason why the American Film Institute has named it the Number 1 epic of all time.

"Brave" is the first foray in fairytale storytelling for "Pixar," and their first contribution to the growing pantheon of Disney princesses. It works so well that we can safely assume that it won't be the last fairytale coming out of Emeryville.
"Company" feels as magical as theater often does while you're in the midst of watching it. It's only upon reflection and by comparison to other musicals that it tends to suffer.
An audience of preschoolers and kindergarteners should still appreciate this colorful Disney film, and curious parents might enjoy seeing certain actors at work.
Visually, the 2012 remake is better than the original, with interesting set and background designs, decent enough futuristic vehicles, and superb special effects. The plot is another story.

If you can get past the the pacing, the length, and the occasional melodrama, "The Joy Luck Club" rewards on two levels: as a look at Asian-American and Asian culture, and as a consideration of the dynamics that shape mother-daughter relationships.
With "Dog Days" and its been-there, done-that screenplay, the franchise takes a step backward.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I never felt that I was wasting my time watching 'Brubaker,' only that it could have been a more dramatic and taut prison movie-which is odd, because it's directed by Stuart Rosenberg ('Cool Hand Luke').

"Viva Zapata!" is one of those films that, while it continues to have impressive aspects, just doesn't hold up as well as it did when it was first made. You find yourself wishing it were in widescreen, and that they had hired at least ONE Latino actor.
Without Robin Williams, 'One Hour Photo' is just another predictable B movie thriller. He's like that slow train wreck, personified, that people can't seem to take their eyes off.
'Adventures in Zambezia' tries to fly high, but struggles to get off the ground.
Audiard crafts a film with logical scenic construction yet surprising turns of events, with the drama never devolving into melodrama.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Rotten Tomatoes notes that I agree with Tomatometer critics 80 percent of the time, but this is one of those times I have to part ways with them.
Hopkins' performance makes "Hitchcock" as much fun as one of the old episodes from "Alfred Hitchcock Presents."
I'm going to give it a seven because of the two stars. They're so darned likable that they make the film's shortcomings seem unimportant.
...solid sci-fi entertainment that does what all good fiction attempts: it appeals to more than its intended audience...
Without getting into spoilers, can I just say how refreshing it was to watch a film about a physically challenged person that didn't end on a total downer?
A lightweight action-comedy that only tries to entertain, but at least it meets that modest goal. And it knocks out lighter weight comedies like The School of Rock.
Though it seems derivative at times, it's offbeat, it's violent, it's well written, and it's well acted.
Years later it's still a treasure, because of Disney and his artists' talent for creating memorable characters.
As a documentary, "Searching for Sugar Man" falls short, but as an enormously satisfying feel-good story it hits the mark.

There's a good chance that children under 10 will find "Hotel Transylvania" entertaining, because it's as non-threatening as can be and the jokes are obvious. There's an equally good chance that everyone else will wander off . . .
Religion may permeate this film, but it does so because it permeates the characters' lives. "The Wise Kids" features some nice surprises and some solid acting and editing.
"Frankenweenie" isn't Burton's best work, but it's still a solid outing for the strange, death-obsessed director.
It's goofy and it smacks of B-movie dynamics, but Duccio Tessari's "Zorro" is still an entertaining film.
"Babar: The Movie" feels like a film in search of an audience.
I've seen better concert videos and I've seen better music documentaries. This one is for diehard Neil Young fans.
Even if parents may be stung by the narrative logic, "Secret of the Wings" is still a wonderful sensory experience to share with your child.
Artfully designed with special effects that border on the elegant-there's no other way to put it-"Prometheus" is a visual delight.
It all comes down to what it often does: a dumb concept, an uninspired plot, and characters we never grow to care about, much less love.
"Under the Tuscan Sun" is an amiable film that, in the tradition of escapist fiction, provides a nice, scenic getaway with just enough drama to keep the story from getting stagnant.
Given the amazing artwork, if a better character [than a cyborg John Silver] had been inserted, we'd be talking about "Treasure Planet" as another Disney classic.
Quill is a drama that feels like a documentary . . . or vice versa. And that makes it kind of a strange animal.
movie_title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Faith, serenity, dreams, possibilities, duty and honor, love . . . and fishing. "Salmon Fishing in the Yemen" somehow ties them all together, and without so much as a kink in the line.

Like "Little Miss Sunshine," this quirky indie comedy chugs along at an amiable pace, and with the same sort of dysfunctional family humor. It's not as successful as that film, but only because it's not as complex.
It's entertaining and at times even insightful, but nowhere near as powerful-or memorable-as "The Hustler."
It's the bartending antics and musical backdrops that make the film entertaining. Without them, "Cocktail" is just another beer gone flat.

Despite some strong production values and performances, the sepia-toned saga ends up being more routine than standout, and more curious than compelling. It feels like something that could have been much more.
"The Decoy Bride" doesn't offer anything truly original, but as romantic comedies go it makes for a pleasant enough evening. And if you're like me, the scenery is a bonus.
I'm not sure how much replay this film will get, but a first viewing is awfully satisfying-though it makes the audience work a little harder than they're accustomed.

Webber's music is hauntingly original and effective, while Rice's lyrics manage to convey the information that's missing without a standard narrative and scenic construction, while also incorporating a constant sense of interpretation.
Bale and the cast are energetic and fun to watch, and the story itself is fascinating history. But the songs and choreography are a disappointment.

Light and fluffy as it is, "Sister Act" still has plenty of laugh-out-loud moments and some warm fuzzies as well as some believable action, and that makes it a 7 out of 10 in my book. But the sequel? It's more like a 5.
For an action comedy, "21 Jump Street" had less action or comedy than I expected. It felt as if I spent too much time waiting for something to happen-either for a joke to fire, or a pistol.
Madonna swears by this guy, and the DVDs prove what the bestselling books cannot: that the calming techniques actually work.
Like so many indie flicks, logic takes a back seat while quirkiness takes a Mr. Toad wild ride through the city.
Save your money. Read "The Devil and Daniel Webster" or "Doctor Faustus." Listen to Robert Johnson. Or just be a decent human being, so you'll never have the devil to pay.
It's never clear what "Mirror Mirror" is saying about the Snow White legend, or about fairy tales in general. It feels like a narrative without a story.

Count me among those who think the Best Actor Oscar that Paul Newman won for "The Color of Money" was a make-up call. The groundwork was laid right here in "The Verdict," and with the equally accomplished "Absence of Malice" a year earlier.
Ultimately, "The Three Stooges: The Movie" isn't funny enough for a comedy, which is too bad, because the three stars really worked hard to nail their characters.
Like "Home Alone," "Adventures in Babysitting" is a lightweight comic adventure, but it's effective in what it sets out to do . . . and that's entertain.

If you like films about travel, if you like watching film legends work together, you might want to check into "The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel." Consummate professionals and some sharp writing and interesting cinematography make it worth the trip.
