"Arachnophobia" is a notch or two above the typical creature horror movie, with solid special effects and a decent story that isn't just one "Boo!" after the other.
"Marvel's The Avengers" is a visual comic book and it doesn't aspire to be anything more than that. As a film version it succeeds-one is tempted to say-MIGHTILY.
I wouldn't call "Ghosts of the Abyss" a compelling documentary or even an artistic one. It's more like a visit to a museum-in this case, one that's 12,500 feet below the surface.

If you liked "Beverly Hills Chihuahua," you'll like this second sequel more than the first. It felt like the filmmakers just tried harder this time around, and that's something I appreciate . . . even in furry fluff like this.
movie_title: Beverly Hills Chihuahua 3: Viva La Fiesta! (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Not nearly as good as previous American Girl films, because without a historical context to divert the writers and director, all that's left is to focus on cheesy feel-good warmth and a formulaic plot.
movie_title: An American Girl: McKenna Shoots For the Stars (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Aardman folks might not have created a pirate film to rival the big screen's best, but they've created a subtle parody of pirate movies that's well worth watching.

This is a movie that all but licks your face and begs you to like it, and you'll find yourself wanting to oblige. But it's just too structured and seems overly concerned with conveying a sense of real time . . .
The music, the chemistry between Houston and Washington, and minor characters that make us smile make this film worth watching-especially around Christmas, when this is set.
A cute, feline version of "Lady and the Tramp" that should enthrall families . . . and, of course, cat lovers.
"Bernie" is a quiet, leisurely paced indie film that's as different as can be from the typical true crime movie.
It still has a direct-to-video feel, despite the care that the filmmakers took to create bridges to the original film.
movie_title: Lady and the Tramp II: Scamp's Adventure (2000)

movie_review_blurb: "Pocahontas" isn't an A-movie in the Disney catalog, but it's a solid second-tier film that, despite its romanticizing of the "noble savage," nonetheless features themes that are wholesome and consistent with Disney's messaging.
Disney finally found a voice for this series, and they did it by going back to what made them successful in the first place.

For John Cusack lovers, "Grosse Pointe Blank" is one of his best, an engaging showcase for his droll demeanor and a seamless blend of comedy and action. It's light entertainment, in spite of the body count.
Kudrow and Sorvino are fun to watch, Garafalo is deliciously acerbic, and the whole Valley Girl reunion thing is a stroke of light-and-fluffy genius.
movie_title: Romy and Michele's High School Reunion (1997)

movie_review_blurb: If these kids did their own singing, they've got bright futures ahead of them.

While the second half is a pleasure, it's the first half that's less impressive. I've seen this deadpan narrator with the bottled-up angst so many times that I looked to the lines and the minor characters to see me through.
It's still a film that has its charms, along with one of the more peculiarly conceived Disney villains.
Just as the main character slowly grows on people in the film, it can draw in reluctant viewers.
Compared to "Midnight in Paris," this homage isn't nearly as sure-footed.
Plummer is phenomenal, but be warned: you really have to like one-person shows in order to enjoy this 84-minute tour de force.
The visuals are memorable, and so are the characters and their moral dilemmas.
Benedict Cumberbatch and Daniel Brühl do a fine job of drawing us into their characters, but because 'The Fifth Estate' is an uneven and sometimes confusing thriller, it's not enough.

'A Chorus Line' will certainly give people who think they want a career in dance some idea of whether they're up to the challenge. And the rest of the audience will never look at a musical chorus line the same way.
Maslany is fantastic as the main character, and there's just enough irony and complexity to make this slice-of-life film seem relevant.
The people and cinematography are compelling, and so, by extension, is this 1962 documentary.
It's fascinating to see a dissenting opinion and wonder where the truth really lies.

A slam-bang action film that's plenty realistic, with a full two-thirds devoted to the battle for survival that ensues when a mission to capture or kill a top Taliban leader goes about as wrong as any mission can go.
If you're not a fan of opera, you probably won't care much for 'Carmen Jones,' despite some pretty solid acting and scenes that bring postwar America to life.
If you can brush aside concerns about historical accuracy (including a 15th century that seems a lot cleaner than you'd expect), 'The White Queen' is a rewarding experience.
A winning comedy that's as leisurely as the Eisenhower years, with just a hint of the rebellion that's coming down the pike.
Of the old-time pirate movies, the top tier may be crowded with films like 'Captain Blood,' 'The Sea Hawk,' and 'The Crimson Pirate.' But 'The Black Swan' ranks just under those.

'The Ghost and Mrs. Muir' easily could have stumbled into melodrama or dramedy. It works as well as it does because of understatement, and it's still a charming and captivating film more than 60 years later.

Jack London's The Call of the Wild has been a difficult book to adapt to film, but this William Wellman-directed entry is still the best. It's probably one of the more interesting films from the first half of the '30s.
'Jesse James' has rich-looking production values and a story to tell that borders on the mythic . . . or the demythologized. In this, the filmmakers couldn't decide.
While the action is decent, the plot is just a little too strained, the dialogue too wooden, and Hudson overmatched in this John Wayne vehicle.
It's not sophisticated enough for older children, but young ones will probably be entertained by 'The Naughty List.'
It might actually be funnier if you haven't seen the first film, but I'm not in a position to say--only that it's disappointingly similar to the original, and suffers from the comparison.
I didn't care, my kids didn't care, and if I had invited the neighbors over to witness this dull flight, they wouldn't have cared either.
I can't in good conscience call this one of John Wayne's best movies, but I have to say that 'North to Alaska' has always been one of my favorites. It's just plain fun.
Griffith's 'Intolerance' was way ahead of its time in terms of its camera angles, sophisticated storytelling, and elaborate set construction. And the restoration and HD treatment makes it shine.

Despite the film's shortcomings, this story of a decade-long affair that poet Elizabeth Bishop had with Brazilian architect Lota de Macedo Soares manages to hold your attention, and largely because of the characters.
These birds are good to look at, and you can easily get caught up in the characters. But the situation is a bit too much to swallow . . . even for Thanksgiving.
"The Adventures of Ichabod Crane" still stands as one of the best versions of Irving's famous tale.
movie_title: The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad (1949)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing Broadway about this Edgar Rice Burroughs adaptation, but the wow factor is still there.
I'm not suggesting that every nature film narrator should sound like David Attenborough, but John C. Reilly really seems an odd choice.

The animation has a Saturday morning look to it, with an overall brighter, yellower cast, and the film feels like a cartoon short that's been put on the rack and stretched until it qualified as a "full-length feature."
movie_title: Mickey, Donald, Goofy: The Three Musketeers (2004)

movie_review_blurb: 'Hercules' may be second-tier Disney, but it's TOP second tier, not far behind the studio's best animated work.

Despite all the flaws, there's no denying the visceral feeling that "Need for Speed" evokes. I found myself tensed up throughout most of it, and that served to remind me that however simplistic and clichéd this film was, it still had me in its grip.
Jude Law gives a bravura performance as the title character, but you can't escape the feeling that this 2013 crime comedy-drama could have been either funnier or more dramatic.
While music doesn't take a back seat, it's more of a passenger than a driver. It feels like nonstop music without the generic concert format. But you learn or intuit something in the process.
Despite the camera cop-outs, 'Code Red' still struck me as a surprisingly decent addition to a subgenre that's crowded with substandard entries.
Although it's a relatively low-budget indie flick, I'd rate "No Clue" among my top three film noir/P.I. spoofs-right up there with "The Cheap Detective" (1978) and "Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid" (1982).
If "The Commitments" shows the gritty, robust side of Dublin and the Irish music scene, "Once" shows us a softer, more romantic side.

I'm going to side with the dissenters this time. I can see where it might be perceived as a dark comedy, but that label doesn't absolve it from an overarching sense that Scorsese didn't push this one far enough.
'Delivery Man' is a little like the main character: just good enough to make you care a little and smile a lot.
Picture 'The Sopranos' transplanted to the South, with . . . all of the mob action happening in an area that seems so rural you'd think they'd be dealing in raccoon pelts instead of meth.
Much of it is difficult to watch, but '12 Years a Slave' is that rare film that's both important in its message and a darned good film all the same.
For some viewers, the agony will be watching Charlton Heston (over)act, and the ecstasy Rex Harrison. But it IS refreshing for a period film to cover such new and (pun intended) artistic ground.
As sword-and-sandal films go, 'The 300 Spartans' is a good one, but don't expect hard-edged action and graphic violence of the '300' sort.
If you're put off by the missionary impulse, then this film probably isn't for you-even though Bergman brings an honest earnestness to the film that's hard to resist.
movie_title: The Inn of the Sixth Happiness (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Robin Williams plays off of a flaming Nathan Lane with delicious understatement and anchors a farce that moves along at a brisk pace-with or without heels.

A respectable outing for the doll-turned-star, but an overly familiar plot, along with animation that doesn't have the same "wow" factor as the Fairytopia film released earlier this year, make it a middle-of-the-road entry in the series.
movie_title: Barbie and Her Sisters in a Pony Tale (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If you're collecting Best Pictures, 'In the Heat of the Night' was completely deserving of the Oscar then, and remains a taut crime drama almost 50 years later.
movie_title: In the Heat of the Night (1967)

movie_review_blurb: As Christian-themed movies go, this one may not be an over-the-fence hit, but decent enough acting almost compensates for a clichéd plot that's intended as a too-obvious illustration/inspiration.
More sensitive than sensational, 'A Werewolf Boy' is an interesting hybrid of the 'Twilight' saga, 'Frankenstein,' and 'Beauty and the Beast.' But there are touches here that make it purely Korean.
The trance angle adds an interesting dimension to an otherwise routine crime caper flick.
The Falls themselves are an ever-present backdrop, and as memorable (and integral to the plotting) as Mount Rushmore was in "North by Northwest."
I suspect that some viewers will either like the film because of Monroe's performance, or hate it because of Murray's.
In this film about murder, the last 10 minutes are enough to kill me.
Features one of the funniest, bawdiest, most memorable scenes I've ever witnessed in a film. Despite the formulaic elements, it still feels like an original.
Like the Beatles' "Yellow Submarine," it's all about the marriage of music and images.
While Park Hoon-jeong's gangster film seems to celebrate the genre rather than adding a whole lot, it's reflective of a self-conscious style that's helping South Korean directors turn a few heads.
It feels like somebody strung together some of the worst SNL skits and called it a film.

I'm not the right audience for this film, but then again neither are some 16,000 readers at the Internet Movie Database who gave it a cumulative rating of 5.7 out of 10. I think a few 21 & Unders might have pushed it up a few points.
As you listen to these six former chiefs of one of the world's most secretive organizations, it's hard not to have your jaw drop in awe, or surprise at their sudden candor.

It's not just the acting. There's no chemistry, and very few Cole Porter songs are performed in such a way that you'd guess would make the old lyricist happy. 'You're the Top'? Not with this group doing the singing.
For all its flaws, 'No' succeeds because the marketers sell the audience, too.
"The Way Way Back" is a sharply written comedy that's full of wise and wise-guy moments.
Watching "Family Weekend" you feel as trapped as the tied-up parents, wondering, when will it all end?
It may not be as compelling and tightly edited as "Ben-Hur," but "Cleopatra" is still a Hollywood epic that tells a grand story in a grand way.
'The Numbers Station' is a competent film and it does manage to create some tension. But you're conscious of the fact that it all feels familiar and wondering why there isn't a little more to it.
'The Muppet Movie' is one big road trip, and like 'The Blues Brothers' there's a payoff not just at the end, but around nearly every corner. Music only sweetens the deal.
Michael Haneke gives us an unflinching look at love in the twilight years, placing a lot on the shoulders of two stars who come through like the veterans they are.
'Aroused' is well done, and like the best documentaries and the best artwork it alters the way you see a subject and the way you think about things. But it is NOT arousing.
As drama it gets a little too soapy and the jumps in time can seem abrupt, but "Cavalcade" really does convey a sense of history and historical periods.
By and large this is a film meant to do exactly what the film's charity event does: to provide light entertainment while raising money for a good cause.

If your child (or children) likes Winnie the Pooh, they should enjoy this holiday feature, because it involves familiar holiday rituals with a gentle variation as only the Hundred Acre Wood gang could manage. But it's only for preschoolers.
movie_title: Winnie the Pooh - A Very Merry Pooh Year (2008)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Internship' isn't as funny or exuberant as 'Wedding Crashers' and the plot is formulaic, but as lightweight entertainment goes it's . . . well, light and entertaining.
'Cars' has energy and heart-two things that 'Robots' lacked.

There are a few off-color lines, but those should fly right over the heads of youngsters who will be more intent on the costumes and stage action. In fact, I'd say that this musical will appeal mostly to families with younger children.
A solid buddy-cop action-comedy that draws all its energy from Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy, who are flat-out funny and fun to watch.

Not be as suspenseful as it once was, because we've seen many shots of the body's interior and we no longer have the undercurrents of the Cold War that made life itself an edge-of-the-seat affair. But it's still a fun sci-fi excursion.

Irwin Allen's "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea" may be a campy affair, but you've got to give them credit for talking about climate change at least 30 years before it became a "hot" topic in the scientific community.
movie_title: Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Despite being under-researched, it's still an effective film. Like '42,' this documentary kindles great respect for those who've faced hardships because of the color of their skin color.
There are stronger Danny Kaye films out there, but 'On the Riviera' is perhaps the best showcase for all of the performer's talents . . . and it's entertaining enough.
Watching it again after not seeing it for many years, I was also struck by how much of a debt novelist-screenwriter Donn Pearce ('Cool Hand Luke') owes to Jones.
Contemporary horror fans will be struck by how much more dramatic than horrific 'The Fly' is.
All it needed was a rewrite from a Second City cast member to punch it up a bit.
movie_title: The Mole Man Of Belmont Avenue (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Despite solid performances, a slow first half takes away from this otherwise effective drama about an IRA sympathizer whose life becomes more complicated after she's coerced into spying for MI-5.
There's something about a free spirit, even in a movie, that makes everything and everyone around her feel more vibrant.
For lovers of fashion who think of designers as Greek gods, and Bergdorf's as their Olympus.
The film's pathos at times seems all-consuming, to where a little more suspense along the way might have helped hold the attention of younger viewers.
Non-surfers may wish for a few more internal human conflicts to go with all of the man versus nature big-wave riding.

If this were a comedy it might be considered a comedy of manners, because it's all about the social customs of an age-and all the actors do a fine job of bringing the age's nuances to their characters.
And it happens, and it happens, and it's an awesome, immersive thing.
It all feels like piling on - the campaign movie as blooper reel.
Perhaps all things must pass, but I would not pass this one up.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a revelation, but it's an intimate story of the band, with performance sequences that show how five guys-in different lineups -- came together and made an entity of pure fire and sex.

Anyone who followed the '08 and '12 elections will not be surprised by how Mitt's story plays out. But it's an interesting footnote, a spin-free picture of the personal cost of campaigning; I found it humanly sympathetic regardless of political sympathies.
A low-key but moving documentary about two low-key people and their moving struggle.
Technically and visually, Peter Pan Live! delivered. The smartest thing the production did was to be unashamedly stagey.
In the end, Sharknado 3-like the CGI monsters that are its true stars-is the beast that it is: single-minded, greedy and ravenous. But for all that, it can still be a lovely creature.
You Don't Know Jack may be a film about the case for making dying patients comfortable. But admirably, it recognizes that thinking about this, or watching, should be discomfiting.
For all its sweep, Spielberg the documentary succeeds most distinctively where Mr. Spielberg the director has: accessing the child in its subject.
Some 30 years later, this movie-strident, passionate, frenetic, and aching-is a reminder, as Memorial Day weekend begins the summer, of all those empty spots the plague left on the beach.
Power and passion are the twin and intertwined themes of Cleopatra, and they have never burned with greater intensity or amid such opulence as they do in this extraordinary film.
The greatest credit for the implacable engagement that the film creates for its audience must go to the director, Mike Nichols. Nichols makes a stunning film bow with Virginia Woolf.
There is no other picture like it. There will be none. If it could be summed up in a word, the word would be sublime. And the man responsible for that, when all is said and done is Cecil B. DeMille.
An unusual love story, glamorous, sophisticated, with more than a touch of the bizarre.
Despite the grim and brooding background, Zhivago has a surging buoyant spirit that is unquenchable. Doctor Zhivago is more than a masterful motion picture; it is a life experience.
To Kill A Mockingbird is a product of American realism, and it is a rare and worthy treasure.
Hitchcock prolongs his prelude to horror for more than half the film, playing with audience suspense with comedy and romance while he sets his stage. The horror when it comes is a hair-raiser ...
An amusing, moving and meaningful picture.

The direction and acting are good, so interest is maintained. Frankeheimer's handling of the early sequences, in which he attempts and succeeds in creating on film the corruption of the mind, is imaginative filmmaking.
It is compounded of taste, excitement, heart and mind, and more than any other individual, the one who put it there and kept it there was Robert Wise.
A lurid melodrama of hate, revenge and murder, a high-class horror film, in the Hitchcock vein, with virtuoso performances from Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, and moments both searing and poignant.
movie_title: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A wickedly funny, infinitely compassionate and profound work about the elusiveness of truth and what one character calls a world "contaminated by fear."
The film works best in the musicians' own words about why music truly is the universal language of mankind.
You know something's amiss in a movie when an omniscient narrator blathers the entire way through it.
My advice to the slam-poetry-hating and documentary-loving individual: Enjoy, but escape before the Q&A.
Champions is estimable in almost every category: The script is taut without being stifling, the characters charm without becoming caricatures, the cinematography is engaging without being mawkish.
Premature hits all the bases, but doesn't knock it out of the park.

Like Before Sunrise, the real joy of writer/director Andrew Haigh's film is in watching two people make bedrooms, overpasses, kitchenettes, and couches feel alive with potent conversation and pregnant silences.
If nothing else, The Turning is probably value for money. Quantity counts for something, after all, as do good intentions. But they can't ever fully satisfy.
It Follows is the real deal.
Even as the events carry a tinge of absurdity, Eggers' sure technique ensures a thick current of dread runs throughout.
Sebastián Silva's Nasty Baby is an amiably funny traipse through the lives of a group of coddled inner-city hipsters, until suddenly, viciously, it's not.
The character Lucy may be all brain, but the film is all heart.
47 Ronin is a film for nobody, made by committee. Like its samurai, it is masterless.
A globe-trotting spy thriller with the brisk pace and the visual wit of a Looney Tunes cartoon.
When high style meets dumb ideas it can be hard to tell which way is up.
Charlie's Country is a gift for both actor and audiences.
Elton knows how to locate the laughs in his material - and he's a shameless crowdpleaser - but his emotional reach only goes skin deep.
The ferocity [Byrne] brings is almost enough to compensate for the limp approach the film takes to its own premise.

Perkins, finding the sweet spot between childish goofiness and adult drama, keeps things fleet, funny, and just the right side of suspenseful; tonally, the film is a match for any Spielbergian 80s coming-of-age classic.

The air almost immediately starts leaking out of the film once it starts. The whole first half-hour is a riot of blunt exposition, useless flashbacks, and false starts. This is a movie that doesn't even know how to begin.
Director James Mangold shoots and orchestrates action with an appreciable clarity, and when he synchs up with the pounding drums of Marco Beltrami's score, the mayhem has a lively intensity.
Surreal, whimsical comedy about an island commune of impersonators.
At just over 80 minutes it feels not so much like a proper film as a piece of extended filler for slow afternoons on Disney's TV channels.
Robert Altman's Korea-as-Vietnam 'comedy' demonstrates the best -- and worst -- of '70s cinema.
Kevin Spacey, Julianne Moore astound in touching, well-told tale of rebirth and redemption.
A superb 20th Anniversary DVD proves that Tron wasn't just groundbreaking; it's also great fun.
Robert Redford's military prison drama contains cruel and unusual punishment -- for the audience.
Vegas heist flick with style, charm and an ensemble cast of the coolest cats in town makes it safe for grown-ups to enter the theater again.
Alejandro Amenabar's psychothriller is a dark dish Cruise and Crowe later turned to plain Vanilla.
Michael Mann reminds us why Muhammad Ali was the greatest -- inside and outside the ring -- in 2001's best film.
Smug, simpering and warmed over, The Majestic is a horrible film with delusions of grandeur.
Perhaps the greatest mystery in Cruise-Crowe mindbender is why it doesn't quite work.
Black-and-white Coen brothers experiment in film noir is transformed by Billy Bob Thornton's superb performance.
Wes Anderson's fairy tale of New York has martini-dry comedy and a superb ensemble cast that can't overcome the failings of the quirky, convoluted script.
Cameron Diaz "comedy" follows the Farrelly brothers' path with degrading, unfunny "jokes" that make you feel unclean just watching them.
Digital video + digital animation + ancient questions = A visionary, stunning examination of the big picture.
Full of smart images, powered by hope and humanity, Amelie is a shining celebration of the possibilities of love.
Ensemble spoof of '80s flicks such as Meatballs and Little Darlings is a camp comedy -- in more ways than one.
Actor Bill Paxton's directorial debut is a stark horror film full of surprises -- and genuine scares.
This Orange has some juice, but it's far from fresh-squeezed.
Cameron Crowe's directorial debut gets a fully loaded DVD that demonstrates the best -- and worst -- of all his films.
Twisty, disturbing mix of John Hughes and James Cameron is an unsettling meditation on fate -- and the debut of a major talent.
Muddled, melodramatic paranormal romance is an all-time low for Kevin Costner.
Moody, suggestive horror piece has fascinating elements, but never quite takes off.
Modern take on H.G. Wells's sci-fi classic has great special effects but isn't especially affecting.
Military thriller aims high and misses the barn door by a mile.
Baseball drama from director Billy Crystal has the graceful arc of a well-hit ball.
Superb, overlooked Vietnam drama may be Brian DePalma's finest hour.
A mix of velocity and idiocy, this ruinous remake lacks the brawn -- and the brains -- of the 1970s original.
Definitive cut of director Steven Spielberg's masterpiece isn't just great science fiction: It's great art.
movie_title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Widescreen biblical epic is bloated with spectacle and thin on plot.
Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire bring a hero to cinematic life with a fun, fast, action-packed blockbuster.
Kung fu, monsters, sorcery, 18-wheelers, swordfights and world-saving heroics against impossible odds: What more could you want?
Kill-or-be-killed reality-TV satire is uneven -- and unforgettable.
Acclaimed 1970s police tale has incredible style, knockout realism -- and Gene Hackman at his best.
Small-town drama has big moments thanks to Johnny Depp, Juliette Lewis and a superb Leonardo DiCaprio.
It's the most reviled sequel in American cinema -- with good reason -- but this DVD casts the least-loved Godfather film in a new light.
Tom Hanks' writing-directing debut is a sweet valentine to rock 'n' roll.
Epic tale about one man's journey down the transforming path of wisdom and peace.
Lancaster-Curtis saga of Manhattan's amoral media has spark and a wicked bite.
In a scabrous follow-up to Happiness, Todd Solondz once again crafts a movie easier to admire than it is to like.
Sprawling comedy has a few laughs in it -- and the specter of recent events hanging over it.
Tim Burton's "reinvention" of '68 sci-fi classic boasts awesome makeup and design -- and awful writing.
Plainspoken story about a horse in the Old West is simple, sincere and engaging for kids and adults.
Engaging thriller combines military movie genres and succeeds as more than the sum of its well-oiled parts.
"Socially conscious" Denzel Washington thriller wants to tackle tough questions -- but settles for easy answers.
Unless you're an AOL Time Warner board member, there's nothing to like about this insipid live-action version of the 1970s cartoon series.
Creepy psychothriller features great performances, twisty plot and superbly crafted moments of tension.
Inspired by true events, this war-is-hell action drama from John Woo is a failed epic that doesn't rise to meet the material that inspired it.
Brawny sword-and-sorcery adventure is both helped and hurt by the charm and good humor of wrestler-thespian star The Rock.
Gritty good-cop/bad-cop drama is elevated to greatness by Denzel Washington.
Brilliant visuals, murky story line make heralded sci-fi anime a confusing experience.
Second installment of mob saga isn't quite as good as the premiere season -- but still addictive stuff.
A brilliant DVD does justice to the greatest rock-and-roll film of all time.
David Fincher's directorial skill makes a tense tale snap with smart terror.
Debut effort by "Project Greenlight" winner is sappy and amateurish.
Kid-friendly, fun sequel is packed with zip-bang-pow style.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Jennifer Aniston shines in a sincere and funny film from the writer and director of Chuck and Buck.
Creepy, well-shot psycho-thriller features brilliant direction -- and an unforgettable turn from Robin Williams.
Seeing De Niro back in drama is the high point of this uneven, fact-based film.
A 100-year-old adventure classic returns to the big screen in a pretty, progressive and slightly poky adaptation.
Drama-thriller-romance with lite music and heavy subtext is a slight near miss, but still fascinating.
True tale of courage -- and complicity -- at Auschwitz is a harrowing drama that tries to tell of the unspeakable.
Seemingly bizarre teaming of Paul Thomas Anderson and Adam Sandler is a weird, slight and sideways -- yet delightful -- romantic comedy.
Rapper Eminem's film debut is far better than you'd think -- and a pure demonstration of the power of charisma.
The gloss of the 1950s gets a deeper, darker look in this triumph of style and substance from writer-director Todd Haynes.
The continuing story of everyone's favorite boy wizard is a visual feast -- and darker than the first installment.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to love -- and more to puzzle over -- in this curiously science-fiction-style outing for 007.
Steven Soderbergh's emotional, imaginative remake of a 1970s Soviet sci-fi classic is visually stunning and philosophically challenging.
Disney's animated pirate tale has masterful visuals -- and an amateur's script.
The geniuses behind Being John Malkovich show brains -- and heart -- in a self-aware comedy about passion, love and survival.
The posters suggest that this is "A Generation's Final Journey." That may be the best thing about Star Trek: Nemesis.
Jennifer Lopez and Ralph Fiennes make another Cinderella story -- and the supporting cast and Wayne Wang's direction make it pleasant.
The middle installment of Peter Jackson's saga is heavy on spectacle, long on talent -- and still feels like the halfway mark of an unfinished symphony.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Spike Lee gives us a crime movie that isn't -- and puts us all under indictment.
Denzel Washington's directorial debut is a handsomely made tale of challenge and triumph diminished by "After School Special" morality.
Quote not available.
Scorsese's New York tale is a curiously cramped epic, roaring with blood and thunder -- but with nothing to say.
True tale of Australian children running from the cruelty of adults is visually captivating -- with an urgent emotional core.
Brilliantly crafted documentary about Hollywood legend Robert Evans may not be the unvarnished truth, but it is great, glossy fun.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Polished Korean political-action film is just as good -- and bad -- as Hollywood action epics. Is this progress?
Soviet submarine drama tells a great true story, but lacks depth.
Comedy about a boy, a man and their very different lives is sharp, sweet and surprisingly winning.
Mel Gibson's Vietnam drama breaks under the weight of its contradictions.
William H. Macy shines in unsettling, unusual thriller.
Computer-animated fable has newfangled look, old-fashioned laughs.
Vampire epic succeeds as spooky action-packed trash of the highest order.
Behind-the-scenes documentary on Canadian comedy troupe needs more scenes, and less, uh, behind.
movie_title: Kids In The Hall - Same Guys, New Dresses (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Kiddie-TV satire has foul-mouthed mania to spare, but never attains true inspiration.
Sports-agent epic about humanity in the face of commercialism still stands as Cruise's and Crowe's best work.
Military whodunit isn't great drama, but director Carl Franklin's skill makes for an above-average thriller.
British comedy about fortyish female friends is as well-crafted as it is predictable.
Surreal comedy explores the differences between man and the animals -- and finds humans wanting.
Dog-eat-dog urban drama has great script, direction -- and unexpectedly smart performances from Affleck and Jackson.
Cop Sandra Bullock tries to keep two teen killers from getting away with murder -- and from stealing the movie out from under her.
Well-shot drama features great work from Billy Crudup and Julianne Moore -- and an infuriating script from director Bart Freundlich.
Angelina Jolie's romance/comedy/drama isn't terribly romantic, comedic or dramatic.
Infidelity drama is nicely shot, well-edited ... and features a standout performance by Diane Lane.
Woody Allen's latest is an ambling, broad comedy about all there is to love -- and hate -- about the movie biz.
There are "strange things done in the midnight sun" by a killer -- and by a cop -- in this taut remake from the director of Memento.
Tom Clancy franchise gets a surprisingly satisfying reinvention thanks to star Ben Affleck and director Phil Alden Robinson.
Hopkins-Rock action-comedy wastes both talents with an achingly inept script and truly ruinous direction.
Cross-generational mother-daughter drama is a little familiar, but it'll still warm your heart.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Matt Damon's an amnesiac secret agent on the run in this immensely satisfying and engagingly direct thriller.
Disney sci-fi action-comedy goes Hawaiian, rejecting formula and finding freshness and fun.
Christina Ricci comedy about sympathy, hypocrisy and love is a misfire.
Spielberg's fable of crime and punishment in tomorrowland is imperfect but still impressive.
Lean serial-killer thriller makes The Silence of the Lambs look sheepish.
Oscar-winning documentary shows an Olympian tragedy in rich detail.
Prison flick from ex-con screenwriter is raw and realistic, with powerful acting.
Snappy Shakespeare adaptation has guts, gloss and glorious performances.
From wild-and-crazy guy to gray eminence, Martin is at his best.
movie_title: Saturday Night Live: The Best of Steve Martin (1999)

movie_review_blurb: "Best of" disc from "Saturday Night Live" comic is a bittersweet look back.
movie_title: Saturday Night Live: The Best of Chris Farley (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Bank-robbery/beauty-pageant caper is sweet, silly fun.
Big tobacco, big media, big drama in director Michael Mann's masterpiece.
Tim Robbins' New Deal theatrical fable tries hard -- too hard.
Being John Malkovich is one head-trip of a comedy.
High-pulp look at Citizen Kane's genesis is stylish but shallow.
Fake documentary about the age of dinosaurs is great fun.
Director Lawrence Kasdan's small-town fable beguiles.
Mouse tale with heartwarming emotion and eye-popping effects is anything but cheesy.
Roger Moore's second outing as James Bond is glossy, but fires blanks.
movie_title: The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Star Trek spoof boldly mocks where no one has mocked before.
The "King of Pop ... Culture References" shines in this stand-up DVD.
movie_title: Dennis Miller Live from Washington D.C. (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Animated Japanese thriller about the price of fame is rich, deep and dark.
Moody thriller is spooky fun, but not much more.
Costner baseball flick is great at motion, not so hot at emotion.
Jet Li remakes Bruce Lee, and the result is great.
movie_title: Fist of Legend (Jing wu ying xiong) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: "Saturday Night Live"-sketch-turned-film is slight -- and surprisingly enjoyable.
Overlooked Martin Scorsese movie has grim humor, grit and grace.
Documentary about a Wisconsin wanna-be filmmaker is funny, honest.
David Mamet-Shel Silverstein collaboration is funny, touching and tense.
A spooky gothic horror tale with first-rate production design.
Little-known gem of a '70s New York crime thriller is near perfect to begin with, and even better on DVD.
movie_title: The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Moving tale about love, regret and redemption boasts standout script and performances.
Intricate, intimate thriller is full of superb performances, deft direction.
Rock-'em, sock-'em, sharp satire is among the best films of the '90s.
Jonathan Demme's fumbled remake of Charade tries to mix old-fashioned champagne romance with straight-from-the-bottle swigs of New Wave style.
The film tackles remarkably unhappy moments, and it discusses mortality and morality in a responsible and emotionally affecting fashion.

Saving Private Ryan is far from flawless, but it's an important movie. It shows what America was once capable of, how a threat to freedom and justice was met with resolve and bravery, and how a great victory came at great cost.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Inspired, brilliant filmmaking and one of the most scathing satires to come along in some time.
Quote not available.
The best Bond gets the best treatment.
Fast Times has not endured the passage of time.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.

By blanketing the prison experience with a sepia-tone haze of nostalgia and placing it in a time that's part history, part Normal Rockwell, the film provides a trip through the belly of the beast that isn't too icky...
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
This "Portrait of the Stand-Up as a Young Man" lacks depth, but has moments.
SNL's Man of a Thousand Faces shines in well-done hits package with great stuff and cool extras.
movie_title: Saturday Night Live - Best of Dana Carvey (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Newman-Robert Redford Western is as great as you remember.
movie_title: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969)

movie_review_blurb: There's more to this crime-thriller than meets the eye.
Bittersweet gender-bender tale features great performances.
It's like Ghostbusters -- but with aliens! And guns! And no script!
A nice animated trip for kids, but hardly a required journey for grown-ups.
Mambo Italiano! Mafia comedy is molto fabuloso!
Tale about "The Mikado" and its creators, Gilbert and Sullivan, provides rich cinema.
Kenneth Branagh's valentine to Alfred Hitchcock is too clever for its own good.
Bloody sword-and-sandals epic is good, but not great.
The neo-noir debut from the Coen brothers is snappy, cynical and intricate.
Magical fable from writer-director John Sayles is a departure -- and a great success.
Lightweight tale of geek love is glib, predictable and utterly charming.
Football flick has a great lineup, but fumbles the ball.
Drama based on the rise and fall of the "Teflon Don" is more satisfying than it should be.
Tim Robbins' documentary about singing Senate candidate is funny, scary political satire.
Yes, it's better than The Phantom Menace. Think for a minute about how little that means.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Worst of the Roger Moore Bond films has a license to bore.
Gritty Los Angeles punk-rock chronicle is ugly, raw and realistic.
World War II classic receives brilliant presentation and provides fascinating perspective on DVD.
movie_title: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Smorgasbord of international short films contains empty calories.
The road to hell is paved with ... bathroom humor.
Labor of love has lots of heart -- but makes little sense.
Gene Hackman and Morgan Freeman can't save "Whodunit?" from becoming "Who cares?"
Simply put: This is the best American film since The Godfather.
Playwright David Mamet's directorial debut is a cardsharp con game full of tricks.
"Family" saga about a mobster's discontents is rule-breaking television -- and great art.
Kidnapping romance showcases Crowe's gifts -- and Ryan's limitations.
Vigilante-justice film flickers between camp and chauvinism, slam-bang action and sexist idiocy.
Director Francis Ford Coppola's paranoid classic is brilliantly revived on DVD.
Horror-spoof musical is goofy fun.
Indie director and movie star team up for thrilling, smart, snappy entertainment with a message.
Invisible man tale mixes high-tech effects and old-fashioned chills for out-of-sight entertainment.
Zeffirelli's Romeo and Juliet is best version on film.
Meg Ryan-Billy Crystal romantic comedy is hard not to like.
Tom Cruise legal thriller is great entertainment; case closed.
Tense tale combines travel magazine gloss with Alfred Hitchcock's dark heart.
Restored Hitchcock thriller charms, chills and sparkles.
Big, dumb, glossy blockbuster designed for mass appeal is massively appalling.
Hollywood magic thriller offers popcorn pleasure.
Director David Lynch's American odyssey is a masterwork of quiet poetry.
Driver and Duchovny shine in romance with heart.
Bizarre comedy of errors is surprisingly good-natured, but not that good.
There's so much right -- and so much wrong -- with this lauded, scathing look at suburban discontent.
Tom Cruise's superspy outing is pure summertime satisfaction!
Andy Kaufman biopic is hollow, even with Jim Carrey's chameleonlike performance.
Unsettling documentary is a gripping study of the banality of evil.
movie_title: Mr. Death: The Rise and Fall of Fred A. Leuchter, Jr. (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Classic tale gets a beautiful -- and unnecessary -- retelling.
Stirring historical biography is epic, intimate and awe-inspiring.
The greatest film of all time now has a DVD to match.
Low-budget debut from Memento's director subtly transposes you to a sinful urban nightmare.
Sci-fi classic is better -- and worse -- than you remember.
Animated space opera shoots for the stars, but runs out of gas.
Idiotic "comedy" is larded with thick makeup and thin performances.
Newman and Fiorentino steal cash -- and scenes -- in amiable heist comedy.
Jackie Chan's East-meets-Western action comedy is surprising fun.
Documentary about Irish boxer's struggle pulls punches, never connects.
U-571 superbly mixes classic touches and brand-new thrills.
Kevin Kline's star turn as a good-yet-flawed prep school teacher is a very different take on private-school-flick cliches. ...
Comic strip adaptation is flabby, lazy and blase -- just like its subject (although probably not on purpose).
Billy Crystal and Robert De Niro sleepwalk through vulgarities in a sequel you can refuse.
Jim Sheridan's latest effort is a ghost story, a personal epic, a celebration of family and America -- and one of 2003's best films.
December-December romance between Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson is a funny and warm look at just how scary love can be.
Servant girl Scarlett Johansson discovers the privileges and perils of being painter Vermeer's muse in a tense, thoughtful masterwork.
Teacher-and-student drama has all the "right" answers; too bad it feels like a cheat.
Ben Affleck stars in a mix of Hitchcock style and 21st century mind games that can't quite cash itself.
Tim Burton's Southern-fried tall tale about fathers and sons is a lot better -- and a lot warmer -- than his recent work.
Civil War story of love and struggle is a carefully, expertly crafted piece of Oscar bait that's still satisfying.
The big-screen, big-everything adaptation of the 20th century's most powerful fantasy epic reaches a stunning finale.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: P.J. Hogan's adaptation of the children's classic is full of dread, desire and delight -- and is one of the best family films in a long while.
Jennifer Connelly and Ben Kingsley shine despite a few unvarnished rough spots in this human drama.
International story of bicycling, rescue, singing, the passage of time and the nature of evil is a fantastic use of animation for grown-up storytelling.
Ponderous "thriller" about French anti-Semitism has noble intentions -- but banal execution.
The flashes of life in this Ben Stiller-Jennifer Aniston romantic comedy don't come along often enough to rescue it.
Disney's latest attempt at TV-series-to-theaters is a kids' film designed to give adults migraines, despite animation innovations and unique design.
Hollywood-meets-the-heartland romantic comedy surpasses expectations.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Olympic hockey drama re-creates an unexpected victory and the blood, sweat, toil and tears that made it happen.
True-tale mountaineering nightmare combines documentary remembrance and dramatic retelling for a terrifying, transcendent experience.
Ice Cube warms up and Cedric the Entertainer lives up to his title in this unexpectedly rich and rewarding comedy sequel.
Charlize Theron's performance as a serial killer is a masterpiece, even if the movie itself falls short.
Adaptation of Elmore Leonard novel doesn't have much rebound at all, despite a big-name cast.
Bernardo Bertolucci's love letter to Paris, cinema and sex in 1968 is as uneven and imperfect as it is unique and impassioned.
Romance meets neurology in this Adam Sandler-Drew Barrymore romance that only works when she's on-screen.
Teen-targeted romantic comedy about President's daughter Mandy Moore pursuing her liberties is surprisingly sweet and civil.
Going beyond just Tom Cruise in "Dances with Shogun," the blend of many other movies makes for a perfectly good -- not great -- action epic.
Billy Bob Thornton's work in this Claus-and-robbers comedy is so very naughty that it's very, very nice.
Another Disney ride-turned-movie looks great ... and goes nowhere.
Florida noir reteams Devil in a Blue Dress's director and star -- with less intriguing results.
Quentin Tarantino goes forward to the past -- and reclaims the cinematic style that he defined.
Clint Eastwood's best film since Unforgiven is another look at murder, death and the good in men that can die long before they do.
Gorgeous, commercial Coen brothers romantic comedy has A-list luster and plenty of laughs, but is a little lacking.
This human drama may be a big showcase for small actor Peter Dinklage, but it's much more than a one-man show. ...
Iconic horror film gets a modernized remake that's as well done as it is blood-soaked.
San Francisco's smart set of high-tech thinkers can still be stupid at love in this warm, winning indie DV romance.
Phony, pseudo-retro tale about a disabled boy and the football coach who reached out to him is thin, syrupy mush.
Director Gus Van Sant's inspired-by-Columbine, digital-video drama is an existential, everyday nightmare of taut suspense and bloody slaughter.
Seafaring story of men and war is a classic tale that works masterfully today, thanks to Peter Weir's superlative adaptation and direction.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Directorial debut of Brit-com master Richard Curtis is a big, bright ensemble tale with many delights -- and absolutely no surprises.
Disney's animated fable takes the "circle of life" for another wearying spin down a road the studio has traveled before.
True story about fact, fiction and fakery is a surprisingly well-tuned thriller about morals, courage and honesty -- with a breakout performance by Peter Sarsgaard.
Philip Roth's novel about race, shame and politics turns into a smug cipher with high-gloss sleepwalkers Anthony Hopkins and Nicole Kidman.
Showy adaptation of Susanna Moore's sexual thriller starring Meg Ryan is more erratic than erotic.
Holiday comedy gives the talented Will Ferrell a chance to flail wildly -- yet warmly -- as a human raised by elves.
Epic trilogy's final installment feels like a trailer for itself -- and more than a little bit wrong.
English-language debut from director and writer of Amores Perros has a broken structure but amazing performances.
Halle Berry's shrink-to-inmate story has a few problems ... and some nice, solid, cheesy-cheap jolts.
Another Dr. Seuss classic gets the big-screen treatment ... and it's not that much of a treat.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Fact-based story of drugs and death in "clubland" is boring and banal, failing in its attempt to shock and scandalize.
Time-travel tale is a so-so action flick that plays like Jurassic Park ... but without the dinosaurs. Or stars. Or excitement.
Ron Howard mingles The Searchers and Dances with Wolves to make a confounding, exasperating, Oscar-seeking failure.
Documentary about a man's search for his famous and distant architect father is warm, human, gorgeous and moving.
"White House meets outhouse" comedy isn't fit to serve, and Marcia Gay Harden and Maura Tierney outshine stars Gene Hackman and Ray Romano.
Teen sex comedy is flesh-obsessed, frantic and foolish -- as well as weirdly satisfying and surprisingly witty.
Mel Gibson's labor of love about the death of Jesus is incredibly labored, recasting his Crucifixion in crimson, slo-mo cliches.
Roland Emmerich's global warming disaster flick is big, dumb and flat, but hard to really hate.
A change in directors brings the third installment of the boy-wizard saga even closer to greatness.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Director Lars von Trier goes mental on his mentor and makes him remake a film over and over and over ...
Canadian doc is a great look at the business of being a business -- even if it's a smidge overlong and made to confirm more than convert.
Portrait of 1960s poet is fun for fans, if a tad dusty.
movie_title: Ladies and Gentlemen... Mr. Leonard Cohen (1965)

movie_review_blurb: Riveting documentary about Al-Jazeera has a simple, sturdy structure, a critical eye and a plain-spoken style.
Pitch Black sequel tries to make a condiment a main course -- and offers action fans a meager meal in the process.
French exercise in California crisis and empty existentialism manages to be pointless, dim and brutal all at once.
This quirky-nerdy, heartland-set tale of a teen outcast's life and dorky times fizzles.
Airport-purgatory story from Spielberg and Hanks is a minor work from two master craftsmen.
Underachieving comedy is a great parody -- and the best smart-stupid laugh we've had in a long time.
Electric leads can't juice up cliche-ridden adaptation of Nicholas Sparks best-seller.
Takeshi Kitano offers his take on a pop-culture standard and demonstrates his immense talent with blood, brains and soul.
Michael Moore's latest volley at the powers that be is his strongest film to date, despite familiar, infuriating flaws.
Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise gets a sweet, sad and touching sequel after almost a decade.
Cole Porter biopic has flair and great tunes, but it's a little short on the facts of the great songsmith's life.
Better, faster, funnier, warmer -- Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire give us a superpowered sequel with soul.
Camelot gets changed a lot in this down-and-dirty, unmagical take on the Arthurian legends.
Raw, riveting rock doc goes inside a mega-band's crisis -- and captures an unexpectedly human search for connection.
It's hardly breaking news to tell you Will Ferrell's funny, but Anchorman's flights of lunacy need a little more story to keep us engaged.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Subtle, quiet look at a desperate journey hurts and haunts by giving us people's stories -- not a politicized slogan.
Big-budget, big-effects tale of men and machines has a tiny imagination and a robo-crafted soul.
This look at the Clinton years is weighted down with bad style, overly familiar faces and a far-too-friendly tone.
Big, bold, superb epic mixes timeless themes with here-and-now issues to strong, startling effect.
Jack Black kicks out the jams in the smartest, most exuberant, best comedy about the power of music since The Blues Brothers.
Bizarre, baroque mix of soap opera, song-craft, sorrow and substance abuse is an unpredictable knockout.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Big, dumb action flick makes the undead, unearthly and unholy look unimpressive, unintelligent and unexciting.
Ashley Judd sex-psycho-thriller isn't great, but you can easily appreciate how good it is.
Wilson-Stiller comedy revamps a 1970s TV show for a few laughs -- but just a few.
Thoroughly modern remake of 1978 B-movie classic is surprisingly smart and delivers zombie-tastic action-horror thrills.
Just your everyday, surreal, sweet, old-fashioned, science-fiction-flavored romance that tugs at your heart as it blows your mind.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Serial thriller starts with a bang, ends with a whimper, and never really moves beyond following its forebears.
Sequel is a hard sell and more of less from AOL-Time Warner's rehash division.
Potty-mouthed, pop culture-mad indie icon Kevin Smith grows up, gets serious, knuckles down ... and makes a boring movie.
Moody gangster-morality tale has an old-fashioned, mean-streets swagger and a charismatic lead in rapper DMX.
Tom Hanks and the Coen brothers team up for a remake that's so much less than the sum of the parts.
A comic book you've never heard of is brought to the big screen gleaming with enthusiasm, even if the script could have used more polish.
Remake of the '70s vigilante smash is a low-grade meat-and-potatoes action flick with The Rock and Johnny Knoxville providing a little gravy.
Animated tale of bovine heroics in the Old West isn't built from the usual Disney blueprint ... and that's a good thing.
Disney's PG-13 spectacle does a disservice to both fact and fiction with clumsy, cliche writing.
Fractured fairy tale is a delight for younger teens and 'tweens, thanks to charm, heart and star Anne Hathaway's enthusiasm.
Playing out farce under the shadow of fascism, this French thriller-romance-comedy-drama is an unusual film -- and an unusual pleasure.
Comic book revenge fantasy would have to struggle to hit two dimensions -- and why is Thomas Jane on board?
Actor-writer Nia Vardalos hopes some like it warmed over in this agreeable-but-familiar gender bender.
Second installment of Tarantino's meta-movie revenge fantasy is a very different film than Vol. 1, but just as good.
Likable two-for-one combo of Big and Regarding Henry offers stars whose charms help cover up script flaws.
Denzel Washington is walking death in Tony Scott's showy but chillingly real revenge film.
Atmospheric chiller about parenthood and peril has a cool, old-fashioned chill and subtle work from De Niro to help it along.
Lawyers-in-love romantic comedy has a retro snap that almost knocks the dust off of the plot, even as Brosnan and Moore shine.
High school's cruel combats make for a funny, smart-stupid comedy from the poison pen of Saturday Night Live genius Tina Fey.
Hilarious, honest and heartfelt documentary about America's obsession with fast food offers plenty of food for thought.
Indie icon John Sayles gives us yet another minor masterpiece that looks at love and want among the haves and have-nots.
Despite an aimlessly ambling plot, this travelogue fantasia of Italian sights is redeemed by Diane Lane's charm.
Knockdown, drag-out, "Yee-HAW!" action-comedy works thanks to the skill of the ensemble on both sides of the camera.
Simple, sincere documentary about the hidden homeless is a wrenching look at poverty, sexual discrimination and crisis.
Bruce Willis military actioner has guts, brains and patience -- and while not a masterpiece, it's far better than you'd think.
Teen spy tale is another success for young Frankie Muniz and is backed by a broad spectrum of unexpected talents.
Rock-and-roll tale of temptation in paradise looks great ... and works thanks to McDormand's fearless performance.
One-on-one match-up between Tommy Lee Jones and Benicio Del Toro is a torturously slow misfire that drips blood.
Military mystery has the swagger of Travolta and Jackson when it moves, but there's nothing behind the curtain.
Geological disaster flick is smarter than you'd think ... which isn't saying much.
Quote not available.
Bumpy, lumpy Stephen King adaptation is anything but by-the-book -- and packed with scares by a team of talents.
Vin Diesel doesn't have the horsepower to get this stalled mass of cliches going.
Joel Schumacher, master of the overblown, tries to craft a stripped-down, simple thriller and fails as desperately as only he can.
Justin Lin's look at overachievers who achieve bad things is a thriller, a social satire, a character study -- and one of the year's best.
A lazy, tired comedy in which Sandler does what he's done too many times before, and Nicholson does ... very little.
Neil Jordan/Nick Nolte caper flick is full of European charm, American swagger and far more style than substance.
Chow Yun-Fat's attempt at a Jackie Chan-style partnership with Seann William Scott might be called Bulletproof, but it's riddled with holes.
Con thriller ensemble is cozy and cute -- and perhaps a little too content with how familiar it is.
Al Pacino as a Manhattan publicist with moral paralysis is talky and tedious.
Football, family friction and cultural pop and politics add up to a comedy as completely delightful as it is predictable.
Psycho-thriller about 10 strangers at an isolated motel is spooky, smart and strange ... and packs a satisfying twist.
Superhero sequel has more action, bigger stakes and a sprawling cast, adding up to big-time popcorn satisfaction.
Philip Seymour Hoffman gives a quietly compelling performance as a financial whiz with plenty to lose.
Another brainy, shocking tale from Neil LaBute puts cruel modern twists on some old-fashioned themes.
Eddie Murphy retread of Mr. Mom is surprisingly satisfying, and sweet without being sickly.
Hong Kong action star Jet Li meets rap rough-rider DMX in a piece of action trash whose gloss can't outshine its flaws.
Moody, thoughtful drama is a brilliant debut for new actress Agnes Bruckner and a triumph for veteran David Strathairn.
Small-town romance has the poetry of the inarticulate, the faith of the wounded and the beauty of the everyday in every heartfelt frame.
This Kevin Spacey/Kate Winslet death row drama has pretensions of grandeur and a script that would shame Nancy Drew.
Big-talent movie musical jazzes up a Broadway classic -- and provides Renee Zellweger a chance to truly shine.
Spielberg's candy-colored tale of cons in the swingin' past is a blast of fun with a surprising amount of heart.
Featherweight romantic comedy has a few nice twists in a standard plot ... and the charisma of Hugh Grant and Sandra Bullock.
Biography of famed painter Frida Kahlo has gorgeous visuals and a slightly hollow heart.
Digital-video documentary about stand-up comedians is a great glimpse into a very different world.
Atom Egoyan may be our new Kubrick -- but his latest film's exploration of genocide and culture is the textbook definition of "ambitious failure."
Big-screen adaptation of brainy book about Virginia Woolf is loaded with star power ... and coldly calculated to go for Oscar's jugular.
Dark cop drama is a sharp shock of cinematic skill, powerhouse acting, '70s style and the evil that men do.
An older cad instructs a younger lad in Zen and the art of getting laid in this prickly indie comedy of manners and misanthropy.
Drama of temptation, salvation and good intentions is a thoughtful examination of faith, love ... and power.
Unsung heroes of some of pop music's finest moments get to stand up and be counted in this documentary/concert/tribute.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Graham Greene's novel of colonialism and empire is elevated by Michael Caine's performance as a weary journalist in a changing world.
Moody, stylish tale of heroin dealer John Leguizamo facing the white-collar world is a well-shot debut from Franc Reyes.
Fractured, flowing ensemble piece has a heart of true, sincere humanity -- and two brilliant performances.
One man's true story set against the Holocaust is a haunting, beautiful tale of humanity, horror and hope.
Tale of Midwestern late-life angst is a triumph for star Jack Nicholson -- but a step back for co-writer/director Alexander Payne.
Montana's wide-open spaces -- and the closed hearts of the people who live there -- make for a sincere, superbly acted story of loss and need.
The funny stuff at the heart of this film struggles in vain to free itself from a cage made of old romantic-comedy cliches.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This Jackie Chan/Owen Wilson sequel is a slack retread of Shanghai Noon -- but it's hard to get too upset about that.
Fernando Meirelles's powerful, energetic debut mixes troubled adolescence with criminal bonding in Brazil's slums.
Jonas Akerlund's crystal meth "comedy" is a feral, fearless Cheech & Chong movie for the times.
A minor-league Marvel hero gets a big-star film treatment that will appeal to action junkies ... and leave a broader audience cold.
L.A. cop-and-corruption drama set against the Rodney King verdicts is an uninspiring morass of been-there, seen-that material.
This college-set comedy has plenty of gas in the tank thanks to its lead actors, but it never arrives at true greatness.
Derivative dystopia is a muddled, maudlin and laughable mess with a few nice fight scenes to break up the failure.
Sci-fi epic is broader, brisker and -- for better and for worse -- about what you'd expect from part two of a trilogy.
Faux-'60s sex comedy is bright, charming and smart in a million different ways -- especially casting Ewan and Renee as Rock and Doris.

I wouldn't have minded seeing a little Bay-hem on the big screen in Transformers 3; instead, with battles I didn't care about between characters I barely knew, all I got was idiocy, tedium and expense in the pursuit of Bay-nality.
But it's Gomez, on the poster in a ball gown and cowboy boots, who will lure the audience into the theaters. And she is ... fine.
Considering how many other summer comedies deserve to be fired for cause and walked out of the building by security with their stuff in a filing box, Horrible Bosses does the job well enough.
I briefly felt bad when the film, in its first five minutes, knocked Sophie into a coma. But I felt even worse 10 minutes later: Dear reader, I envied her.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In an age when the Shrek films make oral sex jokes and Cars 2 flip-flops between tedium and terror, the real pleasure of the gentle, graceful Winnie the Pooh is that it is a kid's film that really, truly works for kids.
Marling and Cahill's script is short on facts and long on feelings, but they do deserve points for thinking outside the box of their small budget...
Funny and frank, real and romantic, Myth feels like a mix of a poem and a party, as brief and beautiful as the right kind of summer night.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Captain America is not high art, but it is so unabashedly fun -- and such well-made fun -- that it is hard to not like and admire it for so steadfastly being what it is.
It's just sad that a movie suggesting an honest and zesty approach to sex and relationships builds to such a conventional ending...
William Carlos Williams wrote "The pure products of America/ Go crazy," and the funny, freaky Tabloid captures that contrast, that promise, that curse.
Is it realistic? Absolutely not. Does it create real feeling? Absolutely.
The workmanship and effort are evident in every straining moment, but the end result is so completely phony as to be without value.
It's warm and beautiful and terrible and scary, full of heart and blood and truly unique.
You don't need to know the original material or French politics to enjoy Ozon's latest. You just need an appreciation for human folly...
Brilliant but bleak comedy for mature Coen brothers fans.
...the film's so flat and sour that when the whole cast are gathered together around a communal dinner table, all you want to do is escape the acid, claustrophobic rancor of its unpleasantness.
Yes, we've seen all this stuff before, but we've never seen this version of this stuff before.
Docu on corporate misdeeds names names, makes mistakes.
Violent action remake races to a high body count.
Bikers, babes, blood, booze ... and blah.
Brutal horror movie offers little to reflect on.
Foul-mouthed Ferrell comedy isn't very funny. No kids.
Grisly thriller with great performances; not for kids.
Excellent sequel much darker, more violent than the first.
Mature road-trip dramedy doesn't go anywhere new.
Horror film is long on peril, but thin on plot.
Bloodier action than other comic book adventures.
Naughty Mike Myers comedy has little to love.
Horror remake has more tension than blood.
Story of "bad-boy" teen is funny, but also rough and raw.

...the traditional problem of big-budget family entertainment arises, where the grown-up jokes are too grown-up for the younger kids in the audience and the jokes for kids are too insipid and simplistic to appeal to grown-ups.
Country Strong stumbles, and has some slack in its silences, but it takes its world, characters and songcraft seriously...
Barney's Version could use some editing and shaping, to be sure, but its core characters -- and core performances -- are sharp and clear even against its fuzzy, unfocused plot.
Waiting for Forever isn't just bad; it's fascinatingly bad.
The degree of hero-making in effect is unintentionally hilarious -- much of [it] plays like a campaign ad, or a career-highlights montage you'd see for someone's retirement
A little more polish in the writing could have made it a must-see, but as it stands, it's a fairly solid B-movie matinee with a nicely calibrated mix of intellectual dread and visceral shock.
It is hard to imagine Drive Angry sustaining this level of trash-tastic hysterical hokum, and I regret to inform you that it does not, even with all of the above in 3-D.
...the over-explained softened edges of the story turn what could have been an exceptional brain-bender into a good, but fairly standard-issue heart-warmer.
Blandly literal and flabbily familiar, the great irony of Beastly is that this filmed version of the classic parable of how beauty is only skin-deep has so very little going on under the surface.
Fukunaga's superbly executed direction and careful staging speak very rarely, and yet say so much.
It's C-minus work from people who normally deliver A-level efforts.
"Star Trek Into Darkness" kind of slumps back into the franchise's own canon, which is why it feels a bit less fun, fresh and funky than its predecessor; It's still a good time.
Sightseers homicidal holiday isn't just a pitch-black comedy made with skill, will and brains; it's also another demonstration that Wheatley is, to use an all-too-appropriate phrase, going places.

Black Rock isn't going to become the sort of classic that Deliverance was, but if you like your scares smart, and like them to happen to people you actually care about, then Aselton's island of friendship and fury is a nice place to visit.
ig Eyes is more melodrama than drama, more comedy of manners than cultural critique -- and yet its wide-eyed candy-colored exterior holds fascinating and funny depths behind its glassy stare.

The Interview may be caught up in turmoil -- considering how smart it is about how dumb we can be when pop culture meets politics, that's pretty funny -- but it's also a funny, risky and well-done comedy far ahead of most of its studio peers.
Praised on the festival circuit, it's got what it takes to succeed outside of that rarefied atmosphere.
Paddington sets the bear -- uh, bar -- very high for any and all family films that will come out this year, but more importantly, you and your kids will love it.
Boring and bloated, it's as if some conglomerate of agents and execs and international moneymen changed the programming and language of Michael Mann with the hope that he might be Michael Bay.

"Still Alice"might sound maudlin, or more on the frequency of a made-for-TV movie than what it is. But this is not only sensitive material handled with tact, it's also sensitive material bolstered and braced by Moore's stunning performance.
Gripping, smart and genuinely thrilling, Black Sea elevates itself above most other thrillers by how wisely and well it brings you down to the depths alongside its crew.

Stale, strained and sadly dismal considering all parties involved, Mortdecai wants to be a globe-trotting roguish romp crossing the globe in a bespoke suit, but it feels more like a brandy-soaked nap in grandad's threadbare housecoat.

Project Almanac has enough heart and brains to keep it steady even as the camera isn't, and its wires-and-widgets variation on "The Monkey's Paw" is very much informed and improved by the charm and capabilities of its young cast.

A documentary with a paralyzingly narrow focus, and one whose bigger question - What is happening to the news as we know it in this age of fractured and freewheeling media?- is shunned in favor of a simpler one: Doesn't Cenk Uygur seem like a great guy?
It's hard to not feel a slight sense of disappointment when what looks like a steaming hot slab of fresh action filmmaking hot off the grill turns out to be microwaved leftovers.
A feel-good movie that earns all those good feelings, "McFarland, USA" might be running on a predetermined track, but the heart it shows along the journey is what makes it a winner.

A swollen, strangulated film, a mad mishmash of the past 40 years in science fiction that has a half-wolf soldier played by Channing Tatum find and guard Mila Kunis' maid-turned-galactic-monarch Jupiter Jones.

"Seventh Son" tells a story of dragons, witches, ghosts and ogres, but the most fantastic thing about it is the idea that someone thought this lumpy, bumpy and swollen sack of tired tropes and cluttered CGI would attract audiences.

Obsessed with money, willfully wrongheaded about sex and crippled by its own construction, Fifty Shades of Grey is too many kinds of awful to work as anything but accidental sociology: We get the smut we deserve.
Unrepentant, uneven and unique, "Da Sweet Blood of Jesus" proves that Lee can still make a film worthy of the arguments it will most certainly start.
Like a perfect cocktail mixes the sour with the sweet and the bright with the boozy, "Focus" combines seamless, superbly-crafted filmmaking with the fizz and fun created by its leads.
'Twilight' alum Taylor Lautner gets physical in a gritty-glossy New York story of crime, star-crossed love and Parkour-style stunts for an agreeably lightweight time-killer thriller.

The Lazarus Effect doesn't exactly break new ground, but it nonetheless finds plenty to relish in the mouldering bits it stitches together as it gives classic themes about death, life and the soul a literal and figurative shot in the arm.

You'll be told repeatedly in whispers and shouts, that Chappie has feelings. It's too bad that neither the philosophy nor the pyrotechnics on-screen in "Chappie" can distract you from your own sinking feeling that you've seen almost all of this before.

But I can't bring myself to hate Unfinished Business as it gives Vaughn, Franco et al. juuuuust enough funny stuff to do while being agreeably mediocre; it'd be like kicking a dog for its failure to be a cat.

With long-building fears and sudden shocks both in profusion, It Follows is one of the better horror films in recent memory precisely because it turns the border between the everyday and the supernatural into a knife-edge that cuts deep into your fears.
It's a expansive, expensive faux-period romance with all of the resources and craftsmanship of the great British costume dramas ... but, you know, for kids.
A startlingly enjoyable and well-made action film leavened by humor and slicked along by style, made by, for, and about people who've seen far too many Bond films.

Compared to most action films, Run All Night is just fine; a little consideration and better writing might, just might, have elevated it above the pack of B-grade action films it resolutely strands itself in.
American Sniper rings out with the sound of shots fired, but the silences between its pulls on the trigger are entirely too full of unanswered questions and missed opportunities.

This film, like this franchise, was never going to be great ---- but if you can get into its gee-whiz vibe and its mix of stonefaced deadpans and serious slapstick, you're in for a movie you will appreciate and your kids will love.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Autómata" is a movie that's all look and no feel, all sizzle and no steak; while it's remarkably easy to appreciate a film with such nimble visuals, the lead-footed storytelling makes it difficult to care.
Unflinching, unsentimental and never unconsidered, "Fury"'s rumbling, metal-clad exterior has real humanity, fragile and frightened, captured and caged deep within it.
"Addicted" doesn't fail because it wants to provide steamy, soapy melodrama to a mainstream audience; its faults are a function of its judgment, not of its genre ... more Cinemax than cinematic.
The Book of Life may be crowded, bumptious, messy and overly ambitious, and yet it's unique and excitingly fresh when it succeeds, with a good heart behind its mustaches, magic and madness.

"The Best of Me" to actual romance what pro wrestling is to actual sports: A loud, overdone mix of sweaty clinches and implausible events leading to a conclusion you knew well before the start, never mind before the end.
Both ludicrous and ludicrously entertaining, "John Wick's" stylish look, B-movie vibe and less-is-more, longer-takes-are-stronger-takes approach to action make it a standout.

Nolan's "Interstellar" spends hundreds of millions to take the audience on a journey to the farthest parts of the cosmos ... so they can be told sentiments as close, and as cheap, as any of the offerings at your local Hallmark card retailer.

Before I Go To Sleep's combination of talents on both sides of the camera means that while it may not rocket you to the edge of your seat as quickly and cruelly as the recent Gone Girl, it's hardly a snooze.
This smart thriller-drama has dark gravity and a sharp-toothed smile, with Jake Gyllenhaal giving one of 2014's best performances in an economic horror film that oozes through the L.A. night.

Those who appreciate Mr. Edwards' appropriation of Mr. Malick's approach will find "The Better Angels" lives up to its aspirations; those with no patience for shots of wind on crops will find the film crashes on the sharp-rocked shore of its pretensions.

Your kids will love it. And frankly, they should: Big Hero 6 is zippy, beautifully made, fraught with action and peril but never scary or bloody and features a vocal team of actors so smooth and polished it verges on the criminal.
St. Vincent is the kind of movie that actually ends with a scene where Bill Murray essentially receives a on-screen standing ovation for being Bill Murray.
"A Most Violent Year" is a slow-burn drama about what kinds of compromises you'll make in order to tell yourself you haven't compromised.
Thrilling, heartfelt, and a terrific curtain-raiser for the final battle, Mockingjay Part 1 takes the Hunger Games series to new heights even as it sings in its own voice.

"Selma" is one of the best American films of the year - and indeed perhaps the best - precisely because it does not simply show what Dr. King did for America in his day; it also wonders explicitly what we have left undone for America in ours.

From its backroom politics to its bedroom activities, "The Circle" has a sincerity and an honesty that shames far more expensive but over-polished dramas; "The Circle" shows you both the happy ending and the incredibly hard work it took to get there.

Foxcatcher crystallizes Miller's technique and concerns the way a dip in the temperature turns free-flowing water into hard-edged ice, as great performances and skillful technique transform history and tragedy into strong, striking art.
"The Captive" bores us with its onscreen mystery while leaving another, more important one unanswered: What exactly happened to director Atom Egoyan?

The Penguins of Madagascar doesn't have the high points of other animated films, they can't match it in one specific area: Sheer, chaotic comedy craziness right out of the classic old-school whack-with-a-frying-pan animation playbook.
Watching Horrible Bosses 2, I was occasionally surprised when looking to my immediate left did not reveal a window with a wing and clouds on the other side of it.
"Top Five" may be Chris Rock's biggest and boldest film as a director and writer, but a sharper, smarter, realer script would have made it far more than just a lazy, lightweight laughfest.

So, yes, if you watch inherent Vice as a whodunnit, you'll be disappointed -- but if you watch not as a whodunnit but rather as a whahappened, it's a film that's both funny and freaky, a pitch-perfect portrait of a time that never was.
This Annie isn't a movie; it's a series of bits and blobs and smiles and sights, designed to be viewed in GIF form on a Tumblr page that recounts its highlights.
Unbroken may be as imperfect as it is impassioned, but it also precisely knows what story it wants to tell you, and how.

Most of the time, Hollywood applies so much energy to warming your heart, the excess energy turns your brain to mush. The Good Lie works as well as it does precisely because of an intelligence, humanity and restraint we rarely see in Hollywood films.

The Gunman simply doesn't work as either escapist entertainment or a serious political thriller; it may very well fire a thousand shots in its pursuit of action and excitement, but very few -- if any of them -- go the distance to the finale.
As animated sci-fi for small fry, it's a success whose modest but well-executed ambitions are no small part of its charm.

Trainwreck is worth seeing and worth talking about, but it's too managed and well-conducted; hopefully, next time, Schumer will really go off the rails and show us something truly worth looking for in the wreckage.

After his recent string of what feels like too many comic-book blockbusters, social-media memes and chat-show appearances, it's nice to see McKellen in a role that actually demands - and rewards - his acting abilities.
Disturbing, honest and compelling, "The Stanford Prison Experiment" turns a well-known story into must-see storytelling, depicting the ugly truth through gorgeous filmmaking.
