movie_review_blurb: If yesterday's headlines are today's trash, think of writer-director John Herzfeld as the friendly neighborhood garbageman who brings the dumpster straight to your door.
The story is nothing more than a series of set-ups for Green to do his thing, and with no one to yell "cut," Green keeps going and going and going, usually long after the laugh has faded.
If "Heathers" was the last word in angry-teen movies back in 1989, "Ghost World" is its perfect contemporary companion piece.

That's what this two-hour workout for the senses is all about: exploring, embracing and exploding all the cliches of the musical comedy genre. ... walks a tightrope between gaudy camp and full-bodied romance.
a Waterford crystal candy dish full of dusty mints ... an episodic, paper-thin story that seems to have been lifted from a 35-year-old Jack Lemmon movie.
not so much Hitchcock as it is Crock Pot, a pound of odds and ends tossed together and left to stew until whatever flavor they may have had is completely gone.
Nearly everyone we meet has a cute name (Billy Pretty, B.B. Nutbeem, etc.), an extensive backstory and his/her personal set of adorable eccentricities. It's enough to give folksy types a bad name.
It's an embarrassment, a misguided tearjerker that will only make you cry if you spent good money to see it.
generates almost palpable heat when its protagonist and antagonist square off against each other.
Witherspoon makes Elle such an engaging, effervescent personality you can't take your eyes off of her.

wants very badly to be liked and is willing to do just about anything to win your affection. This is the latest addition to the growing library of films that see mental illness not as a serious problem, but instead as a charming eccentricity.
This is fantasy at its richest and most vivid. The eyes are nearly overwhelmed by the bone-crushing beasts, fiery pits, the emerald-green forests and purple-blue skies that spin across the screen.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Without a strong hand to guide them, the stars flounder around, sometimes embarrassingly. "Made" has all the sparkle and zip of a martini made with vinegar instead of vermouth.
as full of corn as the frozen foods section of your local grocery. But still, something about this unapologetically hokey tale gets a hold of the heart.

Curiously, the new version omits much of the material that made the first movie so memorable -- including the nuns on trampolines -- and replaces it with gags that probably seemed much funnier on paper than they are on the screen.
no one can say Schnabel doesn't know how to create a marvelous shot when he wants to. Telling a cohesive story, however, is a skill he has yet to master.
Shot in shimmering black and white and saturated with the sweaty essence of 1940s film noir, "Man" is an exquisitely crafted, if somewhat predictable, melodrama...
Every incident, every conversation is a mini-mystery waiting to be unraveled.

directed by Gore Verbinski, whose previous movie "Mousehunt" was a very strange piece of family entertainment. "The Mexican" is a very strange piece of adult entertainment ... sure to confound anyone looking for "Runaway Bride, Part II."
Even the most perplexing problems are wrapped up neatly before the conclusion. In this "House," nobody goes home lonely: Even the local pimp gets some good, good lovin' before the final curtain.

If it were any more of a turkey, it would gobble in Dolby Digital stereo. If nothing else, "Rollerball" 2002 may go down in cinema history as the only movie ever in which the rest of the cast was outshined by LL Cool J.
a rousing Cinderella story that cannily combines boisterous comedy, blood-pumping combat scenes and a generous portion of class-crossing romance.
When signing on to a movie like this, an actor might want to paraphrase Spencer Tracy's famous advice: Learn your lines and try not to bump into the special effects.

begins as a fairly intriguing study of alienation, only to end up as a far-fetched "let's get outta here!" thriller. ... Ruby proves to be so adept at last-minute disappearances, you'd think her grandfather was Houdini.

your standard-issue "I turned around and I was famous" melodrama, set in an implausibly wholesome-looking 1983 club world, where most of the folks dress oddly, but generally are just about as nice as pie.

a bewildering collage of solid performances, moody visuals, horror movie hokum and gallows humor that ultimately threatens to undermine the whole project.

It's exactly the sort of raw, powerhouse filmmaking you'd expect from director Brian Robbins, whose previous works include "Ready to Rumble," "Varsity Blues" and that gripping expose of the fast-food world, "Good Burger."

good enough to please those who already love the books (there's a few million happy faces right there) while giving those who've resisted the Potter craze a tantalizing taste of what they've been missing out on.

Although 'Sam' doesn't always work ... when it connects, it does so with surprising force. A word to the wise: Do not leave your tissues at home.

Neither abysmally bad nor truly good, this is filmmaking McDonald's-style: You know early on what you've let yourself in for and, while it's not too tasty, it's reasonably easy to digest.
This is a drive-in movie supreme, a suspense saga with several wicked shocks and at least as many hearty laughs.

Disney aficionados will notice distinct parallels between this story and the 1971 musical "Bedknobs and Broomsticks," which also dealt with British children rediscovering the power of fantasy during wartime.

for sheer visual elegance, 'The Governess' has few equals, and the magnificence of its imagery more than compensates for its somewhat overheated story.
the filmmaker has great fun trying to catch his audience off-guard, tossing in a burst of humor when you least expect it...

anyone who went to the movies last summer will recognize 'Lost' for what it is: a diluted variation on 'There's Something About Mary.'

the movie is essentially an update of the 1958 drive-in classic "I Married A Monster From Outer Space"... lumbers to a wholly predictable conclusion...
Some comedies are so funny you forget to laugh; 'Phantoms' is so scary you'll forget to scream. You will, however, do a lot of yawning and perhaps some unintended giggling...

While Skoog loads the soundtrack with such can't-miss classics as the Pretenders' 'Mystery Achievement' and Blondie's 'The Hardest Part,' too much of her sluggish screenplay brings to mind another Blondie song, 'Will Anything Happen?'

the denouement involves more double-crosses, false identities and dirty secrets than you'd find in an entire library of Raymond Chandler novels, and you can bet no one is going to mistake this mess for 'The Big Sleep' or 'Farewell, My Lovely.'

lopes along aimlessly, squandering most of its best ideas in its first half-hour.

This is a movie awash in dazzling trimmings but devoid of ideas. ...It's as if the production team dressed up the stage, lined up all the right people and then lost interest in the project once the cameras started to roll.
The film effectively drives home the point that, when forced to choose, most people - even nice ones - will chase their own dreams instead of fulfilling someone else's.
Is it fun? For the most part, yes. Is it a life-changing experience? Only if you reach puberty, give birth or die while watching it.

this smart, funny, visually dazzling film is the kind of moviegoing experience you're unlikely to forget.
the film itself turns out to be much like its hero Richard: good-looking, slightly cryptic and ultimately more than a little tiresome.
throws all logic out the window, raises the gore quotient and offers more offensive racial stereotypes than any WB or UPN sitcom.

movie_review_blurb: Streep makes Guaspari's metamorphosis from self-pitying victim to impassioned activist seem effortless and, while a pro might spot flaws in her musicianship, her playing certainly looks and sounds genuine.

an unorthodox thriller that's less concerned with scaring viewers than it is with building a carefully controlled atmosphere of menace... a beautifully evoked, vaguely creepy atmosphere hangs over every scene...

what a clever plot it is, spiked by hip one-liners that knowingly poke fun at such targets as Sandra Bullock, sorority sisters and the sad state of sequels in general.
succeeds both as a thriller and as a mood piece, evoking a joyless world in which almost everyone has a past they won't discuss and a future they can't fathom.

a cheerfully silly caper comedy that mixes in a little of 'My Fair Lady' and a lot of 'The Honeymooners' as it breezes along. ...Allen and Tracey Ullman spar and slander each other with an almost maniacal glee.

a tight, tense little thriller that's most notable today as a launching pad for the careers of Bill Paxton and Billy Bob Thornton.
a deft, sometimes perplexing comedy-drama that stubbornly refuses to bow to convention or to soft-sell its darker, more upsetting aspects in the name of drawing a wider audience.

borrows a bit from the classics "Wait Until Dark" and "Extremities" ... But in terms of its style, the movie is in a class by itself.
an effective inspirational drama for those on the verge of their first mid-life crisis.

brisk and hyperactive. Some scenes move so quickly, it looks like Sonnenfeld forced the cast to consume large amounts of espresso between each take.

a better picture than you might expect, given that it was produced by MTV Pictures (who created last year's debacle 'Dead Man On Campus') and directed by Brian Robbins, the man who previously brought 'Good Burger' to the screen.

movie_review_blurb: a sometimes charming, completely predictable comedy that might be the pilot episode for a TV series you will forget to watch every week.

The film's success ultimately depends on the byplay between Sheen and Langella, and they're more than up to the task. Langella, in fact, may have just delivered a performance for the ages -- and how often do those come along?
It's not a movie for kids, but it's a fine movie for any adult who doesn't mind thinking a little after the hot lead has flown.

movie_review_blurb: Featuring interviews with such luminaries as Tim Burton, John Lasseter, Don Bluth, Michael Eisner, the late Howard Ashman, the irascible Roy Disney and others, the film is a self-congratulatory dud.

Who killed Katharina Brow, and is Hilary Swank her generation's Meryl Streep? These are questions you might ask yourself after watching Tony Goldwyn's true-crime-and-redemption drama "Conviction," based on a real Ayer, Mass., murder.
OK, so this is not exactly Shakespeare or even David Mamet. It's more like Mad magazine's "Spy vs. Spy" on crystal meth, or a geriatric "Kick-Ass."
A "Portrait of the Artist" as a smart-mouthed juvenile delinquent, "Nowhere Boy" bristles with Freudian tension in front of and behind the camera.
In essence, "My Dog Tulip" is a love song from a lonely 50-year-old man to the Alsatian he adopts and which becomes his best friend and boon companion.
It's the sort of acting virtuoso duet this film, a weak-tea variant of Martin Scorsese's 1992 "Cape Fear" remake with Norton riffing on De Niro's Max Cady, needed a lot more of.

A modern-day, screwball reimagining of Thomas Hardy's 1874 novel "Far from the Madding Crowd" (with sex and grownup characters!), Stephen Frears' "Tamara Drewe" is an odd, oddly lovable, well-acted and funny duck. It quacked me up.

"Inside Job" is worth seeing just to learn who else refused to be interviewed, including current Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, former secretaries Robert Rubin and Henry Paulson and former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan

You are unlikely to find a scarier group of screen convicts in any movie anywhere (including Don Siegel's similar-sounding 1954 prison-drama classic "Riot in Cell Block 11" with the great Neville Brand).

With its "Son of Frankenstein" climax, complete with shambling monster, murky pool, ropes, ladders and lofty ledges, "The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest" is a fitting conclusion to the Nordic saga of Goth heroine Lisbeth Salander.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What makes "Welcome to the Rileys" watchable is the cast. You won't find much Tony Soprano DNA in Gandolfini's somewhat slimmer Doug, outside of the powerful paternal instinct.
The film is a fascinating, fictionalized, notably sexually charged account of the two-decade reign of terror masterminded and carried out by this lone radical "soldier."
A cross between "The Hangover" and "Planes, Trains & Automobiles," "Due Date" is a refreshingly mean, mismatched-buddy comedy featuring Robert Downey, Jr. and Zach Galifianakis.
Even the 3-D thing, which makes films murky and claustrophobic, is a gimmick from the 1950s. And wasn't this rehabilitated-bad-guy routine the plot of "Despicable Me"?
The film is repetitive, monotonous and, like its source's title, goes on way too long.

I'm not saying that a great film cannot be made out of the run-up to the war in Iraq. But "Fair Game," Doug Liman's flat drama about the 2003 politically charged "outing" of covert CIA agent Valerie Plame Wilson (Naomi Watts), is not it.
"Morning Glory," which was written by Aline Brosh McKenna ("27 Dresses"), is a dumbed-down "Broadcast News" (1987) lazily directed by Roger Michell ("Venus," "Notting Hill").
"Unstoppable" is smart enough to recognize the unique relationship between the cinema and the train.
As Aron, Franco brings tremendous charm and depth to a virtual solo performance piece.
A fascinating story about the founding of Facebook and a classic fable about ambition, betrayal, greed, fame, envy, status and sex, the film is an absolute must-see for anyone, on Facebook or not.

"Enter the Void" is banal, melodramatic, repetitive, monotonous and dull. As Oscar's junkie-artist guru, Cyril Roy is really very good. But we spend far too much time following the back of Oscar's head.

The reconstructed film and Hersonski's filling and framing devices are a worthwhile social artifact and a reminder of the lengths the Nazis went to to deflect the world's attention from their real intent: genocide.
"Why am I watching this?" is the question I asked myself throughout the film. That and "Is this even a movie?" Third: "Thank God I didn't pay to see this."
"Farewell" would, in fact, fit nicely on a double bill with Germany's 2006 arthouse hit "The Lives of Others."

A surprisingly joyless, almost-2-hour fable about finding your joy and starring Julia Roberts, whose innumerable voice-overs become increasingly grating and unwelcome, the film, directed by Ryan Murphy, is inert.
"Hulk like 'Expendables.' It SMASH. Guns go BANG-BANG. Things go BOOM. Fire EVERYWHERE. Cars crash and make even MORE FIRE. HA-HA-HA. Hulk no like Rourke, though. Rourke NUTS."

"Scott Pilgrim vs. the World" arrives and the internerds who fell in love with the 2004 comic book, ahem, excuse me, graphic novel, rejoice. But the film is, like the comic's creator, tragically Canadian. It's "Kick-Ass" redux.
Stylistically, the documentary is generic: existing footage and talking head interviews with the addition of centerfolds and shots of classic Playboy short stories and Forum debates.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film skillfully mixes exposition, including Mallory and his wife Ruth's letters read aloud, re-creations, interviews, amazing archival footage and still images of stunning nature photography.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The best Jennifer Aniston film opening this month (Is it me, or has she been in a half-dozen films in the past two years?), "The Switch" is mighty predictable. But sometimes rank predictability, like greed, can be a good thing.
You've heard of 3-D, the latest box-office "sensation." Are you ready for Poo-D, the only way you can watch "Nanny McPhee Returns?" Bring wellies and goggles. It's going to get messy.
In the Middle Eastern-spiced, new age "Romeo and Juliet" story "Cairo Time," middle-aged actors Patricia Clarkson and Alexander Siddig show the youngsters how it's done.
Say g'day to "Grandma Smurf," pint-sized Lucrezia Borgia of taut Australian crime drama "Animal Kingdom."
Why should I care if no effort or skill is used to generate sympathy for the film's characters or make us identify with them. "The Last Exorcism" is a film without a heart.

Beautifully shot by Sam McCurdy ("The Descent,' "Doomsday"), "Centurion" is a throwback to the great Roman legionnaire and gladiator movies, but with prosthetics and "300"-style digital makeup effects.

Meet the new "Public Enemy." A French "Goodfellas," "Mesrine: Killer Instinct" begins in the 1970s with what might be the end of the life of Jacques Mesrine (a magnificent Vincent Cassel), France's most charismatic criminal.
If this sounds like the makings not for a tasty repast but for a Turkish-German sitcom called "Dude, Where's My Cleaver?" you'd be right.
You've heard of "Jason Bourne." Here's "Jason Boring."

At this point, I can't tell if Robert Rodriguez ("Grindhouse," "Sin City"), co-directing with editor Ethan Maniquis, is spoofing grade-Z, 1970s-era, drive-in trash or if that is all he can make, outside of "Spy Kids" films.
One of the things I liked best about the film is how it is grounded in the grim economics of the newspaper and recording industries.
It is the latest addition to the pantheon of great gangster films and the great leading men in them.
It is on some level a recklessly orchestrated hoax and, yes, Phoenix, who must be crazy to allow himself to be depicted in this way, has lost his marbles.
G'day, mate. Can you say "Aboriginal Slumdog Millionaire"?
It is a modern war movie of unusual poetic-political resonance and a brilliant stroke of minimalist filmmaking.

In "The Town," Affleck's adaptation of Chuck Hogan's Hammett Prize-winning 2004 novel "Prince of Thieves," Affleck skips another junk-movie paycheck to make a film closer to his heart and his hometown.
Directed by Cesar award-winning Stephane Brize and based on a 2001 novel by French writer Eric Holder, "Mademoiselle Chambon" unfolds in a series of quiet, middle-distance shots.
An odd, oddly likable hybrid, "A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop" is a tribute from Zhang Yimou, arguably the greatest filmmaker of his generation in China...
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Finally, a film about an artist acknowledges that the art is what's important.

This may work against "Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps." The film, Oliver Stone's revisit to his innovative, Academy Award-winning 1987 film "Wall Street," is classy and entertaining to be sure. But its time has passed.
If you believe that Kristen Bell, even with zits, oily skin and bad hair, was a loser in high school, this film is for you.
Marty" remade by Jim Jarmusch, "Jack Goes Boating" is a long dip in a pool of New York working-class-romantic angst.
The film, which as usual eschews voice-overs and soundtrack music, is a chorus of labored breathing, an unblinking, at times beautiful recording of real-life,
Half the audience won't know a Horcrux from a House Elf, while the other half will know what size shoe every character in the film wears. Obliviate, my friends. You've been warned.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Another prison drama, Paul Haggis' blandly titled "The Next Three Days' is a remake of a far-fetched recent French hit and a movie only the gullible, or the French, could swallow.
English auteur Mike Leigh's unique blend of misanthropy and humanity has produced yet another blistering human comedy.
Watching Statham in action is always worth the price of admission.
The best thing about "Sanctum" is the "Avatar"-like immersive 3-D imagery, shot with Cameron's Fusion Camera System. The rest of it is shockingly mediocre.

"Barney's Version," a film adaptation of Richler's 1997 valedictory novel of the same name, is an oddity in today's movie marketplace, a throwback to films cele-brating the lives of grown men, warts and all...

Shot on Manhattan's virtually resurrected street of broken persons, the film is a snapshot of gin mills, flophouses and human wrecks, once known as "winos" for their addiction to cheap, fortified wine.
At what point did films set in ancient Roman times stop emulating "Spartacus" or "Ben-Hur" and become a species of cowboys and Indians?
The hour and 45 minute concert film "Justin Bieber: Never Say Never 3-D" makes a strong case for more strict child labor laws.

An entirely worthwhile experience.

The best blockbuster of the summer movie season, a furry fable for our times. All hail Apocalypse Ape.

Not so good, really. And once again not so "real" either. Cue the shaky cams in their faces. Ugh.

movie_review_blurb: Mostly dumb, but also fun. Apocalypse KONG.
MacLaine and Seyfried a fun match in female mismatched buddy comedy.
Watson is adorable. Mostly beat by beat remake; new additions add only length. 3D murk is annoying for more than two hours.
Stewart provides heart and soul of mysterious Paris-set existential ghost tale.
Marillier is a great find. But French-Belgian body horror or more correctly food disorder horror film leaves a bad taste.
Terribly titled, unoriginal and brutal "Alien" knockoff. Cast hamstrung by screenplay.
Another empty, heavily voice-overed perfume commercial.
Ugly 3D, cheese whiz CG, derivative visuals and plot and white-washed. What's to like?
Not terrible. Boss Baby sounds like Donald Trump. Why is that?
Ozon's best effort. Spellbinding and deliriously romantic and also frankly morbid. A rare blend perfectly suited to post WWI era. Ninney and Beer are superb. Enchanting visuals.
When this cast can't save your movie you are in deep trouble.
Rodriguez and Weaver are riveting. This lurid B-movie has cult following written all over it.
A great cast - Evans, Grace, Spencer, Slate and Duncan - elevates middling material.
A mediocre mash-up of James Bond and Mission Impossible tropes with street car racing, a very talented cast and great location visuals.
Nixon is splendid. Davies makes connection between the art and the life clear as light.
Arterton is charming. Nighy is wonderful, first Oscar worthy turn of 2017.
I love Timecrimes but Colossal is Pacific Rim directed by Charlie Kaufman
This is why I fell in love with movies to begin with. Gray does Herzog, but where is Kinski?
Gritty Scorsese-like, ensemble, underworld shoot-out romp. Not Wheatley's longed for breakout film, but fun.
Gere is brilliant; the role is unappealing. You decide.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Patti is hard to resist, even if she's ripping off Eminem and 8 Mile.
An award worthy turn by Lakeith Stanfield as Colin Warner.
Fine cast, misfired comedy, more like bad TV sitcom.
Damon, Waltz and brilliant Hong Chau save conceptually flawed Alexander Payne sci fi satire.
Legendary Ridley Scott drama is lushly visual, gripping and frankly miraculous.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Aaron Sorkin's directing debut boasts fine, if familiar Jessica Chastain. Kevin Costner lends gravitas. But film lacks visual flair and is not really about poker at all.
Bale and Studi lend stature. Great visuals. But I liked this better when it was called The Outlaw Josey Wales.
A Spielberg classic. Streep and Hanks superb. This is why newspapers matter.
Shaye is great. But how many times will dopes pay to see the same film?
The great Liam Neeson should have said no to another go round with director Jaume Collet-Serra.
Paul Thomas Anderson evokes Hitchcock's "Rebecca" and even "My Fair Lady" in this dark Gothic romance. DDL says it's his last film (don't bet on it).
This gritty Heat-like crime thriller with fabulous cast could be first breakout hit of 2018.
Jessica Rothe is wonderfully expressive as female lead in this country music infused romance from writer-director Bethany Ashton Wolf. Better than recent Nicolas Sparks films.
A throwback to ultra-violent crime drama of the 1970s. Great cast headed by lead John Hawkes, producer-costar Octavia Spencer and Anthony Anderson. Should be picked up by Netflix as series.
Rousing, if not quite great real-life drama about American Afghan war heroes the Horse Soldiers.
This unnecessary retread could use a cure for boredom.
Stirring, mythic hero's journey with rare Islamic hero and great voice cast. Too violent for little kiddies. But fine for older ones.
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping, multi-level, multi-character chronicle of ACT UP Paris in early '90s.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's no "American Sniper," and enjoyable as it is, the stunt casting is self-defeating. Still, you can't help but be moved by the valor of these young men.
Surprisingly charming. Corden kills it. Gleeson and Byrne are amusingly mismatched. Buster Keaton and Hanna and Barbera would have loved it.
Hail Wakanda. Powerful symbolism and visuals, fabulous supporting cast, score produced by Kendrick Lamar. Film is also technical embarrassment of riches.
Another stop-motion gem from Nick Park and Aardman Animations. Goal!!!!
Heavy on atmosphere, light on content. Derivative sci fi murk and chronological mush.
A stunning turn by Daniela Vega in trans-themed, Oscar nominated Chilean film.
Tinker Tailor Soldier Sparrow? Um, no. Early Razzie contender with Jennifer Lawrence in title role and Charlotte Rampling as cross between Rosa Klebb and Minerva McGonagall.
Film buffs must-see doc about Lamarr's invention of device to steer torpedoes remotely using frequency hopping technology. Genius. Another Hidden Figures.
Not great, inevitably derivative, but cast is fun to be around.
Academy Award nominated film by Andrey Zvyagintsev of The Return and Leviathan has devastating power and haunting mystery
Full of stereotypes, including a Mexican drug lord nicknamed Black Panther, this would-be crime thriller film is a yet another winter-season reject.
Quote not available.
Barely fresh. Too much bad CGI and physics-defying action. Cast makes the most of it.
A reboot of Empire Strikes Back, Star Wars: The Last Jedi is overlong, heavy-handed and fun if mostly uninspired.
A career-capping personal best for Oscar contender Gary Oldman. Kristin Scott-Thomas and Lily James also shine.
Del Toro exceeds self with this modern fairy-tale/Gothic romance. Hawkins is stunning. The La-La Land of monster movies.
A small, sparkling, posthumous gem from the dean of American documentary filmmaking.
Director Andy Muschietti, cinematographer Chung-hoon Chung, Bill Skarsgard (Pennywise) and young cast make King's tale a real scream.
Devastating and beautifully shot and edited.
Third rate Jason Bourne effort with one-note turn by Dylan O'Brien.
Yes, points for being original. But why is it so boring and unpleasant? Calling Lars von Trier. All is forgiven.
Should Matthew Vaughn direct the next James Bond movie? He already has with the proper R rating.
Jake Gyllenhaal and Tatiana Maslany excel in this real-life Boston Marathon bombing -related drama
Unfortunately, while the performances are good, Brad is a whining bore.
Emma Stone and Steve Carell score as feminist queen and sexist court jester in "Battle of the Sexes."
Barely fresh. 163 minutes of post apocalyptic eye candy and sci-fi sound and fury signifying not much.
Great fun. Jackie Chan goes Rambo on Irish terrorists with help from Martin Campbell and Pierce Brosnan.
Liam Neeson should be Oscar contender for this. Film could not be more relevant.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Barely fresh. Not for kids, not terrible. Macdonald wasted.
Was I the only critic to praise John Wick? JW2 is more of the same, different dog.
How could so much talent produce such a mess? See Jo Nesbo adaptation "Headhunters" instead.
Fargo lite, fun, if also a mixed bag of 1950s era suburban America hypocrisy, murder, racism and pulp noir.
Most fun since Guardians of the Galaxy. Director Waititi brings the offbeat, weirdo charm of What We Do in the Shadows to Marvel.
Harrelson triumphs as under appreciated visionary U.S. President. Jennifer Jason Leigh a standout as Lady Bird.
New Wave legend Agnes Varda and French photographer-muralist JR tour France spreading art and joy.
Hijacked by a mustache. A crass and dumbed down imitation of the classy Sidney Lumet version.

Ferrell, the comic master of this class, carries the heaviest load in the film, as he should and successfully trots out his bag of tricks, including the pratfalls and inappropriate, neurotic and manic behavior.
More mediocrity from DC factory. Gadot and Miller bright spots, otherwise CGI slog and cookie-cutter villain.
Frances McDormand stands tall as angry, grieving mother. Rockwell and Harrelson very strong in support.
Pixar is back. Charming, vibrant, prepare to buy your kid a guitar.
Great cast. If you're a Dickens' fan and love the Christmas Carol movies, you're going to enjoy this as much as I did.
Sorry, must disagree with majority. This film is a frequently too boring film about boorish filmmaker with a lot of mystery money, Maybe as a five minute SNL skit. But as a feature, it's a drag.
Sublime tale of political and sexual awakening of 1970s Swiss house frau. Great cast. Writer-director Petra Volpe is someone to watch.
Colorful Coney Island-set dark romance has roots in pulp noir and Tennessee Williams. Winselt is wonderful.
Cast makes this Brit disease of the week movie work. They are churning them out.
The Comedian is De Niro's The Entertainer. Watch the great actor rage, Don Rickles-style, amazing supporting cast.
The fire is back. Spellbinding and ridiculously relevant.
From the title and ripped off plot to Brit Robertson's Rebel Without a Cause routine, awful.
Another Irish cultural gem from Alex Fegan of The Irish Pub.
Pryce and Holder have a nice mismatched father-son vibe as the curmudgeonly baking whiz and rascal apprentice, respectively, and Davis is fun as the hissable villain of the piece.
Not as bad as Batman v. Superman. But way too long and dumb. Who believes they are out to kill one another?
Sarandon is great. But the film is a pilot for a TV sitcom.

It is, overall, a fitting tribute to a man from Madras who became a Fellow of the Royal Society, foreshadowed Albert Einstein and is rightfully considered one of the greatest mathematicians the world has ever produced.
Food, drink , sex, sun, beautiful bodies, great music and a scene stealing turn from Fiennes.
First rate cast and material add up to very little. A misfire.
Best ever Kate Beckinsale, could have been naughtier
Another sequel no one wanted.
Crowe and Gosling have mismatched-buddy chemistry to burn. Black riffs on LA Confidential, 48HRs and his own Lethal Weapon script.
This is proof that you can be uniquely offbeat and utterly boring and nonsensical, too.
Yet another superhero movie disappointment. Uninspired, thoroughly routine, seen this before-itis. Boring villain.
But if you've seen one Weiner... A rehash of unpleasant people and events.
Another CG 3D slog. Helena Bonham Carter is one of the film's few virtues. Why Does S.B. Cohen's Time sound like Werner Herzog?
A CG hot mess.
Jacques Audiard's gripping refugee tale has a Charles Bronson-like lead character from Sri Lanka and a great performance from Jesuthasan Antonythasan.
Some nice touches, but way too long and derivative.
A unique, Gaza-shot, real-life, coming of age tale from Hany Abu-Assad.
Nice production values and gore scenes, but too familiar and ultimately toothless.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: McConaughey unleashes that thousand-yard stare, and we wait for someone to say, "I am Spartacus." A misguided misfire.
A sensuous guilty pleasure to be sure, but David Lynch's "Mulholland Dr." is so much better. "No hay banda."
Toy Story with pets. Improves dramatically when Kevin Hart, Albert Brooks and Steve Coogan show up.
Another piece of investigative-journalism cinema from Alex Gibney. Talky and too long, but also terrifying and gripping.
Not terrible, but utterly uninspired.
Mortensen is the reason to see this, Langella, too. Dig the contemporary "Swiss Family Robinson" vibe.
Scorsese-like, but not quite there. Bryan Cranston, John Leguizamo, Amy Ryan and the rest of the cast are terrific. The direction flags too frequently.
Remarkable doc account of functioning autistic man, whose childhood passion for Disney animated films was his and his family's salvation.
Blue Ruin, Green Room? They're both bloodbaths. Jeremy Saulnier is breakout splatter-movie auteur. Stewart is terrifying.
Let it go. Really. Mediocre, derivative unnecessary sequel.
Another marvelous movie-music hybrid from Dublin auteur John Carney.
Lightweight, but worth seeing for Spacey and Shannon.
A harrowing and unique Holocaust film from Hungarian Laszlo Nemes.
Low rent knockoff The 5th Wave is boring teenage wasteland.
Casey Affleck is the best thing about this Cape Cod-set, true-rescue-story film.
These mostly accomplished Oscar nominated shorts display more diversity than the #OscarSoWhite nominees.
Film noir enthusiasts should get a kick out of Poe Dameron playing Max Cady.
Fun, but It's the same movie over again. I've had enough dumplings, thanks. Ski-doosh.
Jane Austen spins in grave. Dreck.
Enough already. A tiresome exercise in pointless celebrity cameos.
Amazing feature debut by Tim Miller. Plays to Reynolds strengths. Best opening credits ever. Funny and raunchy as heck. Zoolander who?
Marvelous portrait of icon Bergman's life and work by Stig Bjorkman. Narrated by Alicia Vikander.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: #EgyptSoWhite. Ridiculous and pointless.

Director Takahata captures the interplay of past and present and painful and poignant childhood milestones with great insight and artistry, complete with haunting memories of a poor classmate, TV shows and poetry of Japanese Zen master Matsuo Basho.
Not as good as Olympus, and too much like Paris, but Butler is still fun to watch.
Generic plot, meaningless action, overdone CGI, forgettable villain. The camaraderie of the first of the three in short supply. Only Karl Urban scores.
Nifty Norwegian disaster movie.
Another Malick trip down the rabbit hole. Not unpleasant, just hollow and superficial.
The worst in a bad and derivative series. Is the next one Abhorrent?
Game of Drones, indeed. Excellent ensemble cast, nerve-shattering, technological high-wire act. Mirren, Rickman (sigh) and Abdi in top form.
A diabolically clever, geriatric "Memento" set up, magnificent cast. Slight let down at the end. Plummer outstanding.
Better and a lot sexier than "Ex Machina" and "Her." Virtual reality sex thriller is a fun Brooklyn-hipster ride.
Dazed and Confused meets Before Sunrise, an Animal House for a new generation.
Standard biopic stuff, but strong cast. Loki can sing (and play).
Close Encounters of the Spielberg Kind. Big build up to disappointing ending.
Yet another dysfunctional family drama indie film, writer-director Matt Sobel's Take Me to the River has its flaws. But on the whole, this is an impressive feature debut.
An insane first-person shooter action-movie blast. Go, Henry.
Tyger, Tyger, burning bright indeed. Elba's voice work is one for the ages. Marvelously cast and visually lush.
If there were any justice in the Academy Awards, Curtis would be a front runner for Best Actor for this "Raging Bull"-level performance.
Combine "Black-ish" with "Straight Outta Compton" and voila. A "Barbershop" movie for Obama-era America.
Derivative, risible, paltry. Bring back M. Night Shyamalan, all is forgiven.
If you like J-horror, you're going to like this nifty, little Japan-set hybrid. The talented and appealing Dormer plays American twins.
A sweet retro-romance set mostly in old-time Hollywood. Cast is marvelous.
Familiar, a retread possibly, but a fun ride, even if that jerk Greengrass is hellbent on whiplash cam.
Miles Teller is riveting. The cast is strange, but also superb.
Take a walk with Billy and Academy Award winning director Ang Lee and see the horrors of war and the emptiness of canned spectacle.
Naughty, not nice, often hilarious. Thornton and Bates make a great mother-son team.
Mr. and Mrs. Smith meets Inglourious Basterds. Pitt and Cotillard are worth watching, even if you don't quite buy the film.
Lily Collins best ever. She is the new Audrey Hepburn. Beatty's best since Bugsy.
Affleck is riveting as a broken man, a resonant metaphor for our times.
Movie down despite efforts of Shia LaBeouf, Kate Mara, Clifton Collins, Jr . War movie-apocalyptic thriller mash-up fail.
Worthwhile look at screen icon and movie god Toshiro Mifune, especially his historic collaboration with Akira Kurosawa.
Portman's Jackie is certainly haughty (she cannot hide her disdain for the Johnsons), and she's got that excessively breathy speech pattern down pat.
Chastain is fun to watch and cackles convincingly, but a scene in which Liz Sloane shows up for a meeting dressed like the Devil Girl from Mars made me eager to make my escape.
Can you say: Fire up the 3-D printer so that Jeremy (Rob Corddry) can duplicate his junk?
A fun outing, if also a derivative one. Donnie Yen and the droid steal the film from the leads...
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Utterly captivating. A seismic event in contemporary American cinema.
Police procedural captures the horror and urgency of the Boston Marathon Bombings. Watertown shootout is amazing real-life recreation.
"Prepare the Animus?" I thought she said, "Prepare the enemas." Given the film, it makes more sense.
Spectacular visuals. But derivative and hollow storytelling. Just watch Gravity again, instead.
Square but rousing portrait of real-life figures who helped U.S. win Space Race. Great cast.
Too much Bettelheim, not enough Grimm, but visually stunning and fine cast.
28 years after being denounced by the Catholic Church, Scorsese screens his film at the Vatican and meets Pope Francis.
A better poster than film, It Follows meets Ringu in bad way.
Stylish, entertaining, with well-staged violence, if not original or great.
Another mysterious reverie on motherhood from auteur of All About My Mother.
Silly CG Cheez Whiz action movie. But Vin Diesel is fun. Donnie Yen is even more fun.
Dark and derivative. PG-13? Are you kidding me? Don't send kids to this .
Adam Driver is the reason to see this special film from Jim Jarmusch.
More like pyrite. McConaughey all in performance impressive but wasted. Like a faux David O. Russell film.
Boycott not necessary. Inferior doggie It's a Wonderful Life will vanish. Dennis Quaid worth weight in gold, however.
Newt Scamander is a rather charmless wizard boy-man. A lot of gratuitous CGI to make up for derivative story.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Empowering, if not very authentic.
If The Day the Earth Stood still (the original) were silly and derivative, this would be it. Bodes unwell for Blade Runner sequel.
A unique, brilliantly acted twist on an indie coming-of-age film.
Sublime, another rapturous family story from Japanese auteur Hirokazu Koreeda.
A hybridized, John Ford-infused, French Western from writer of Jacques Audiard films.
Like their previous entry A Cat in Paris, film soars on wings of directors' film noir fancy with a villain worthy of Fritz Lang. Music by Serge Besset is gigantic asset.
Spiritually dead film-making with canned classic-rock accompaniment. Can't wait for more avocado-men to meet their end. Enchantress is terrible villain. Robbie is only source of fun.
One of the best American films of the year. Bridges is Oscar bait, again.
Gripping, real-life war story ends with unforgettable shootout in Prague Cathedral. Cast is first rate.
These Dogs make you want to howl.
If you liked TV's Parenthood, you'll like John Krasinski's well-played, enjoyable if also predictable, frequently familiar family dramedy The Hollars.
Welcome back, Bridget Jones.
Provocateur Oliver Stone makes comeback with "Snowden." Gordon-Levitt and Woodley make fine pair. Lightning rod figure is fascinating centerpiece of important film.
Do not miss this film gift from Ron Howard. A year's ten best to be sure.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A far cry from the 1960 Sturges film, never mind the Kurosawa classic. But better than expected. Washington and Pratt make a fun, if unlikely duo.
Kate Winslet as sexy femme fatale with a wicked pair of shears is a lot of fun. As her mum "Mad" Molly, Judy David triumphs.
Break out the Bolly and caviar, darlings. Welcome back, Eddie and Patsy.
A real-life transformative fable from filmmaker Mira Nair with a unique and vibrant setting. All that and Lupita Nyong'o.

A funny, fact-based heist movie about a bunch of nitwits? Zach Galifianakis, Kristen Wiig, Kate McKinnon, Owen Wilson, Leslie Jones and Jason Sudeikis? Do they know this is better than "Ghostbusters?"
Completely derivative but Green has wistful majesty; young cast is excellent, and Burton's visuals dazzle.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: TGOTT goes nowhere slowly. At least Gone Girl was trashy fun.
A lot more fun than Batman v Superman. Affleck and Kendrick have nice chemistry.
Not as great as Feel My Pain or Let Me Explain, but still great fun.
It's a Wonderful Life to the tenth power.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another lone samurai movie. Cruise doing strong and silent is a bit dull. Plot not exactly surprising.
An important and mature film about 19th century Japanese artist Hokusai and his brilliant, perhaps equally talented daughter.
If you liked Robert Altman's Short Cuts, you'll want to see this award-winning Kelly Reichhardt film.
Inferno not exactly scintillating. James bond-movie locations are nice, however.
Not great, but Rye grows on you. Cooper is terrific as Salinger.
Twisted tale from Chan-wook Park is Korean hybrid Gothic pleasure.
Dull, talky, derivative, full of the usual CGI cheez whiz. Cumberbatch is the epitome of vanilla.
A first class, corporation-shaming disaster movie for our hard-pressed times.
A spectacularly adroit and daring piece of cinematic legerdemain, Abbas Kiarostami's "Certified Copy" may be too clever for its own good.
This crowd-funded sleeper recalls such genre masters as the Coen brothers and Sam Peckinpah. See this.
If you think you can't sit through another vampire movie, think again.
I honestly could not take this art house Omen seriously, however much fun it may be to watch Swinton suffer and however languid and lyrical director Lynne Ramsay's visual compositions might be.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: McGregor and Blunt have a sweet chemistry as the two people thrown together by this fishy tale.
'John Carter' is the best-looking 3-D sci-fi adventure since 'Avatar.' At a reported $250 million plus, it certainly cost enough.
Yet another variation of a Girl and a Dark House...
Stripped of Boston-accent, 'Flynn' flops.
Was it because 'The Dukes of Hazzard' and 'The A-Team' worked out so well for us?
Less a movie than three half-hour installments in a semi-mediocre sitcom, 'Jeff, Who Lives at Home'...
'Casa de mi Padre,' a comedy spoof from Will Ferrell and company, may be the mostly Spanish-language answer to Three Amigos.'
What lifts 'Undefeated' above other sports docs is the remarkable force of Bill Courtney's personality.
'The Most Dangerous Game' meets 'Dawson's Creek.'
The best thing about Mirror Mirror is a Bolly-wood dance number seen over the final credits...better than the movie that precedes it.
'Wrath of the Titans' is a Greek tragedy...I felt like I was being pounded to death by the theater's subwoofers and having things flung at me from the screen.
This is one Reunion worth attending.
Jiro Ono makes sushi Dreams come true
Urban decay finds home in Pruitt-Igoe
movie_title: The Pruitt-igoe Myth: An Urban History (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cracks show in Thin Ice
This is slapstick with the emphasis on the slap.
The best hockey comedy since 'Slap Shot.'
The film is 100 minutes of bad lighting, bad editing, dodgy sound, science-fiction-film cliches and CGI Cheez Whiz.
Get your geek on.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This movie has its tongue so firmly in its cheek, it's poking through and making a really nasty hole.
Jason Segel soars in Judd Apatow comedy
Quoth The Raven, this is a bore
The artistry in this Aardman effort is most evident in dizzyingly acrobatic sequences evoking traditional action-movie mayhem and classic slapstick comedy.
'Hulk, smash,' is the inner-child battle cry of the comic-book world, and this mash-'em-up mantra is finally getting its due on the big screen.
A South of the Border crime drama wrapped inside an action movie in the shoot-'em-up-blow-'em-up style of the late, great Sam Peckinpah ('The Wild Bunch').
They're not super; they're superannuated 'Avengers.' If I had to put money on which film would still be standing in theaters come Labor Day, it would be this one.
Seriously sick, in the good way.
What constitutes imprisonment and what constitutes a film?
The film lacks quips, Q and gadgets. But it is nonstop action.

Another heavily weighted, often histrionic effort from writer/director Oren Moverman and actor Woody Harrelson, 'Rampart' gives Harrelson plenty of opportunity to chew the bark off the palm trees in Los Angeles.
Pretty tame 'Zoo'
Though you may try your best not to get sucked into this man-animal love story, resistance is probably futile.
'The Artist' paints a glorious picture of old Hollyood.
Are you ready for some "Sexual Healing," David Cronenberg-style?
Mamma mia! Why would you turn the story of Margaret Thatcher into a tale of a sweet, dotty old lady?
Mark Wahlberg struggles to deliver the goods in 'Contraband'.
As funny as 'Bridesmaids' and almost as gross...
A surprisingly existential and cosmopolitan post-apocalyptic thriller...
What if you combined sex, lies and videotape, moody synth music and a butt-kicking babe?
The 1990 drama 'Memphis Belle' may have had more gravitas. But what it lacks in finesse, 'Red Tails' makes up for in enthusiasm.
Half the time you sit there wondering, what sort of mother lets her bereft 11-year-old wander New York City alone or in the company of an elderly stranger?
You won't hear the names Merce Cunningham, Martha Graham, Paul Taylor or Bob Fosse breathed herein.
In spite of its exotic origins, 'Silent Souls' might best be described as a Slavic version of William Faulkner's 'As I Lay Dying.'
Giving a seriously Marlene-Dietrich-like performance in her first major role, Ni Ni is spellbinding as the hooker with a heart of gold.
t could have been a 'Deliverance' for a new generation. Instead, it's another entry in the 2012 winter of our discontent at the movies.
'Man on a Ledge' is a film that was probably designed to be seen on an airplane, where you wouldn't care what it was about or that it was not very good but at least it passed the time.

Giving new meaning to the expression "upstairs/downstairs," 'Albert Nobbs' is a period piece about a cross-dressing, gay, single woman passing as a man and working as a butler in a posh Victorian-era Dublin hostelry.

The Cirque du -Soleil of strip joints, Paris landmark cabaret Crazy Horse may strike some as an inappropriate institution for a documentary by the great Cambridge-and-Paris-based filmmaker Frederick Wiseman
The ghosts are a-poppin' in the genuinely scary Hammer Film release 'The Woman in Black,' an old-fashioned haunted house movie with Harry Potter himself in the lead.
'The Innkeepers' offers room with a 'Boo!'
What the film, directed by Josh Trank and written by him and Max Landis, lacks in Spielbergian production values, it makes up for in imagination.
My advice to these filmmakers otherwise is take your 'national security directive,' shove it into your 'encryption packet' and 'initiate damage control.'
The in-your-face 3-D effects -- debris flying, etc. - are fun at times, but not enough to justify the darkened screen or warrant wearing those glasses and paying extra.
Can I just listen to 'Unchained Melody,' again?
At least give Madonna credit for playing the Sex Pistols' 'Pretty Vacant' on the soundtrack. 'W.E.' is film as auction catalog come-to-life.
This means wah?
A Balkanized 'Hurt Locker,' Ralph Fiennes' 'Coriolanus' is a timely, aptly fierce, IED-rigged adaptation of the Shakespeare tragedy
A Navy recruitment poster riding a wave of well-deserved Navy SEAL enthusiasm, 'Act of Valor' arrives disguised as a feature film.
Depp's Barnabas is a Kabuki-faced boy vampire with a notably smooth visage for a character played by a 48-year-old man.
This is one funny, gory, high-class crime thriller and my favorite Norwegian export since 'Troll Hunter.'
It's 'Spartacus' en pointe.
Great Danes 'Klown' Around
Half relentless cutsie-wootsies, half sentimental slop, 'Ruby Sparks' has no sparks, not even between real-life couple Dano and Kazan, and little originality.
'The Babymakers' is so uninspired it's depressing.
Like Universal's Oscar winner 'All Quiet on the Western Front' (1930), 'La Grande Illusion' was banned in Germany by Nazi propaganda minister Josef Goebbels. See it and sing 'La Marseillaise.'
'Bourne' again? I don't think so.
Eat your hearts out, Aaron Sorkin and Michael Moore.
A Southern Gothic pulp-noir freak show, yee-haw.
OK, you snobs who turned up your noses at 'The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,' try this piece of hackwork. Ugh.
So it's just a coincidence that the couple's name is Green, and their son is some sort of triffid?
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Stop-motion 'ParaNorman' As Ghoul As It Gets.
The best movie couple of the summer is getting a divorce.
The real imposter here is the director.
A quirky, modern romance wrapped around a motor-mouthed Tarantino-esque crime movie.
Feel this 'Rush.'
Blessed with artistry bordering on magic, Langella carries the film.

GQ-ready, super-rich Internet entrepreneur/financier Eric Packer (Robert Pattinson) sails around New York inside a sleek, white, ovoid sarcophagus-limo from which he emerges like a modern-day, couture-clad Count Dracula
Scary bad.
Tom Hardy is as incomprehensible as he is in 'The Dark Knight Rises'
The film is perhaps the most emotionally devastating and yet paradoxically delicate effort of the year, a genuine gem.
Girls just want to have fun making raunchy R-rated comedies, too.
Among the standouts in the cast beyond the legendary Li is Lunmei Kwai as a Tartan warrior princess.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Possession' is not bad. Director ole Bornedal has a nice touch with some things, such as the afore-mentioned atmosphere. But he inexplicably blows other things. Oy, Ole.
